Tryin? to loosen my load
I?ve got seven women on
My mind,

Two that wanna stone me,

Drive you crazy

And take it easy
Well, I?m a standing on a corner
In winslow, arizona
And such a fine sight to see
It?s a girl, my lord, in a flatbed
Ford slowin? down to take a look at me
Come on, baby, don?t say maybe
I gotta know if your sweet love is
Gonna save me
We may lose and we may win though
We will never be here again
So open up, I?m climbin? in,
So take it easy
Well I?m running down the road trying to loosen
My load, got a world of trouble on my mind

Cover, she?s so hard to find
Take it easy, take it easy
Don?t let the sound of your own
Wheels make you crazy
Come on baby, don?t say maybe
I gotta know if your sweet love is
Gonna save me, oh oh oh
Oh we got it easy

11) Grindvik - Nand-Grind - Original Mix
12) Matt Rock - What U Feel - Deadmau5 Remix
13) Sergio Mu=F1oz - Qwerty - Urbantorque Recordings Promo
14) Dual Core - Scan - Original Mix
15) Rekorder - Rekorder 9.1 - Original Mix - Rekorder 09
16) Marc Antona & Anthony Collins - Sharks - Original Mix
17) Martinez - Land-Crab - Original Mix - Re:Connected 002
18) Kaliber - Kaliber 13 B1 - Original Mix - Kaliber 13
19) Argy - Love Dose - Original Mix
20) Ink & Needle - Five
21) Kollektiv Turmstrasse - Grillen Im Park - Dreher & Sm.Art Remix
22) Gui Boratto - Mr. Decay - Robert Babicz Universum Disco Mix
23) Mario Piu, Ricky Fobis, Lady Brian - Isla Bonita - Original Mix
24) Andrea Doria, LXR - Freak Me - Dave Spoon Remix
25) Dominik Eulberg - Grunschenke - Super Flu Remix
26) Gaiser, Heartthrob - Nasty Girl - Original Mix
27) Dubfire - Ribcage
28) Juergens - Love it
29) Extrawelt - 8000 (Traum) - Original Mix - Time Warp Promo

Marc(O)
OtherWorld // M.*O*S*H* // The MidnightSons // Ill Behavior (SF)
www.myspace.com/the_uber_wop
www.myspace.com/illectrofunk
www.themidnightsons.com

nough to stream the audio into a sound system (beware of Internet glitches =
at high volume however) but IMO to really make it work you also need two wa=
y video between the parties so that the revelers in both locations can shar=
e the experience across time and space.  =0A=0ASee for example: http://www.=
ecafe.com/getty/HIS/=0A=0AI went to a party in 1994 where there were two st=
ereoscopic video feeds from other parties and these could be switched betwe=
en three projection systems here in San Francisco.  One of these was a 50+f=
t high stereo projection system using GE lightvalve projectors and polarize=
d filters for the stereo effect.  =0A=0AOne of the other parties was in Jap=
an and one on the east coast if I recall correctly.=0A=0AThere is not enoug=
h time to throw anything like this together for this event, however I'd be =
interested to see what could be done with the latest and greatest Internet =
and video tecnology sometime down the road...=0A=0APeter=0A=0A----- Origina=

> Anyone done this right recently?  
> 
> By that I mean while it is simple enough to stream
> the audio into a sound system (beware of Internet
> glitches at high volume however) but IMO to really
> make it work you also need two way video between the
> parties so that the revelers in both locations can
> share the experience across time and space.  
> 
> See for example: http://www.ecafe.com/getty/HIS/
> 
> I went to a party in 1994 where there were two
> stereoscopic video feeds from other parties and
> these could be switched between three projection
> systems here in San Francisco.  One of these was a
> 50+ft high stereo projection system using GE
> lightvalve projectors and polarized filters for the
> stereo effect.  
> 
> One of the other parties was in Japan and one on the
> east coast if I recall correctly.
>

> together for this event, however I'd be interested
> to see what could be done with the latest and
> greatest Internet and video tecnology sometime down
> the road...

Subject: [sfraves] "radio edits" of tracks?

So, I just had a thought come to mind that I figured I'd pass by you all 
and see what you think.

First, a little background.  As you hopefully know, I do a weekly radio 
show that features all genres of dance music.  Since this show is 
actually broadcast over the air, I have to be concerned with all the FCC 
regulations that go along with it.  The method that I generally use is 
to utilize that 3 second delay that we have available to us at the 
station.  That way I have 3 seconds in which I can hear a violation 
occur and then press a button so that it doesn't go out over the air.

So, the thought that came to mind happened while I was eating lunch and 
happened to look over at a stray hip hop CD sitting on the table near 
me.  On it, it had the track listings as "dirty", "clean", 
"instrumental", etc.  Pretty much the usual types of mixes you get on 
many hip-hop releases.  Now, hip hop has been a radio mainstay for 
decades.  Can one assume that the (generally) easy availability of a 
known* FCC friendly version of a track aids in that radio success?  Can 
one also assume that with dance music musicians providing similar we can 
expect a similar rise in support from over the air radio?  Would it be 
worth the producer's time?

Discuss.


-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Alright, so I moved up here for college from socal (greatest decision ever).=
=20
Tonal was my first party up here, and I AM IN LOVE! I paid FIVE DOLLARS to g=
et=20
in; 15 dollars is a bargain (and most likely a busted party) in LA. There wa=
s no=20
overpriced parking, no shuttle, no map point garbage... NO SHADY BS! They ev=
en=20
threw in FREE WATER, WTF!?! Keep your pants on for just a moment, this is bu=
t=20
the beginning...

After walked in and looked around, my jaw hit the floor... the theme of the=20
party was actually carried out! The mannequin heads placed on the speakers a=
nd=20
elsewhere brought me alongside Alex deLarge for a night of oh, so fulfilling=
=20
ultra-violence! However, we cannot forget the old in-out, in-out. The projec=
tor=20
provided plenty of sensual visual delights, dashed with a hint of morbid hor=
ror=20
scenes to spice things up. I don't know about you guys, but Alice (from Resi=
dent=20
Evil) tearing stuff up and getting all pissed off, simultaneously mixed with=
=20
some honeys getting down, challenged the boundaries of my imagination. Needl=
ess=20
to say, I don't think I've ever been that horny on a dance floor in my life.

It even gets better, the costumes enhanced my visual experience more than a=20
death-star-laser-beam fired directly upon a happy hardcore dance floor. I've=
=20
never had so much fun just looking at people! I must give a shout out to the=
 guy=20
dressed as Nosferatu, I want to party with vampires every night I go out fro=
m=20
now on. The girl in the droog outfit had me convinced that I was at the Koro=
va=20
milkbar with Alex, getting ready for some ultra-violence while sipping on so=
me=20
milk-plus; not to mention, she convinced me that lady droogs can be unbearab=
ly=20
attractive (ultra-violence isn't just for the gents anymore!). It sure as he=
ll=20
beats watching cracked out kandi kids massaging each other in the middle of=20=
the=20
dance floor.

And of course, we can't forget about the music. I'm not a house-head, but I=20
definitely got down to those funky, techy, electro beats! However, I don't t=
hink=20
I heard a single acid line that night; what a shame for the genre that breed=
 the=20
term. Call me old-fashioned, but I think the TB-303 is the greatest machine=20=
ever=20
conceived; rumors say that it has induced sonic orgasms in several instances=
.=20
Maybe I'm just too much of a psytrancer. Regardless, I got down proper to so=
me=20
groovy tunes.

My first party up here left an amazing first impression. Let's hope that it=20=
just=20
gets better from here. Now, if only Moontribe and droidbehavior came up with=
 me,=20
then it would be paradise...

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "radio edits" of tracks?

I have done a lot of projects like this. Although,
most of them have been for non-dance groups, and a
couple of pop bands in Germany. The most artisticly
demeaning, yet financially rewarding, version of this
type of remix work I have done is re-producing music
catalogues for the MUZAK company.... Next time your at
Safeway, and you hear a song you recognize, but now it
soundz like the horrible elevator version, you might
be able to blame me... And it might also be at Hot
Topic, Macy's, or Nordstrom... Depending on the
institution... they all play different versions of the
ruined songs. To be fair, sometimes those projects are
actually good, and I like to do them... but often
times, you feel like you are doing something wrong...
LOL...

E

--- "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:

> So, I just had a thought come to mind that I figured
> I'd pass by you all 
> and see what you think.
> 
> First, a little background.  As you hopefully know,
> I do a weekly radio 
> show that features all genres of dance music.  Since
> this show is 
> actually broadcast over the air, I have to be
> concerned with all the FCC 
> regulations that go along with it.  The method that
> I generally use is 
> to utilize that 3 second delay that we have
> available to us at the 
> station.  That way I have 3 seconds in which I can
> hear a violation 
> occur and then press a button so that it doesn't go
> out over the air.
> 
> So, the thought that came to mind happened while I
> was eating lunch and 
> happened to look over at a stray hip hop CD sitting
> on the table near 
> me.  On it, it had the track listings as "dirty",
> "clean", 
> "instrumental", etc.  Pretty much the usual types of
> mixes you get on 
> many hip-hop releases.  Now, hip hop has been a
> radio mainstay for 
> decades.  Can one assume that the (generally) easy
> availability of a 
> known* FCC friendly version of a track aids in that
> radio success?  Can 
> one also assume that with dance music musicians
> providing similar we can 
> expect a similar rise in support from over the air
> radio?  Would it be 
> worth the producer's time?
> 
> Discuss.
> 
> 
> -- 
> http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
>
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
> AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)
> 
> If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon
> offsets, that's like
> getting drunk every night and getting into an AA
> meeting, throwing
> money in the basket, and leaving.
> -- Ed Begley Jr
> 
> "Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily
> represent those of
> KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to
> that effect.)
>

--- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> Anyone done this right recently?  
> 
> By that I mean while it is simple enough to stream
> the audio into a sound system (beware of Internet
> glitches at high volume however) but IMO to really
> make it work you also need two way video between the
> parties so that the revelers in both locations can
> share the experience across time and space.  
> 
> See for example: http://www.ecafe.com/getty/HIS/
> 
> I went to a party in 1994 where there were two
> stereoscopic video feeds from other parties and
> these could be switched between three projection
> systems here in San Francisco.  One of these was a
> 50+ft high stereo projection system using GE
> lightvalve projectors and polarized filters for the
> stereo effect.  
> 
> One of the other parties was in Japan and one on the
> east coast if I recall correctly.
> 
> There is not enough time to throw anything like this
> together for this event, however I'd be interested
> to see what could be done with the latest and
> greatest Internet and video tecnology sometime down
> the road...
> 
> Peter

a rare downtempo set!

Two rooms of downtempo, ambient, trip hop, glitch, atmospheric
d+b, midtempo, dub, and bossa nova in a virgin UG San Francisco
location!

> --- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>
> > Anyone done this right recently?
> >
> > By that I mean while it is simple enough to stream
> > the audio into a sound system (beware of Internet
> > glitches at high volume however) but IMO to really
> > make it work you also need two way video between the
> > parties so that the revelers in both locations can
> > share the experience across time and space.
> >
> > See for example: http://www.ecafe.com/getty/HIS/
> >
> > I went to a party in 1994 where there were two
> > stereoscopic video feeds from other parties and
> > these could be switched between three projection
> > systems here in San Francisco.  One of these was a
> > 50+ft high stereo projection system using GE
> > lightvalve projectors and polarized filters for the
> > stereo effect.
> >
> > One of the other parties was in Japan and one on the
> > east coast if I recall correctly.
> >
> > There is not enough time to throw anything like this
> > together for this event, however I'd be interested
> > to see what could be done with the latest and
> > greatest Internet and video tecnology sometime down
> > the road...

to be compatible with OS X....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] why the scene is how it is and how we can change it

Someone made a comment that the rave scene is now commercialized.  I  
would only say that the commercialization is complete, the rave  
scene's been commercialized for 15 years in my opinion, there's not a  
lot of people that know or care how to keep it smaller, simpler, and  
more creative - and those hands down are the better parties.  When  
you get over 500-1000 people at a party, too, I think it's hard not  
to be tempted to treat it more like a business than just a fun time.

I could go on but I'm not feeling long winded today.  Outside is  
though, hurricane whatever it is creating 50 knot winds outside.   
Cheers.

DF


On Oct 25, 2007, at 4:22 AM, Peter Farr wrote:

> I'm about to make a lot of enemies with this, but hey, it's truth.  
> Here are
> my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to  
> change
> it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it  
> or not,
> are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned,  
> but the
> laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here
>
> 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
> 2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave  
> experience
> 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make  
> my case if
> you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)
> 4. A lack of creativity and originality and artistry in the  
> creation of a
> rave
> 5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure desire of money  
> (if you are
> going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party  
> a rave)
>

From: Unagi <djunagi@gmail.com>
Reply-To: djunagi@womsound.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <91BBBF37-E44B-42B3-8A75-D10E2AE2593A@deepfog.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
References: <81ecd2150710250122l76e5bd1cu8bbcde1ab048480e@mail.gmail.com>
	 <91BBBF37-E44B-42B3-8A75-D10E2AE2593A@deepfog.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] why the scene is how it is and how we can change it

I agree with you from first had experience.  It's is a gigantic
sacrafice for anyone who decides to throw a party.  Your most likely
not going to break even, even though the party went off.  If you have
been doing it a while, yeah you might.  I have a friend that had to
declare bankruptcy after throwing farking awesome events for a few
years.  Yeah, they were attended well.  But it still cost him a bunch
to do.  Eventually he pulled out of that hole but wow.  Talk about
doing it for the love.

I started throwing parties with the goal to get away from the ego
games, the profit centric bullshit I saw in the clubs and the
underground.  Throwing the parties for free eliminated a lot of that
but it ends up taking a toll financially.  I've got a lot of friends
that have been down for the cause though.  But like a lot of the
scene, the number of peeps willing to take a loss for a good event is
lessening year by year.

Ultimately, the scene you want is the scene you make.  Sitting on the
sidelines does nothing.  If you don't like it, get involved and
contribute in some small or big way.  If you still don't like it,
throw your own event.  If you still hate on the scene, move on cause
it was never for you in the first place.

-Unagi
-- 
www.womwestcoast.com
Music - Events - Good Vibes

DJ Unagi - Levee Breaks

MySpace Aka MyMeatMarket(tm):  http://www.myspace.com/dj_unagi




On 11/2/07, Deepfog <sfo@deepfog.com> wrote:
> Someone made a comment that the rave scene is now commercialized.  I
> would only say that the commercialization is complete, the rave
> scene's been commercialized for 15 years in my opinion, there's not a
> lot of people that know or care how to keep it smaller, simpler, and
> more creative - and those hands down are the better parties.  When
> you get over 500-1000 people at a party, too, I think it's hard not
> to be tempted to treat it more like a business than just a fun time.
>
> I could go on but I'm not feeling long winded today.  Outside is
> though, hurricane whatever it is creating 50 knot winds outside.
> Cheers.
>
> DF
>
>
> On Oct 25, 2007, at 4:22 AM, Peter Farr wrote:

> > Here are
> > my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to
> > change
> > it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it
> > or not,
> > are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned,
> > but the
> > laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here
> >
> > 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
> > 2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave
> > experience
> > 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make
> > my case if
> > you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)
> > 4. A lack of creativity and originality and artistry in the
> > creation of a
> > rave
> > 5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure desire of money
> > (if you are
> > going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party
> > a rave)

Subject: [sfraves] RR: Techno Laboratory of the Present (random academic mumblings)

"Even if they no longer truly partake of the religious or sacred, raves bear witness to a resistance or recurrence of festiveness and 'expenditure.' as if man had always felt a need to discover and share zones of excess."

"It is above all becaus they are a living and present form of the festive, the revival of the Dionysiac in a West coming to its end, that raves are now being demonized.  Everything is being done to supress them, either by simply banning them or by moving them into clubs or dischoteques, even into halls intended for traditional spectacles, thus neutralizing them -- authorizing them as they are integrated into an economic circuit where they can only be gradually transformed and reified into spectacle and leisure."

"Thus modern capitalist societies (and even Communism, which accodring to Marx was to be fully realized only in its thrid stage, that of a 'society of leisure') exclude in principle the festiveness of collective practices, not only because it is judged to be useless, but mainly because it seems a potential danger, a contagious threast of disorder which, like a flame fed by the wind, disturbs social order.  indeed, all state power tends by its very nature and essence to eliminate festive practices, for the latter can only exist by transgressing the limits and prohibitions that structure and define them."

-- Jean-Luc Nancy, Techno as a Political Laboratory of the Present

Discuss.

Regards,

Peter

PS happy bday Nico!

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Nov.3rd [KONTROL] w/ Tadeo, Damian Schwartz LIVE, Vadim, & Solar

Ok folks, get some sleep tonight, cuz tomorrow's gonna be another
rager!  We realize that many of you non-techno heads may not be as
familiar with these artists as some of our usual headliners, but
please, PLEASE don't let that stop you from coming out.  It's always
been part of our mission to bring SF fresh new talent, and we wouldn't
be bringing these guys all the way from Madrid if they weren't gonna
bring the noise!  It's seriously going to be an incredible night of
music, with every DJ on the bill being top notch, headliner-worthy
talent.  Our Spanish guests will definitely be bringing an energetic,
whumping sound, similar to their labelmate Alex Under who absolutely
KILLED IT back in March, so if you're looking for the "crickets on
tinfoil" variety of minimal tonight...well, you'll have to look
elsewhere.  These guys are known for making dancefloors explode, so
come prepared to dance... and holla.. and sweat!

We can't wait to party with you tomorrow.


-------> Greg, Nikola, Alland, Sammy, and Craig

_________________________________________



Saturday, November 3rd, 2007

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


NET 28 SHOWCASE ft. from in Madrid, Spain:

<<< TADEO >>>

( Cyclical Tracks . CMYK Musik . Apnea . M=FApa )

Influenced by seminal techno artists like Plastikman and
Jeff Mills, Tadeo's productions fuse the early sound of
Detroit with tones of jazz and cutting-edge electronics.
His energetic DJ sets are the culmination of years of
experimentation and working the crowds at his own basement
techno events in Spain.  Don't miss what's sure to be a
slamming San Francisco debut!


and:

<<< DAMI=C1N SCHWARTZ >>> LIVE!

( Musica Charlista . M=FApa . CMYK Musik . Apnea )

With 5 years of production and 3 years of outstanding
releases on some of Spain's brightest techno labels to his
credit, it's no wonder why this 24-year-old Madrid native
is in high demand.  From his innovative solo projects to
his work as Musica Charlista with labelmate Alex Under,
Dami=E1n has consistently delivered his signature avant-garde
sound to ecstatic dancefloors across the globe.



plus special guests:

VADIM ( loft.n.space . LESS : NYC)

Last heard at the wicked Platform underground earlier this
year, NYC's minimal evangelist Vadim returns with another
foray into techno's darker corners and heavier rhythms:
throbbing, deep space music that will get you lost inside
your own head.


and:

SOLAR ( Bang The Box . Bionic : SF )

Sure, you know Solar from his years with the Sunset crew
and from rocking damn near every last party in town over
the past decade...but tonight he'll show he can still
surprise with a techy set crafted specially for KONTROL.


with [KONTROL] residents:

ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )


________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


TADEO

Tadeo is influenced by various branches of electronic music,
especially by Detroit Techno and Cristian Vogel, Neil Landstrum,
Plastikman and Jeff Mills productions. In his first stage, he created
the collective Domestic Techno with DJ Slick, carrying out parties in
several clubs and basements of their city.

Throughout time he has tested almost every single style of electronic
dance music.  After a large period of techno investigation and
development, Tadeo runs his actual art collective Javha oriented to
all kinds of art expressions, and Cyclical Tracks, a conceptual techno
label. In this second stage, he purified his technique and studied
with care the connection with audience, trying to make this connection
the principal resource of his sets. Since then and little by little,
minimal and electronic sounds have started to become a natural rule
both in his sets and productions. He also has a predilection for dub
and sounds which emanate from Jamaican music. In May 2004 he released
his first 12" in his own label, Cyclical Tracks, and a remix for Alex
Under on CMYK002. In November 2004 he released Dub Infection
(APNEA002), featuring the techno-dub legend Paul St. Hilaire aka
Tikiman.

In June 2005 Tadeo released Lup! (CT-02): this time the music took a
step away from dub while his Detroit Techno influences were more
noticeable... dark and unstoppable dance, pure groove that impressed
artists like Magda, Troy Pierce, Luciano, Damian Lazarus, Marco
Carola, and countless others.  His innovative and dancefloor-friendly
tracks have appeared on mix compilations by techno heavy-hitters such
as Luciano, Loco Dice, Chris Liebing, Richie Hawtin and Tiefschwarz,
to name a few.


Tadeo's Website:
http://www.cyclicaltracks.com/

Tadeo's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Tadeo

Tadeo's MySpace profile:
http://www.myspace.com/cyclicaltracks

Music samples on Beatport.com
http://www.beatport.com/Tadeo

Tadeo on YouTube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D6PcRp0xkO64



________________________________________________


DAMI=C1N SCHWARTZ

At only 24 years of age, Dami=E1n Schwartz has already has logged 5
years producing electronic music, and 3 years releasing and working
with the Madrid platform Net 28, which includes the labels Apnea,
Bemysheep, CMYKmusik, Cyclical Tracks, Mupa and Pulpa. He joined Net
28 after meeting Alex Under, with whom he created the Musica Charlista
project. Dami=E1n is also responsible for the youngest record label of
the Net 28 family, M=FApa.

As a producer Dami=E1n inclines towards the avant-garde: developing
multiple musical concepts, turning his music into something original
and unique.  Surprise, jazz, harmony and melody are the common factors
in Dami=E1n=B4s solo productions, though never losing sight of the dance
floor.  The concept is the most important matter in his universe:
images, ideas and sensations giving shape to the concept, and the
music as the courier of that message, filling the space as the water
fills everything on its route.  Raw sequences, unique samples, strong
patterns, frantic rhythms, innovation, inspiration... Techno as you've
never really heard it.


Dami=E1n Schwartz's website:
http://www.mupa.biz/

Dami=E1n Schwartz's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Dami%C3%A1n+Schwartz

Dami=E1n Schwartz's MySpace Profile:
http://www.myspace.com/damianschwartz

Music samples on Beatport.com
http://www.beatport.com/Damian%20Schwartz

Dami=E1n Schwartz on YouTube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D9qCavnxr-Xc


________________________________________________


VADIM

Vadim, originally from Moscow where he graduated from music school for
classical guitar, has been DJing and promoting electronic events in
NYC since 1999. His first DJ gigs were at underground parties in small
clubs and infamous outdoor "bridge" parties. Between 1999 and 2005 he
worked with Jason as SubtleChaos DJing and promoting parties around
NYC. Vadim and his new partner Igal are also known as "loft.n.space"
which is a concept that was born when a vacant factory loft in
Brooklyn has appeared as a perfect spot for a party. Since then,
loft.n.space has hosted latenight and afterhours events with
international DJs and live acts such as Dan Bell (Tresor), Zip & Sammy
Dee (Perlon), Alka_Rex (Supralinear, Resopal), Vince Lemieux (Musique
Risqu=E9e), and Pheek (Minus, Archipel).  Currently Vadim is a resident
at one of NYC's most respected weekly events - "LESS" @ Annex.


Vadim's MySpace profile:
http://www.myspace.com/comtak

________________________________________________


SOLAR

C'mon people. You know who this guy is.


Solar's MySpace profile:
http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=3Duser.viewprofile&friendid=

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Welcome back to the list Apollo...

--------------090207010201060308030106
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I'm sending you a pic off list of a TAZ graffiti tag  that I took in 
Washington DC that's at a free-way underpass about a block away from 
both the Watergate Hotel, (where Condi Rice currently keeps a 
residence), and the Georgetown staircase that was featured in the 
Exorcist movie.

I used to go by the damn thing everyday, and of all the spots in the 
world I ever wanted to throw a party at that's close to being my number 
one pick.

In early May I thought we had collectively dodged the "April is the 
cruelest month" bullet, and then I went back and saw what your last 
posts, here and elsewhere, were  and it was on 4/12, the same damned day 
as the Titanic hitting that iceberg.

Wanna give a shout-out to Micheal for keeping me posted through the 
worst of it, and with the stress that I was feeling, I can only imagine 
how horrible it was for Joey, mad love to him.

I just got a taste of what personal injury is myself. Back in August, 
right when some of my writing was getting noticed, I fell asleep sitting 
upright in a chair.

When I woke up less than 3 hours later I had completely lost the use of 
my right hand and arm from the elbow down.

Pinched a nerve.

When I went to get the prosthetic brace the doc ordered from me, the 
clerk that took my paperwork was a double-amputee with dual click claws 
for hands, and I remember being jealous because he had more hand 
function than me, he had no problem typing into a keyboard.

Couldn't feed myself, shave, zip my fly, jerk-off, button a shirt, type, 
and did I mention jerk-off, etc, and it wasn't until about 3 weeks ago 
that my most important survival skill, the ability to fully extend my 
right middle finger came back.

 From that point on recovery's been swift, it's about 70% back now and I 
wish for you to get better as quickly too.

:-* 

~Nyc

.....

From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-To: osby@viberation.com

Subject: [sfraves] Beetlejuice Reveiw/ Sac Adventure

So Wed was interesting & I was very proud of myself!!  Early in teh day, i
made this most yummy awesome batch of veggie beef soup & damn... so
Dope!!!  I mean.. Oooh man.. Hello 2day... YUM!!

Then mid afternoon, i bused from my house to the bus stop, then bused to
martinez, then took this mondo amtrak train to sac... @ the Sac station..
oh oh oh .. i have to tell y'all this... i called Terri (aka Malaysia)
inside the train station.. like i mean.. i wanted to call her when i was
outside havin' my after train ride ciggy & ask the magician japanesse girl
chica if i could use her phone.. but i think i scared her... so like i
went insdie to use pay phone & I mean.. i know i have a loud voice &
stuff, but like yeah... i was LMAOing sooo damn hard that i was echoing in
the whole train station!!

So anywaze... she picked me up, we picked up Romie (really Awesome Dude),
get food, then go to her animal conservatory aka her pad!!  DinaFly (aka
Canada) was listening to her new choonz in the studio, then well.. they
got ready while i watched ANTM & Gossip Girl then Malaysia joined me for a
lil So You Can Think You Can Dance on her Tivo... then we took off to go
to the Rave in The Bowling alley.. oh yeah.. i went as David Beckem again
& this time i carried around a tooth pick who i introduced to people as
Posh Spice... not alota kids i met got it.. but those who did laughed so
hard! :)  Oh Yeah.. Dina was a Pirate & Terri was a goth girl who slit her
throat 'cause she was sick of the house music!!!

We got to the bowling alley & Wow.. it was HUGE!!  Seriously, it wasn't
even 11PM yet & the party started @ like 10... & there were 4-500 people
there!!!  Like i mean... there were RAvers in Costumes like EVERYWHERE
outside!!!  Like as soon as we got there, there were massive people just
chillin' outside, a long as line to get, & yeah.. it was mondo busy!! 
Unfortunately we missed the haunted house 'cause it closed early!  But
like there was teh bar downstairs that was the only 21 place in the whole
thing & it was primarily the breaks room.. then up stairs there were t he
main room where like they dropped Trance House Techno Electro, then the
side room that dropped Jungle & Breaks oh oh oh yeah.. there was this Live
PA Hip Hop thingie in that room too!!

OK.. CanadaFly's set was Dope!!  I mean.. LoL.. along with her Techy
Electro Housie Grooves, she dropped some Trancey Housey & NRGish kinda
anthems & classics that made the whole room like have a fucki'n orgasm....
seriously.. i haven't witnessed this kinda crazy dance floor yummy in so
long.. like i danced a whole lot during this set then kicked it behind the
DJ booth (but that even got boring just watching people dance & yell
well... kinda funny @ times) so i just danced!!  I didn't reallyhang out
in the room much before of after that!

But i did hang out in the Jungle room a lil & the DJ  remember the most
played alota old skool yummy!!  WOW!!!  I danced as much as possible in
that roiom... but ok.. i mainly kicked in the lounge/ pool room/ bar
'cause I dunno man.. those breaks reaally got me!!  OK.. there was a break
from the breaks for a set when Swami jumped on & did his live Glitch Hop/
Mid Tempo set!!  YUUUUM!!!  I swear.. like i been watchinalot Janet
Jackson & Tina Landon stuff on youtube Oooh, & Wade Robson stuff w/
Malaysia @ her pad & I just i dunno.. the dance like i'm doing a Janet
Jackson video dancer in me like hella came out & I was just groovin' so
mondo fuckin' hard!!!  Jay Vigor went on after Swami & ooh man.. he tore
it up!!  Towards the end of his set... he dropped 80s & it was sooo damn
Dope!!!  O h yeah.. i even got into a bowling game & me & my Prethel beat
everyone!!!

So after the rave in the bowling alley, we dropped of Terri Malaysia back
@ the pad & i hella watched her clean off all that zombie make up &
Canadafly turn from a Pirate into the Dragnfly who just came back from
Burningman ;)  Then Canada ended up back @ that dude Romie's pad again &
WOW.. for a small ass Sac Apartment.. there wre hella head there already
like 30!!!  Hello 2day... so we kicked it there for like 2 hours then
continued to another after party @ Neighbor Michael's pad where like in n
out the whole well.. early morn... like around 15 people showed up &
well.. me & this Yummy Chica Aly actually made a trip back to Romie's
around noon, went back to Neighbor Mikey's pad, Terri got back from work &
we kicked it the Animals (2 Dogs & cat) & then around 7:30, we went back
to Romie's then HOME!!

It was a very Crazy after after after & another after hours party, but
yeah.. so fun!!!  Ooh, & i met so many amazing people!!!


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RR: Techno Laboratory of the Present (random academic mumblings)

------=_Part_20659_26827440.1194109811104
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Temporary Autonomous Zone like what!

On 11/2/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> "Even if they no longer truly partake of the religious or sacred, raves
> bear witness to a resistance or recurrence of festiveness and 'expenditure.'
> as if man had always felt a need to discover and share zones of excess."
>
> "It is above all becaus they are a living and present form of the festive,
> the revival of the Dionysiac in a West coming to its end, that raves are now
> being demonized.  Everything is being done to supress them, either by simply
> banning them or by moving them into clubs or dischoteques, even into halls
> intended for traditional spectacles, thus neutralizing them -- authorizing
> them as they are integrated into an economic circuit where they can only be
> gradually transformed and reified into spectacle and leisure."
>
> "Thus modern capitalist societies (and even Communism, which accodring to
> Marx was to be fully realized only in its thrid stage, that of a 'society of
> leisure') exclude in principle the festiveness of collective practices, not
> only because it is judged to be useless, but mainly because it seems a
> potential danger, a contagious threast of disorder which, like a flame fed
> by the wind, disturbs social order.  indeed, all state power tends by its
> very nature and essence to eliminate festive practices, for the latter can
> only exist by transgressing the limits and prohibitions that structure and
> define them."
>
> -- Jean-Luc Nancy, Techno as a Political Laboratory of the Present
>
> Discuss.
>
> Regards,
>
> Peter
>
> PS happy bday Nico!
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP : Movie Night at the Bliss Factory : Friday, November 9th - AMP marathon!

------=_Part_13371_21817319.1194113262944
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Hello jaded ravers!

I had the amazing luck of having a video projector find its way into my
home. I feel it is now my duty to hold movie nights. Joy!
Bliss Factory Move Night, Installment #1 : AMP
Friday, November 9th, 2007, 8pm-ish until you guys go home.
Located at the Bliss Factory loft in Alameda

Yes, Amp... remember Amp??  If you don't remember....
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amp_%28TV_series%29

We have two video cassettes of Amp taped off of TV circa 1997-98, that we
have preserved and treasured all these years (and watched a million times...
especially after coming home from raves at 8am and still not being able to
sleep...)  Now we share our 90s electronica fixation with you.

We provide: The sweet loft space, the projector, big soundsystem, and lots
of Amp.

You provide: Yourself, some friends, a folding chair if you have one, booze
or snacks to share if you feel so inclined.

Come between 8-9pm and we'll probably get the projector going around 9.

If you know how to get there, come on by, if not, send me an email and I'll
give you directions.  We're in Alameda, not far from Downtown Oakland.

Yay movie night!!

Love Chelsea

------=_Part_13371_21817319.1194113262944--

the acid jazz live pa downstairs! ahhhh lol.  anyways i thought it was
a great party, (btw, the party started at 8pm not 10 lol) if you went
into the lazertag room you could still see a large portion of what the
haunted house was (which they did a fuckin amazing job on btw).  Great
decor, great music, fun vibe, cool people.  good party :)

> Bliss Factory Move Night, Installment #1 : AMP
> Friday, November 9th, 2007, 8pm-ish until you guys go home.
> Located at the Bliss Factory loft in Alameda
>
> Yes, Amp... remember Amp??  If you don't remember....
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amp_%28TV_series%29
>
> We have two video cassettes of Amp taped off of TV circa 1997-98, that we
> have preserved and treasured all these years (and watched a million times...
> especially after coming home from raves at 8am and still not being able to
> sleep...)  Now we share our 90s electronica fixation with you.
>
> We provide: The sweet loft space, the projector, big soundsystem, and lots
> of Amp.
>
> You provide: Yourself, some friends, a folding chair if you have one, booze
> or snacks to share if you feel so inclined.
>
> Come between 8-9pm and we'll probably get the projector going around 9.
>

 Hey now. Let's get one thing straight:

I have *no* shame about my candy kid past. Exhibit A: http://flickr.com/photo_zoom.gne?id=225003980&context=set-72157594251774354&size=l? on my own flickr page, even. Unlike *some* people, I have pride in my status as a former candy kid. Sweet pea fer life, fer reals. I would relive those days in a heartbeat. I also have no qualms about my love of Happy Kids. They were some of my favorite parties of that era.... even if they did reuse those form-core cutouts oooover and oooover again. ;)? (And even if Marty *still* owes me $500 I loaned him to cover lighting one night. *grumble grumble*)

And yes, John, dig out the scanner! If the pics are from that Happy Kids party at the children's party center thing in Sac, that was actually well after my candy kid days when I decided to get decked out for one more night of fun just for shits and giggles. Good times. I would love to see those photos either way!

Heart,
Alida

multinational consolidation of the commercial and banking interests by
seizing control of the political government of the United States. The
Trilateral Commission represents a skillful, coordinated effort to
seize control and consolidate the four centers of power political,

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone, J Hazen - December 1st

Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY
Saturday, December 1st, 2007
Fat City (314 11th st. @ Folsom)
10pm-4am
21+

$10 presales
$10 b4 11pm & $15 after


It's been a long time since we've had Uberzone play at one of our
shows (Dec. '05), and it's been even longer since Uberzone has
released a full-length album (2001). And during the past few years,
there have been quite a few of us waiting very impatiently for another
album. 6 years later, Ideology has been releaseed, and we are finally
getting some new music out of Q, and let me tell you, it was worth the
wait!!!

Evil Breaks does it right once again with Uberzone playing LIVE along
with Davey Dave at what is San Francisco's CD release party for the
long awaited new album from Uberzone. We'll also be giving away a few
of the new cd's as well as a bunch of other freebies. Check back here
later, or sign up our mailing list to get all the info on that as we
figure it out.

If that isn't enough, we also have an amazing producer coming out from
the East Coast to do a little live set for us (you are not ready for
this), along with the Ambient Mafia in the back room, Viberation doing
visuals, and the E.B. dj's owning the main room like they tend to do
at E.B. parties. I don't know about you, but it sounds like fun to
me.......


Uberzone LIVE with Davey Dave

Nitrus / City of Angels / Astralwerks / TCR / L.A.
SF Ideology Album release party


Uberzone is the brainchild of southern California native Q (named
after the "gizmo" -loving James Bond character). Like his namesake, Q
is a die-hard collector of all things electronic, and has been
collecting electronic-music gear since his early teens.

His early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on taste-maker
indie dance label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed club
tracks that established Q as one of the leading American producers of
breakbeat music. These singles were charted consistently by DJs like
Florida's DJ Icey and the UK's Adam Freeland, among others. His
remixes of Sarah McLachlan, The Crystal Method and BT also established
him as one of the biggest names in the American dance scene. Spin
Magazine named Uberzone as one of the six producers to create "the
biggest beats ever." Q does have Faith in the Future. "Sometime during
my life I turned from a pessimist into an optimist. Faith in the
Future ties into technology, electronic music and my lasting desire to
live in the Jetson Age." Perhaps that's why Uberzone's debut album,
"Faith in the Future" has a feeling to it unlike any other electronic
album. It recalls influences from quirky sci-fantasy film soundtracks
to "Planet Rock" to dream-pop to the energetic, future breaks that
Uberzone has created in ways no one else can approach.


J.Hazen
Sound of Habib / Virus B-23 / System Rec / NY


For quite a few years now this guy has been producing the wickedest
beats, but would never perform. After a bunch of badgering, some good
intentioned insults, and a few 3rd party threats, we're finally able
to bring out what I consider to be, one of the most talented producers
in the U.S. Although he's just recently had his 1st couple of official
releases, his tracks have been rockin parties around the world for
years. And to top it off, he's going to be performing a live set for
us!!

Check out a mix J.Hazen did for the "6th & Fairfax" radio show on
Bijoubreaks. This mix definitely shows his diversity & ability to
flawlessly mix a wide range of sounds and genres. He has promised to
bring the HEAT, for his first West Coast performance, so ya best be
ready for some slammin beats.......You've been warned.
Right Click here, and "Save Target As"

Just got another mix from J.Hazen. Recorded Live on Halloween, this
set is being dubbed the "Zombie Prom" mix.
Right Click, "Save Target As"



In the Evil Breaks room:

Bam vs. Icon
Aaron Jae
M.O.D.
Athena


In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:

Calamity Jane
Seventh Swami
Speakeasy Ray
Hickory
Sixty4k


more info, guestlist, a chance to win free tickets, & more: www.EvilBreaks.com

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

"J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote: The Ambient Mafia's 8-year Anniversary
Featuring Garth (Back2Back, Grayhound, GoldenGoose) performing
a rare downtempo set!

Saturday, 11.10.07
9pm - 6am // 18+ (21+ to drink)
$6 presales thru 11/09 at ambientmafia.com, $10 door

info: 415.294.8535 or ambientmafia.com

Two rooms of downtempo, ambient, trip hop, glitch, atmospheric
d+b, midtempo, dub, and bossa nova in a virgin UG San Francisco
location!

Featuring Ambient Mafia DJs:
actual rafiq // big sloppy // calamity jane //
cubik y origami (live) // dj fieldsoe // drop // hallucid //
harken // hickory // mc boomerang fidget // mo corleone //
peek // redstickman // seventh swami (live) // shane //
sixty4k // skye // speakeasy ray // squelchy //the captain

Free pancakes at 5am
Free water
Stilt walkers
Circus performers
Pole dancers
Massage therapists
Fortune tellers
BYOB and our bartenders will mix your drinks for you!

A portion of our profits will go to the relief effort for the
Southern California fires.  We will be donating to the
following charities:

The American Red Cross
www.redcross.org

Direct Relief:
www.directrelief.org

Happy ____th Birthday, Redstickman!


-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: SFMOMA free on saturday

Public Programs

Saturday, November 10, 2007
Yerba Buena Arts and Culture Free-4-All
11:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.
For the first time ever, SFMOMA and 11 of its fellow arts and cultural
institutions in the Yerba Buena neighborhood will collectively open
their doors for a day of free admission for all visitors. Take
advantage of a variety of exhibitions and activities for adults and
children, brought to you by Oracle Open World.

Visit www.yerbabuena.org/Free4All for more information.

--

From: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>
X-X-Sender: terry@taz3
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <10472.98863.qm@web32412.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20071107120916.P1629@taz3>
References: <10472.98863.qm@web32412.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fogscreen water projection technology

There are a number of different types, levels, and options for 
water screens:

That link you posted, is a FogScreen, the least expensive (and 
least impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a 
few casino resort clients that use them in their nightclubs. I 
think they also use one in Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride. 
These are small, the water/fog dissipates so there's no 
recollection/pump necessary. Again these really don't look so 
impressive up close, not compared to...

Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's 
Phantasmic show, like this,
http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These 
can be $10's of thousands a day to rent & operate. They are 
pumps that can be permanently installed (submerged), or in the 
case of the Taman Bali (above link), you can't see in the pics 
but in my video there are a half a dozen boats out there 
temporarily submerging the pumps. I once inquired about one for 
Mission Rock, but the sea water would require a heavy and 
expensive filtering system.

Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution 
images, way bigger screens (50 ft.+) can be used in stage 
applications. Requires a sophisticated collection and pump 
assembly. I'm scared to know what one of these things actually 
costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I ever got to use one 
(very unlikely)

I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about 
this....

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

what would be some cheap things that are effective for lighting effects or =
decor in general at a party to make it look interesting?

> Date: Wed, 7 Nov 2007 12:43:39 -0800
> From: terry@hyperreal.org
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fogscreen water projection technology
>=20
> There are a number of different types, levels, and options for=20
> water screens:
>=20
> That link you posted, is a FogScreen, the least expensive (and=20
> least impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a=20
> few casino resort clients that use them in their nightclubs. I=20
> think they also use one in Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride.=20
> These are small, the water/fog dissipates so there's no=20
> recollection/pump necessary. Again these really don't look so=20
> impressive up close, not compared to...
>=20
> Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's=20
> Phantasmic show, like this,
> http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These=20
> can be $10's of thousands a day to rent & operate. They are=20
> pumps that can be permanently installed (submerged), or in the=20
> case of the Taman Bali (above link), you can't see in the pics=20
> but in my video there are a half a dozen boats out there=20
> temporarily submerging the pumps. I once inquired about one for=20
> Mission Rock, but the sea water would require a heavy and=20
> expensive filtering system.
>=20
> Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
> Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution=20
> images, way bigger screens (50 ft.+) can be used in stage=20
> applications. Requires a sophisticated collection and pump=20
> assembly. I'm scared to know what one of these things actually=20
> costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I ever got to use one=20
> (very unlikely)
>=20
> I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about=20
> this....
>=20
> -terry
>=20

>
> > Date: Wed, 7 Nov 2007 12:43:39 -0800
> > From: terry@hyperreal.org
> > To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> > CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fogscreen water projection technology
> >
> > There are a number of different types, levels, and options for
> > water screens:
> >
> > That link you posted, is a FogScreen, the least expensive (and
> > least impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a
> > few casino resort clients that use them in their nightclubs. I
> > think they also use one in Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride.
> > These are small, the water/fog dissipates so there's no
> > recollection/pump necessary. Again these really don't look so
> > impressive up close, not compared to...
> >
> > Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's
> > Phantasmic show, like this,
> > http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These
> > can be $10's of thousands a day to rent & operate. They are
> > pumps that can be permanently installed (submerged), or in the
> > case of the Taman Bali (above link), you can't see in the pics
> > but in my video there are a half a dozen boats out there
> > temporarily submerging the pumps. I once inquired about one for
> > Mission Rock, but the sea water would require a heavy and
> > expensive filtering system.
> >
> > Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
> > Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution
> > images, way bigger screens (50 ft.+) can be used in stage
> > applications. Requires a sophisticated collection and pump
> > assembly. I'm scared to know what one of these things actually
> > costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I ever got to use one
> > (very unlikely)
> >
> > I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about
> > this....
> >
> > -terry
> >
> > ------------------------------------------
> > terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org

At 12:43 PM 11/7/2007, Terry Estioko wrote:
>There are a number of different types, levels, and options for water screens:
>
>That link you posted, is a FogScreen, the least expensive (and least 
>impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a few casino 
>resort clients that use them in their nightclubs. I think they also 
>use one in Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride. These are small, the 
>water/fog dissipates so there's no recollection/pump necessary. 
>Again these really don't look so impressive up close, not compared to...
>
>Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's 
>Phantasmic show, like this,
>http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These can be 
>$10's of thousands a day to rent & operate. They are pumps that can 
>be permanently installed (submerged), or in the case of the Taman 
>Bali (above link), you can't see in the pics but in my video there 
>are a half a dozen boats out there temporarily submerging the pumps. 
>I once inquired about one for Mission Rock, but the sea water would 
>require a heavy and expensive filtering system.
>
>Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
>Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution images, way bigger 
>screens (50 ft.+) can be used in stage applications. Requires a 
>sophisticated collection and pump assembly. I'm scared to know what 
>one of these things actually costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I 
>ever got to use one (very unlikely)
>
>I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about this....
>
>-terry
>
>------------------------------------------
>terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
>SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

Subject: [sfraves] Beatport categorization?

--0-1277272386-1194498072=:12568
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I've been downloading quite a bit of music from Beatport lately, and I find the way they categorize things isn't very concise. 

Their techno section seems pretty good.  A lot of 4 on the floor tracks with quite a bit of polyrythms.  Some on this list may not agree that it's techno since most of it isn't hard and slammin'.

Their house section seems pretty on... as does their psytrance and trance sections.

Their electro house sections seems like a clusterfuck of all sorts of stuff.  Some songs I'd call techno find their way into electro house.

They have literally 0 electro on beatport.  They have an electro section under breaks but that shit is absolutely not electro.

I wonder if they have a team who categorizes stuff, or if they just take the word of the producer and categorize that way?

It makes me curious whether



--0-1277272386-1194498072=:12568--

> At 12:43 PM 11/7/2007, Terry Estioko wrote:
>> There are a number of different types, levels, and options for water 
>> screens:
>> 
>> That link you posted, is a FogScreen, the least expensive (and least 
>> impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a few casino resort 
>> clients that use them in their nightclubs. I think they also use one in 
>> Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride. These are small, the water/fog dissipates 
>> so there's no recollection/pump necessary. Again these really don't look so 
>> impressive up close, not compared to...
>> 
>> Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's Phantasmic 
>> show, like this,
>> http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These can be $10's of 
>> thousands a day to rent & operate. They are pumps that can be permanently 
>> installed (submerged), or in the case of the Taman Bali (above link), you 
>> can't see in the pics but in my video there are a half a dozen boats out 
>> there temporarily submerging the pumps. I once inquired about one for 
>> Mission Rock, but the sea water would require a heavy and expensive 
>> filtering system.
>> 
>> Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
>> Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution images, way bigger screens 
>> (50 ft.+) can be used in stage applications. Requires a sophisticated 
>> collection and pump assembly. I'm scared to know what one of these things 
>> actually costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I ever got to use one (very 
>> unlikely)
>> 
>> I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about this....
>> 
>> -terry
>> 
>> ------------------------------------------
>> terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Fogscreen water projection technology

--0-1207459028-1194503887=:63006
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=X-UNKNOWN; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8BIT

Moving heads like Studio Spot 250s, Technobeams, or 
less-expensive Martins are always cool, though moving heads cost 
a several grand minimum for a pair, for decent ones and a basic 
controller.

But for flexibility and coverage, an assortment of standard 
par cans with gels are always good.
http://www.musson.com/sales/product_list.php?&entryQty=45&moveSet=116
(scroll down to the par cans)

Also cool are LED color changing mini par cans that can be 
chained and dmx controlled. Something like this:
http://www.djdepot.com/chauvet-colorsplash-jr-led-par-can-p-1270.html

Although, par cans don't move, if you want light to move around 
you have to get a fixture that moves it via head, mirror, or 
gobo/projection.

Just smoke a bowl, go to your local guitar center when it's not 
busy, and audition a bunch of the lights :-)

Fyi, I'm not a real lighting guy, just a fanboy.

-terry

>> Date: Wed, 7 Nov 2007 12:43:39 -0800
>> From: terry@hyperreal.org
>> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
>> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fogscreen water projection technology
>>
>> There are a number of different types, levels, and options for
>> water screens:
>>
>> That link you posted, is a FogScreen, the least expensive (and
>> least impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a
>> few casino resort clients that use them in their nightclubs. I
>> think they also use one in Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride.
>> These are small, the water/fog dissipates so there's no
>> recollection/pump necessary. Again these really don't look so
>> impressive up close, not compared to...
>>
>> Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's
>> Phantasmic show, like this,
>> http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These
>> can be $10's of thousands a day to rent & operate. They are
>> pumps that can be permanently installed (submerged), or in the
>> case of the Taman Bali (above link), you can't see in the pics
>> but in my video there are a half a dozen boats out there
>> temporarily submerging the pumps. I once inquired about one for
>> Mission Rock, but the sea water would require a heavy and
>> expensive filtering system.
>>
>> Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
>> Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution
>> images, way bigger screens (50 ft.+) can be used in stage
>> applications. Requires a sophisticated collection and pump
>> assembly. I'm scared to know what one of these things actually
>> costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I ever got to use one
>> (very unlikely)
>>
>> I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about
>> this....
>>
>> -terry
>>
>> ------------------------------------------
>> terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
>> SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

We made cider back in high school..in biology class. >> impressive). It costs about $6000/day to rent. I have a few casino resort 
>> clients that use them in their nightclubs. I think they also use one in 
>> Disneyland's Indiana Jones ride. These are small, the water/fog dissipates 
>> so there's no recollection/pump necessary. Again these really don't look so 
>> impressive up close, not compared to...
>> 
>> Water Peacock Tail screens: This is what you see at Disneyland's Phantasmic 
>> show, like this,
>> http://www.miragewaterworks.com/peacock/index.htm. These can be $10's of 
>> thousands a day to rent & operate. They are pumps that can be permanently 
>> installed (submerged), or in the case of the Taman Bali (above link), you 
>> can't see in the pics but in my video there are a half a dozen boats out 
>> there temporarily submerging the pumps. I once inquired about one for 
>> Mission Rock, but the sea water would require a heavy and expensive 
>> filtering system.
>> 
>> Water Scrim: http://www.miragewaterworks.com/home.htm
>> Newer  technology, supports higher-resolution images, way bigger screens 
>> (50 ft.+) can be used in stage applications. Requires a sophisticated 
>> collection and pump assembly. I'm scared to know what one of these things 
>> actually costs to rent, but I'd get a boner if I ever got to use one (very 
>> unlikely)
>> 
>> I have no idea why I have all this unnecessary knowledge about this....
>> 
>> -terry
>> 
>> ------------------------------------------
>> terry estioko    | terry@hyperreal.org
>> SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org
>> 
>> On Wed, 7 Nov 2007, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>> 
>>> Similar technology to that used at Disneyland and elsewhere...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport categorization?

--0-570081385-1194544272=:4650
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

it seems annoying at first, but their rampant miscategorization is one of the things i've learned to love about beatport. it forces me to dig around in sections that i might not have otherwise spent much time in, and i usually end up finding all sorts of cool tracks that way. 

electronic music has so many gray areas that it would be impossible to please the masses no matter how they labeled things. everyone has their own idea of where to draw the line between tech house, progressive, electro, etc. and a lot of tracks these days have elements of several different styles anyway. 

i suppose this is how i get drawn into the vortex that is beatport for hours at a time. not only do i take forever moving in various genre directions, i also burn up a huge chunk of time re-labeling everything in the ID tags once i'm done downloading :D

i consider it part of the fun, just like digging around in dusty stacks of vinyl.

love,
mo

Phillip Mispagel <phillip@viberation.com> wrote: I've been downloading quite a bit of music from Beatport lately, and I find the way they categorize things isn't very concise. 

Their techno section seems pretty good.  A lot of 4 on the floor tracks with quite a bit of polyrythms.  Some on this list may not agree that it's techno since most of it isn't hard and slammin'.

Their house section seems pretty on... as does their psytrance and trance sections.

Their electro house sections seems like a clusterfuck of all sorts of stuff.  Some songs I'd call techno find their way into electro house.

They have literally 0 electro on beatport.  They have an electro section under breaks but that shit is absolutely not electro.

I wonder if they have a team who categorizes stuff, or if they just take the word of the producer and categorize that way?

It makes me curious whether





*bliss does not require ignorance*

> usually end up finding all sorts of cool tracks that way.
>
> electronic music has so many gray areas that it would be impossible to 
> please the masses no matter how they labeled things. everyone has their 
> own idea of where to draw the line between tech house, progressive, 
> electro, etc. and a lot of tracks these days have elements of several 
> different styles anyway.
>
> i suppose this is how i get drawn into the vortex that is beatport for 
> hours at a time. not only do i take forever moving in various genre 
> directions, i also burn up a huge chunk of time re-labeling everything in 
> the ID tags once i'm done downloading :D
>
> i consider it part of the fun, just like digging around in dusty stacks of 
> vinyl.
>
> love,
> mo
>
> Phillip Mispagel <phillip@viberation.com> wrote: I've been downloading 
> quite a bit of music from Beatport lately, and I find the way they 
> categorize things isn't very concise.
>
> Their techno section seems pretty good.  A lot of 4 on the floor tracks 
> with quite a bit of polyrythms.  Some on this list may not agree that it's 
> techno since most of it isn't hard and slammin'.
>
> Their house section seems pretty on... as does their psytrance and trance 
> sections.
>
> Their electro house sections seems like a clusterfuck of all sorts of 
> stuff.  Some songs I'd call techno find their way into electro house.
>
> They have literally 0 electro on beatport.  They have an electro section 
> under breaks but that shit is absolutely not electro.
>
> I wonder if they have a team who categorizes stuff, or if they just take 
> the word of the producer and categorize that way?
>
> It makes me curious whether
>
>
>
>
>
> *bliss does not require ignorance*
> __________________________________________________
> Do You Yahoo!?
> Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
> http://mail.yahoo.com

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> From: "mo corleone" <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>

>
>
> > it seems annoying at first, but their rampant miscategorization is one of
> > the things i've learned to love about beatport. it forces me to dig around
> > in sections that i might not have otherwise spent much time in, and i
> > usually end up finding all sorts of cool tracks that way.
> >
> > electronic music has so many gray areas that it would be impossible to
> > please the masses no matter how they labeled things. everyone has their
> > own idea of where to draw the line between tech house, progressive,
> > electro, etc. and a lot of tracks these days have elements of several
> > different styles anyway.
> >
> > i suppose this is how i get drawn into the vortex that is beatport for
> > hours at a time. not only do i take forever moving in various genre
> > directions, i also burn up a huge chunk of time re-labeling everything in
> > the ID tags once i'm done downloading :D
> >
> > i consider it part of the fun, just like digging around in dusty stacks of
> > vinyl.
> >
> > love,

> > techno since most of it isn't hard and slammin'.

> > Their house section seems pretty on... as does their psytrance and trance
> > sections.
> >

> > stuff.  Some songs I'd call techno find their way into electro house.

> >
> >
> >
> > > it seems annoying at first, but their rampant miscategorization is one of
> > > the things i've learned to love about beatport. it forces me to dig around
> > > in sections that i might not have otherwise spent much time in, and i
> > > usually end up finding all sorts of cool tracks that way.
> > >
> > > electronic music has so many gray areas that it would be impossible to
> > > please the masses no matter how they labeled things. everyone has their
> > > own idea of where to draw the line between tech house, progressive,
> > > electro, etc. and a lot of tracks these days have elements of several
> > > different styles anyway.
> > >
> > > i suppose this is how i get drawn into the vortex that is beatport for
> > > hours at a time. not only do i take forever moving in various genre
> > > directions, i also burn up a huge chunk of time re-labeling everything in
> > > the ID tags once i'm done downloading :D
> > >
> > > i consider it part of the fun, just like digging around in dusty stacks of
> > > vinyl.
> > >
> > > love,
> > > mo
> > >
> > > Phillip Mispagel <phillip@viberation.com> wrote: I've been downloading
> > > quite a bit of music from Beatport lately, and I find the way they
> > > categorize things isn't very concise.
> > >
> > > Their techno section seems pretty good.  A lot of 4 on the floor tracks
> > > with quite a bit of polyrythms.  Some on this list may not agree that it's
> > > techno since most of it isn't hard and slammin'.
> > >
> > > Their house section seems pretty on... as does their psytrance and trance
> > > sections.
> > >
> > > Their electro house sections seems like a clusterfuck of all sorts of
> > > stuff.  Some songs I'd call techno find their way into electro house.
> > >
> > > They have literally 0 electro on beatport.  They have an electro section
> > > under breaks but that shit is absolutely not electro.
> > >
> > > I wonder if they have a team who categorizes stuff, or if they just take
> > > the word of the producer and categorize that way?
> > >
> > > It makes me curious whether
> > >

Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

http://edgecentral.blogspot.com/2007/11/begoggled-in-mega-vibe-burning-ma=
n.h
tml

This post offers a brief history of electronic dance music culture at
Burning Man, referencing vectors of resistance and expression within =
EDMCs
that are explore further in my forthcoming book Technomad: Global Raving
Countercultures. Towards the end there's some loose comments about the
curious interfacing of desert and city, as the begoggled second life =
merges
with the first.

From: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Virus-Scanned: ClamAV 0.91.2/4705/Wed Nov  7 21:19:16 2007 on paz.well.com
X-Virus-Status: Clean
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man


Hi Apollo -

I found the following article interesting, I would take exception with a few
of the points - and I would point out that there is a BIG GAPING HOLE
in the narrative - mainly - how EDM got from Spaz and Community Dance
to what you observed in 2006 - 1999 was the last Community Dance -
and at that point, rave or EDM was still not exactly a welcome presence
on the playa - some of us decided to change all that.

In 2000, I was part of a large collective who brought the concept
of Large Scale Sound Art to the playa in a camp called The Illuminaughty -
Paul Oakenfold came to the playa for the first time that year (paying ALL
of his own and his crew's expenses - including the price of entry to BM) -
to play on a cold Friday night in the driving rain in a last-minute makeshift
dj booth - he brought Mark Lewis and Hernan Canteno with him and the
3 of them delivered killer sets - followed by our great friend - Dragn'fly !!

In 2000, 2001, and 2002 - The Illuminaughty were a major presence
on the playa - we were in MAJOR reaction to what had gone down before
(mainly sound systems controlled by small cliques which only allowed
"their" djs (or djs known to them) to play on their systems)

Not only did The Illuminaughty build large beautiful art-filled 
camps, we rented
the best soundsytem we could find and hired technicians to keep them
finely tuned - each year cost us tens of thousands of dollars, and we raised
ALL of the money ourselves in the SF Underground.

Though we were primarily a trance, yes trance loving crew - we featured
every kind of EDM including entire evenings dedicated to DnB, House,
Psy-trance etc

In our 3 years on the playa - we opened our soundsystem to DJs from
all over the world - Mexico, Israel, UK, Germany, Canada - we featured
over 120 different djs and gave many DJs their very first break playing for
a crowd of people.  Many of the people involved in The Illuminaughty were
part of Sol System which rocked the playa in 2003, 2004

Syd Gris who has musically owned the playa the last 3 years has told
me directly that he was inspired by The Illuminaughty in realizing his
vision for EDM on the playa.

There is a lot more to the story - if you're interested, let me know




At 12:29 PM 11/8/2007, Henry E Kielarowski wrote:
>Interesting.....
>
>Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man
>
>http://edgecentral.blogspot.com/2007/11/begoggled-in-mega-vibe-burning-man.h
>tml
>
>This post offers a brief history of electronic dance music culture at
>Burning Man, referencing vectors of resistance and expression within EDMCs
>that are explore further in my forthcoming book Technomad: Global Raving
>Countercultures. Towards the end there's some loose comments about the
>curious interfacing of desert and city, as the begoggled second life merges
>with the first.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>apollo@speakeasy.org
>MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
>"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is nothing
>but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and look
>and look at all those X's..."
>"And?"
>"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
>-Kurt Vonnegut
>
>"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you
>upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!"
>- W.B.YEATS

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for how 
commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned into.

Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ lineup" 
driven BM format is what cheapens it.

Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to how it 
was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads out there are 
starting to get to the point where having big names and "headliners" all 
over the place as the draw for everything is getting kind of tired.

And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing "banging" sets. 
He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did for EDM back in the day, 
he sucks major ass, and has for as long as I can remember.

His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of that...the 
mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on the mix. A 
PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
