> c h r i s
>
>
>
> On Nov 8, 2007, at 2:20 PM, Marco wrote:
>
> > So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible
> > for how commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM
> > has turned into.
> >
> > Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ
> > lineup" driven BM format is what cheapens it.
> >
> > Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to
> > how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM
> > heads out there are starting to get to the point where having big
> > names and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for
> > everything is getting kind of tired.
> >
> > And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing
> > "banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did
> > for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as
> > I can remember.
> >
> > His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of
> > that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on
> > the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
> >
> > ----- Original Message ----- From: "Jim Cyr" <surfpunk@well.com>
> > To: "Henry E Kielarowski" <djapollo2k@mac.com>;
> > <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Thursday, November 08, 2007 2:12 PM
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man
> >
> >
> >>
> >> Hi Apollo -
> >>
> >> I found the following article interesting, I would take exception
> >> with a few
> >> of the points - and I would point out that there is a BIG GAPING HOLE
> >> in the narrative - mainly - how EDM got from Spaz and Community Dance
> >> to what you observed in 2006 - 1999 was the last Community Dance -
> >> and at that point, rave or EDM was still not exactly a welcome
> >> presence
> >> on the playa - some of us decided to change all that.
> >>
> >> In 2000, I was part of a large collective who brought the concept
> >> of Large Scale Sound Art to the playa in a camp called The
> >> Illuminaughty -
> >> Paul Oakenfold came to the playa for the first time that year
> >> (paying ALL
> >> of his own and his crew's expenses - including the price of entry
> >> to BM) -
> >> to play on a cold Friday night in the driving rain in a last-
> >> minute makeshift
> >> dj booth - he brought Mark Lewis and Hernan Canteno with him and the
> >> 3 of them delivered killer sets - followed by our great friend -
> >> Dragn'fly !!
> >>
> >> In 2000, 2001, and 2002 - The Illuminaughty were a major presence
> >> on the playa - we were in MAJOR reaction to what had gone down before
> >> (mainly sound systems controlled by small cliques which only allowed
> >> "their" djs (or djs known to them) to play on their systems)
> >>
> >> Not only did The Illuminaughty build large beautiful art-filled
> >> camps, we rented
> >> the best soundsytem we could find and hired technicians to keep them
> >> finely tuned - each year cost us tens of thousands of dollars, and
> >> we raised
> >> ALL of the money ourselves in the SF Underground.
> >>
> >> Though we were primarily a trance, yes trance loving crew - we
> >> featured
> >> every kind of EDM including entire evenings dedicated to DnB, House,
> >> Psy-trance etc
> >>
> >> In our 3 years on the playa - we opened our soundsystem to DJs from
> >> all over the world - Mexico, Israel, UK, Germany, Canada - we
> >> featured
> >> over 120 different djs and gave many DJs their very first break
> >> playing for
> >> a crowd of people.  Many of the people involved in The
> >> Illuminaughty were
> >> part of Sol System which rocked the playa in 2003, 2004
> >>
> >> Syd Gris who has musically owned the playa the last 3 years has told
> >> me directly that he was inspired by The Illuminaughty in realizing
> >> his
> >> vision for EDM on the playa.
> >>
> >> There is a lot more to the story - if you're interested, let me know
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >> At 12:29 PM 11/8/2007, Henry E Kielarowski wrote:
> >>> Interesting.....
> >>>
> >>> Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man
> >>>
> >>> http://edgecentral.blogspot.com/2007/11/begoggled-in-mega-vibe-
> >>> burning-man.h
> >>> tml
> >>>
> >>> This post offers a brief history of electronic dance music
> >>> culture at
> >>> Burning Man, referencing vectors of resistance and expression
> >>> within EDMCs
> >>> that are explore further in my forthcoming book Technomad: Global
> >>> Raving
> >>> Countercultures. Towards the end there's some loose comments
> >>> about the
> >>> curious interfacing of desert and city, as the begoggled second
> >>> life merges
> >>> with the first.
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> apollo@speakeasy.org
> >>> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
> >>> Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
> >>> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >>> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/
> >>> housemusic101.htm
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> "No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle
> >>> is nothing
> >>> but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look
> >>> and look
> >>> and look at all those X's..."
> >>> "And?"
> >>> "No damn cat, and no damn cradle."

> >>> Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

> >>> http://edgecentral.blogspot.com/2007/11/begoggled-in-mega-vibe-
> >>> burning-man.h
> >>> tml
> >>>
> >>> This post offers a brief history of electronic dance music
> >>> culture at
> >>> Burning Man, referencing vectors of resistance and expression
> >>> within EDMCs
> >>> that are explore further in my forthcoming book Technomad: Global
> >>> Raving
> >>> Countercultures. Towards the end there's some loose comments
> >>> about the
> >>> curious interfacing of desert and city, as the begoggled second
> >>> life merges
> >>> with the first.
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> apollo@speakeasy.org
> >>> MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
> >>> Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
> >>> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >>> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/
> >>> housemusic101.htm
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> "No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle
> >>> is nothing
> >>> but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look
> >>> and look
> >>> and look at all those X's..."
> >>> "And?"
> >>> "No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
> >>> -Kurt Vonnegut
> >>>
> >>> "Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride
> >>> with you
> >>> upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!"
> >>> - W.B.YEATS
> >>>

        "Henry E Kielarowski" <djapollo2k@mac.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>
In-Reply-To: <BAY110-DAV7BB79327FBEF704737D32858B0@phx.gbl>
References: <200711082209.lA8M9Pr9027248@smtp.well.com>
 <BAY110-DAV7BB79327FBEF704737D32858B0@phx.gbl>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Virus-Scanned: ClamAV 0.91.2/4709/Thu Nov  8 09:19:26 2007 on paz.well.com
X-Virus-Status: Clean
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

At 02:20 PM 11/8/2007, Marco wrote:
>So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for 
>how commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned into.

not particularly - but you are welcome to interpret it that way - my 
perspective was I was introduced to Oakey at the Filmore in early 2000 -
based on a handshake, and nothing else he showed up and played a set 
that a lot of people liked on one of the worst nights weather-wise
I've ever experienced on the playa - like it or not, his presence 
allowed for a lot of DJs who probably never would have otherwise
gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our 
way to be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers 
to - in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting form


>Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ 
>lineup" driven BM format is what cheapens it.

At over $200 a ticket, there is nothing 'cheap' about BM these days - 
the first time I went it cost $15.


>Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to 
>how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads 
>out there are starting to get to the point where having big names 
>and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for everything is 
>getting kind of tired.

I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did 
NOT like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the 
word and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave 
lotsa new people a shot


>And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing 
>"banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did 
>for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as 
>I can remember.

in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter 
how many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say so -
what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and 
the DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an 
evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen dancing


>His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of 
>that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on 
>the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.

You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we 
have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a 
certain point -
the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point - 
otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are 
talking about -
a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ 
who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will always
win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it 
is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his ears -
he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening 
and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse that -
you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG 
chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .






---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

--0-526653633-1194566972=:59820
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

articles like this are really great for perspective. i've trekked out to the playa for 8 consecutive years now, and the growing presence of big-name DJs, scheduled and advertised lineups, and the resulting concert-goer atmosphere has always rubbed me the wrong way. it's interesting to learn that the "rave camps" had been promoting edm superstars like goa gil and simon posford since day one. maybe i shouldn't be quietly passing so much judgment on the sound camps of today given the culture that been developing since long before my time.

and as a bit of personal pride, i have to admit i was beyond stoked to see this paragraph in the piece:

"By 2007, there were Decompression events in various US cities including Los Angeles and New York, and international events such as those in London and Tokyo. There were even pre-Decompression parties like the one I attended in October 2007 at a warehouse at 1300 Potrero produced by Want It and Ambient Mafia (watch a video of  the party here) and, of course a host of Decompression after-parties."

fuck yeah! it's an honor to be mentioned among the names of so many stellar crews. i'm still uncertain about my feelings on the current state of burning man, but reading that bit was pretty exciting.

love,
mo


Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote: So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for how 
commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned into.

Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ lineup" 
driven BM format is what cheapens it.

Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to how it 
was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads out there are 
starting to get to the point where having big names and "headliners" all 
over the place as the draw for everything is getting kind of tired.

And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing "banging" sets. 
He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did for EDM back in the day, 
he sucks major ass, and has for as long as I can remember.

His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of that...the 
mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on the mix. A 
PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Jim Cyr" 
To: "Henry E Kielarowski" ; 
Sent: Thursday, November 08, 2007 2:12 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man


>
> Hi Apollo -
>
> I found the following article interesting, I would take exception with a 
> few
> of the points - and I would point out that there is a BIG GAPING HOLE
> in the narrative - mainly - how EDM got from Spaz and Community Dance
> to what you observed in 2006 - 1999 was the last Community Dance -
> and at that point, rave or EDM was still not exactly a welcome presence
> on the playa - some of us decided to change all that.
>
> In 2000, I was part of a large collective who brought the concept
> of Large Scale Sound Art to the playa in a camp called The Illuminaughty -
> Paul Oakenfold came to the playa for the first time that year (paying ALL
> of his own and his crew's expenses - including the price of entry to BM) -
> to play on a cold Friday night in the driving rain in a last-minute 
> makeshift
> dj booth - he brought Mark Lewis and Hernan Canteno with him and the
> 3 of them delivered killer sets - followed by our great friend - Dragn'fly 
> !!
>
> In 2000, 2001, and 2002 - The Illuminaughty were a major presence
> on the playa - we were in MAJOR reaction to what had gone down before
> (mainly sound systems controlled by small cliques which only allowed
> "their" djs (or djs known to them) to play on their systems)
>
> Not only did The Illuminaughty build large beautiful art-filled camps, we 
> rented
> the best soundsytem we could find and hired technicians to keep them
> finely tuned - each year cost us tens of thousands of dollars, and we 
> raised
> ALL of the money ourselves in the SF Underground.
>
> Though we were primarily a trance, yes trance loving crew - we featured
> every kind of EDM including entire evenings dedicated to DnB, House,
> Psy-trance etc
>
> In our 3 years on the playa - we opened our soundsystem to DJs from
> all over the world - Mexico, Israel, UK, Germany, Canada - we featured
> over 120 different djs and gave many DJs their very first break playing 
> for
> a crowd of people.  Many of the people involved in The Illuminaughty were
> part of Sol System which rocked the playa in 2003, 2004
>
> Syd Gris who has musically owned the playa the last 3 years has told
> me directly that he was inspired by The Illuminaughty in realizing his
> vision for EDM on the playa.
>
> There is a lot more to the story - if you're interested, let me know
>
>
>
>
> At 12:29 PM 11/8/2007, Henry E Kielarowski wrote:
>>Interesting.....
>>
>>Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man
>>
>>http://edgecentral.blogspot.com/2007/11/begoggled-in-mega-vibe-burning-man.h
>>tml
>>
>>This post offers a brief history of electronic dance music culture at
>>Burning Man, referencing vectors of resistance and expression within EDMCs
>>that are explore further in my forthcoming book Technomad: Global Raving
>>Countercultures. Towards the end there's some loose comments about the
>>curious interfacing of desert and city, as the begoggled second life 
>>merges
>>with the first.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>apollo@speakeasy.org
>>MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo
>>Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
>>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>>House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>>
>>
>>"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is 
>>nothing
>>but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and look
>>and look at all those X's..."
>>"And?"
>>"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
>>-Kurt Vonnegut
>>
>>"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you
>>upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!"
>>- W.B.YEATS
>>

leave it to sfraves to turn a discussion about the history of electronic music at burning man into a flame-fest about paul oakenfold. 

i don't know exactly how illuminaughty fits in to the overall picture, but i do remember the camp fondly... minus oakenfold and peretz of course ;) so congratulations on a job well done, and if i make it out to the desert again i look forward to the next progression of your efforts. 

ps: i miss bianca's.

love,
mo

Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote: At 02:20 PM 11/8/2007, Marco wrote:
>So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for 
>how commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned into.

not particularly - but you are welcome to interpret it that way - my 
perspective was I was introduced to Oakey at the Filmore in early 2000 -
based on a handshake, and nothing else he showed up and played a set 
that a lot of people liked on one of the worst nights weather-wise
I've ever experienced on the playa - like it or not, his presence 
allowed for a lot of DJs who probably never would have otherwise
gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our 
way to be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers 
to - in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting form


>Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ 
>lineup" driven BM format is what cheapens it.

At over $200 a ticket, there is nothing 'cheap' about BM these days - 
the first time I went it cost $15.


>Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to 
>how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads 
>out there are starting to get to the point where having big names 
>and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for everything is 
>getting kind of tired.

I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did 
NOT like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the 
word and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave 
lotsa new people a shot


>And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing 
>"banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did 
>for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as 
>I can remember.

in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter 
how many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say so -
what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and 
the DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an 
evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen dancing


>His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of 
>that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on 
>the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.

You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we 
have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a 
certain point -
the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point - 
otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are 
talking about -
a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ 
who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will always
win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it 
is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his ears -
he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening 
and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse that -
you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG 
chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .

>i don't know exactly how illuminaughty fits in to the overall 
>picture, but i do remember the camp fondly... minus oakenfold and 
>peretz of course ;) so congratulations on a job well done, and if i 
>make it out to the desert again i look forward to the next

oh, we're there every year - just doing different things - several of

some of us were Barbarella Boot Camp the last few years - many of us 
have a quiet camp called Oacious that has
been on the playa every year since '99 - a lot of our peeps were 
involved with Coda this year


>ps: i miss bianca's.


i miss bianca's too - but between the Nevada food authorities getting 
on their case
over the free grilled cheese sandwiches and the increasing presence 
of what could
only charitably described as 'dirty old men' i guess there day was 
over - but the
people are still around

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

> not particularly - but you are welcome to interpret it that way - my 
> perspective was I was introduced to Oakey at the Filmore in early 2000 -
> based on a handshake, and nothing else he showed up and played a set that 
> a lot of people liked on one of the worst nights weather-wise
> I've ever experienced on the playa - like it or not, his presence allowed 
> for a lot of DJs who probably never would have otherwise
> gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our way to 
> be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
> commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers to - 
> in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
> the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting 
> form

That is good too hear... (your last sentence)

> At over $200 a ticket, there is nothing 'cheap' about BM these days - the 
> first time I went it cost $15.

I wasn't referring to the cost, lol.

> I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did NOT 
> like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
> one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the word 
> and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
> we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave lotsa 
> new people a shot

I love the idea of there being no timeslotted lineup - the names on the 
lineup, I can take or leave - but it'd be nice to see people just list a 
lineup (sans timeslots) and make people come and get into things. Kind of 
force them to participate a bit more than just showing up for "cool DJ X" 
and then bailing. Of course, as demanding and whiny as partygoers (myself 
included sometimes) can be, that may just be good in theory, and not in 
practice.

> in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter how 
> many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say so -
> what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and the 
> DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
> DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an 
> evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen 
> dancing

A trainwreck or two here and there is one thing - but I am sorry, some 
people just shouldn't be behind the decks on a soundsystem if they can't mix 
at least semi-competently. That's what booty clubs are for. If you want 
poorly mixed sets, I suggest sticking with the Top 40 set. It's not a 
trainspotting thing - it's called desiring QUALITY in a performance. I bet 
if you saw your favorite band play an awful set where they forgot lyrics 
left and right, and missed cues, and sucked in general - no matter how 
lively they were on stage, you'd think they sucked balls. Same idea.

> You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we have 
> different criteria - music can only be about technique to a certain 
> point -
> the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point - 
> otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are 
> talking about -
> a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ who 
> has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will always
> win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it is 
> true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his ears -
> he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening and 
> react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse that -
> you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG chances - 
> they don't always work out, but when they do . . .

Funnily - tracklisting wise, I love that CD too, and have (at one point in 
time or another) owned the vast majority of the tracks on it. It's not an 
ego thing to want to be precise or even semi-precise in your craft. It's 
called delivering the best performance and vibe you can muster to the people 
you are performing for. Sure - you have to love the tracks and feel the 
vibe, and really try and connect with your crowd - but your crowd is 
typically made up of different people, some of which CARE about what they 
just shelled out $25 a ticket for. Some of us work hard to earn our $$, and 
are more than a little irritated when some jackass who hasn't bothered to 
practice, learn his tracks, or got so shitfaced he/she can't mix get up on 
the decks and make racket on a soundsystem. It's (IMHO) unprofessional, and 
fairly assumptive to think that people should just be "into it" despite 
that.

--0-994828826-1194569004=:13138
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

> i miss bianca's too - but between the Nevada food authorities getting 
> on their case over the free grilled cheese sandwiches and the increasing > presence of what could only charitably described as 'dirty old men' i guess there > day was over - but the people are still around.

for sure. i was involved with bianca's in their final years and while there was undoubtedly a dirty old man factor involved, there were internal problems as well. i was sad to have only caught that group on the downswing, but i'm happy to have been included at all. there were some fantastic people in that collective, and some of them definitely are still around, but obviously it's different... just like the illuminaughty camp in all its glory is different than a few scattered folks decorating the cafe and assisting some newer sound crews. 

i can't blame any camp for burning out or wanting to try something new. everything changes i suppose, and if i've learned anything from burning man it's to embrace impermanence. it's interesting to note that sound camps have always faced an uphill battle out there - i guess if it were easy, none of us would bother doing it. thanks for posting such a great history of our people :)

love,
mo

>progression of your efforts.

oh, we're there every year - just doing different things - several of 
our major people decorated Center Camp this year -
some of us were Barbarella Boot Camp the last few years - many of us 
have a quiet camp called Oacious that has
been on the playa every year since '99 - a lot of our peeps were 
involved with Coda this year


>ps: i miss bianca's.


i miss bianca's too - but between the Nevada food authorities getting 
on their case
over the free grilled cheese sandwiches and the increasing presence 
of what could
only charitably described as 'dirty old men' i guess there day was 
over - but the
people are still around

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "mo corleone" <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, November 08, 2007 4:20 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man


> leave it to sfraves to turn a discussion about the history of electronic 
> music at burning man into a flame-fest about paul oakenfold.
>
> i don't know exactly how illuminaughty fits in to the overall picture, but 
> i do remember the camp fondly... minus oakenfold and peretz of course ;) 
> so congratulations on a job well done, and if i make it out to the desert 
> again i look forward to the next progression of your efforts.
>
> ps: i miss bianca's.
>
> love,
> mo
>
> Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote: At 02:20 PM 11/8/2007, Marco wrote:
>>So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for
>>how commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned 
>>into.
>
> not particularly - but you are welcome to interpret it that way - my
> perspective was I was introduced to Oakey at the Filmore in early 2000 -
> based on a handshake, and nothing else he showed up and played a set
> that a lot of people liked on one of the worst nights weather-wise
> I've ever experienced on the playa - like it or not, his presence
> allowed for a lot of DJs who probably never would have otherwise
> gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our
> way to be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
> commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers
> to - in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
> the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting 
> form
>
>
>>Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ
>>lineup" driven BM format is what cheapens it.
>
> At over $200 a ticket, there is nothing 'cheap' about BM these days -
> the first time I went it cost $15.
>
>
>>Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to
>>how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads
>>out there are starting to get to the point where having big names
>>and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for everything is
>>getting kind of tired.
>
> I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did
> NOT like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
> one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the
> word and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
> we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave
> lotsa new people a shot
>
>
>>And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing
>>"banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did
>>for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as
>>I can remember.
>
> in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter
> how many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say 
> so -
> what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and
> the DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
> DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an
> evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen 
> dancing
>
>
>>His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of
>>that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on
>>the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
>
> You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we
> have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a
> certain point -
> the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point -
> otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are
> talking about -
> a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ
> who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will 
> always
> win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it
> is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his 
> ears -
> he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening
> and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse 
> that -
> you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG
> chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .
>
>
>
>
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

On 8 November 2007, Marco wrote:

> I love the idea of there being no timeslotted lineup - the names on the 
> lineup, I can take or leave - but it'd be nice to see people just list a 
> lineup (sans timeslots) and make people come and get into things. Kind of 
> force them to participate a bit more than just showing up for "cool DJ X" and 
> then bailing. Of course, as demanding and whiny as partygoers (myself 
> included sometimes) can be, that may just be good in theory, and not in 
> practice.

It actually worked in practice.  I recall the 1st time that I heard 
rumors of a headliner being slated for a set on a given evening out 
there some years ago (DJ Spooky, I believe) I also heard of said camp 
getting a lashing from the org for letting the cat out of the bag.

[snip]

>
> Funnily - tracklisting wise, I love that CD too, and have (at one point in 
> time or another) owned the vast majority of the tracks on it. It's not an ego 
> thing to want to be precise or even semi-precise in your craft. It's called 
> delivering the best performance and vibe you can muster to the people you are 
> performing for. Sure - you have to love the tracks and feel the vibe, and 
> really try and connect with your crowd - but your crowd is typically made up 
> of different people, some of which CARE about what they just shelled out $25 
> a ticket for. Some of us work hard to earn our $$, and are more than a little 
> irritated when some jackass who hasn't bothered to practice, learn his 
> tracks, or got so shitfaced he/she can't mix get up on the decks and make 
> racket on a soundsystem. It's (IMHO) unprofessional, and fairly assumptive to 
> think that people should just be "into it" despite that.

And I'll jump in with politics here since we're already talking about 
oakie.  Today we are at the highest level of income disparity since 
around 1923 (and do you recall what went down not many years after 
1923?)  So there are folks for whom that $25 means a lot more to than 
others. ;)  And I say they have a right to be that much more discerning 
about what they get.

http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

it's just myopic as hell to read an article as chock-full of history and details as this one and yet only be able to puke out some canned comment about oakenfold. or did you even bother reading the article? contrary to what your sfraves pocket guide may tell you, bagging on oakie *does* get old. 

i know you've never gone to burning man and you're not that impressed with it overall, but it has shaped the dance scene in this city in a big way. i'm not that serious a participant on this list, but once in a while it might be cool to actually reflect on our culture for at least a few posts before everyone starts flinging poo at the easiest targets.

if your ass is that chapped, consider masturbating with a newer joke book.

*smooch*

love,
mo

> Jim Cyr  wrote: At 02:20 PM 11/8/2007, Marco wrote:
>>So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for
>>how commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned 
>>into.
>
> not particularly - but you are welcome to interpret it that way - my
> perspective was I was introduced to Oakey at the Filmore in early 2000 -
> based on a handshake, and nothing else he showed up and played a set
> that a lot of people liked on one of the worst nights weather-wise
> I've ever experienced on the playa - like it or not, his presence
> allowed for a lot of DJs who probably never would have otherwise
> gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our
> way to be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
> commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers
> to - in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
> the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting 
> form

>>how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads
>>out there are starting to get to the point where having big names
>>and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for everything is
>>getting kind of tired.
>
> I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did
> NOT like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
> one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the
> word and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
> we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave
> lotsa new people a shot
>
>
>>And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing
>>"banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did
>>for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as
>>I can remember.
>
> in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter
> how many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say 
> so -
> what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and
> the DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
> DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an
> evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen 
> dancing
>
>
>>His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of
>>that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on
>>the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
>
> You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we
> have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a
> certain point -
> the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point -
> otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are
> talking about -
> a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ
> who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will 
> always
> win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it
> is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his 
> ears -
> he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening
> and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse 
> that -

> chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .

ol' filters are for.

Just like TV, if ya don't like what's on, change the channel!

horror I am sure) this upcoming year so I can see what the hell it is people 
are on about so much. (And to party my frickin' arse off for a week - 
naturally)

Will I reflect on on our culture after? Who knows - maybe. Maybe I'll even 
have more pooh tro fling afterwars, only this time I'll have the ammo and 
experience with which to do so. I have no idea. I am keeping an open mind 
about it and letting the experience be what it is.

*shrug*

>>

>> but
>> i do remember the camp fondly... minus oakenfold and peretz of course ;)

>> again i look forward to the next progression of your efforts.
>>
>> ps: i miss bianca's.

>> love,

>>
>> Jim Cyr  wrote: At 02:20 PM 11/8/2007, Marco wrote:
>>>So, essentially what you're saying is, your camp was responsible for
>>>how commercialized and "structured" the whole DJ thing at BM has turned
>>>into.
>>
>> not particularly - but you are welcome to interpret it that way - my
>> perspective was I was introduced to Oakey at the Filmore in early 2000 -
>> based on a handshake, and nothing else he showed up and played a set
>> that a lot of people liked on one of the worst nights weather-wise
>> I've ever experienced on the playa - like it or not, his presence
>> allowed for a lot of DJs who probably never would have otherwise
>> gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our
>> way to be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
>> commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers
>> to - in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
>> the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting
>> form
>>
>>
>>>Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ
>>>lineup" driven BM format is what cheapens it.
>>
>> At over $200 a ticket, there is nothing 'cheap' about BM these days -
>> the first time I went it cost $15.
>>
>>
>>>Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to
>>>how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads
>>>out there are starting to get to the point where having big names
>>>and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for everything is
>>>getting kind of tired.
>>
>> I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did
>> NOT like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
>> one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the
>> word and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
>> we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave
>> lotsa new people a shot
>>
>>
>>>And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing
>>>"banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did
>>>for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as
>>>I can remember.
>>
>> in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter
>> how many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say
>> so -
>> what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and
>> the DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
>> DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an
>> evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen
>> dancing
>>
>>
>>>His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of
>>>that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on
>>>the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
>>
>> You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we
>> have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a
>> certain point -
>> the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point -
>> otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are
>> talking about -
>> a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ
>> who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will
>> always
>> win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it
>> is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his
>> ears -
>> he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening
>> and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse
>> that -
>> you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG
>> chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>

> > gotten the attention to play for a large crowd - we went out of our
> > way to be inclusive, not exclusive, and we have NEVER used our name for
> > commercial purposes - though we have received MANY lucrative offers
> > to - in fact, we so dislike how structured things have become on
> > the playa that we may return in some new and hopefully more interesting
> > form
> >
> >
> >>Funny, lots of folks I have spoken to think that the whole "DJ
> >>lineup" driven BM format is what cheapens it.
> >
> > At over $200 a ticket, there is nothing 'cheap' about BM these days -
> > the first time I went it cost $15.
> >
> >
> >>Of course I have yet to go, so I have no frame of reference as to
> >>how it was, as opposed to how it is - but I think the true EDM heads
> >>out there are starting to get to the point where having big names
> >>and "headliners" all over the place as the draw for everything is
> >>getting kind of tired.
> >
> > I could agree with that - fyi, a lot of people in our collective did
> > NOT like the idea of a name DJ on our system - so, we never invited
> > one to play with us in either 2001 or 2002 - instead, we put out the
> > word and got over 300 audition tapes from all over the world -
> > we never kept 'our' system for ourselves, or for 'our' djs - we gave
> > lotsa new people a shot
> >
> >
> >>And let me add further, Paul Oakenfold doesn't ever playing
> >>"banging" sets. He's an awful fucking DJ, and despite what he did
> >>for EDM back in the day, he sucks major ass, and has for as long as
> >>I can remember.
> >
> > in my never humble opinion - no DJ delivers a banging set - no matter
> > how many trainspotters standing with their arms folded and scowling say
> > so -
> > what makes for a banging set - is the INTERACTION between the DJ and
> > the DANCERS - trainwrecks do NOT trainwreck a set or an evening -
> > DJs who are more focused on technique and being cool trainwreck an
> > evening - personally, I never trust (or hire) a DJ who I've never seen
> > dancing
> >
> >
> >>His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of
> >>that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on
> >>the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
> >
> > You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we
> > have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a
> > certain point -
> > the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point -
> > otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are
> > talking about -
> > a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ
> > who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment will
> > always
> > win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but it
> > is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with his
> > ears -
> > he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is happening
> > and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you can't rehearse
> > that -
> > you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG
> > chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > *bliss does not require ignorance*

> > Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around

Under Socialism you would not be allowed to be poor. You would be
forcibly fed, clothed, lodged, taught, and employed whether you liked
it or not. If it were discovered that you had not the character and
industry enough to be worth all this trouble, you might possibly be
executed in a kindly manner. . . .


- George Bernard Shaw, Intelligent Woman's Guide to Socialism and
Capitalism, 1928.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

How was that?  Fred Everything is one of my favorite house producers/remixers, but I've never seen him DJ...

As far as life in the USSR, my introduction was http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_Day_in_the_Life_of_Ivan_Denisovich

There are lots of good books out there if you are interested in delving deeper.

You might also read this: http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_n15_v41/ai_7850511

"Metaphysically, the whole trip was fascinating: physically less so. Readers will have come across many accounts of the ordinary horrors of a Soviet visit, such as the dusty emptiness of shops. Even the hard-currency Beriozkas, which most Russians can only dream of entering, are like combinations of a small, obsolete, ill-stocked supermarket and a souvenir shop in Atlantic City. As to purchases in rubles, GUM, the huge general store on Red Square, might be characterized as a place where in purgatory those Westerners who have shopped excessively in life are doomed to spend a million years. And Moscow is privileged: of a central food store in Vladimir, in the provinces, I would rather not speak.

But why? Why does Leningrad water contain intestinal parasites? Why is sugar rationed? Why can't soap-or even toothbrushes-be bought in Moscow? Why did our hotel, the seventh or eighth best in the city, display such squalor in the rooming, the feeding, the ventilation? And why, incidentally, do decent Russians have to be met at the front door, while tarts and pimps enter freely? And if they do, why can't the pimps be required at least to look respectable-many would have been thrown out as excessively louche from a bar in the Marseille docks. The whores are more presentable-and can earn in half an hour the equivalent of two months' pay for a doctor. (There seem to be more pimps than tarts: a Russian explained that this was on the Soviet principle, 'Two administrators for every worker.')"

Regards,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Thursday, November 8, 2007 4:43:24 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

> i miss bianca's too - but between the Nevada food authorities getting 
> on their case over the free grilled cheese sandwiches and the increasing > presence of what could only charitably described as 'dirty old men' i guess there > day was over - but the people are still around.

for sure. i was involved with bianca's in their final years and while there was undoubtedly a dirty old man factor involved, there were internal problems as well. i was sad to have only caught that group on the downswing, but i'm happy to have been included at all. there were some fantastic people in that collective, and some of them definitely are still around, but obviously it's different... just like the illuminaughty camp in all its glory is different than a few scattered folks decorating the cafe and assisting some newer sound crews. 

i can't blame any camp for burning out or wanting to try something new. everything changes i suppose, and if i've learned anything from burning man it's to embrace impermanence. it's interesting to note that sound camps have always faced an uphill battle out there - i guess if it were easy, none of us would bother doing it. thanks for posting such a great history of our people :)

love,
mo


Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote: At 04:20 PM 11/8/2007, mo corleone wrote:
>leave it to sfraves to turn a discussion about the history of 
>electronic music at burning man into a flame-fest about paul oakenfold.

it IS our regularly scheduled programming


>i don't know exactly how illuminaughty fits in to the overall 
>picture, but i do remember the camp fondly... minus oakenfold and 
>peretz of course ;) so congratulations on a job well done, and if i 
>make it out to the desert again i look forward to the next 
>progression of your efforts.

oh, we're there every year - just doing different things - several of 
our major people decorated Center Camp this year -
some of us were Barbarella Boot Camp the last few years - many of us 
have a quiet camp called Oacious that has
been on the playa every year since '99 - a lot of our peeps were 
involved with Coda this year


>ps: i miss bianca's.


i miss bianca's too - but between the Nevada food authorities getting 
on their case
over the free grilled cheese sandwiches and the increasing presence 
of what could
only charitably described as 'dirty old men' i guess there day was 
over - but the
people are still around

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

I've only seen Oakenfold once at Ultra in Miami 2001 and well he was at this one point holding a glass of champagne (Dom Perignon in fact) in one hand and waving it around over his head.  The champage was splashing out of glass onto the records and turntables.  He wasn't even touching the mixer.  It was a spectacle of the worst sort.

Tho I guess this random arm waving could qualify as a DJ dancing...

Regards,

Peter

PS Oakenfold has very hairy arm pits.

PPS I have that GU CD too and I seem to recall that there were actually a few tracks on there that I liked at the time.  I don't remember the mixing glitch that Marco is talking about tho.  I might have to track down that CD and listen for it.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

I disagree. I loved the statement, so much I quoted it elsewhere. A bit out of context though as I don't really agree that it pertains to DJs like Paul Oakenfold, but I do somewhat agree. In my experiences, i've seen this kind of 'non-mixing' on purpose.. Most I've seen at sick Wicked parties in the day... Francois Kervorkian and DJ Harvey come to mind instantly. I was a bit thrown off by the lack of mixing until I realized what it was doing to the dancefloor and that it was VERY on purpose. Dancefloors like the Paradise Garage never had Larry Levan spinning perfect mixes, but had sick vibe.. Shit was off the cuff, experimentation and crowd connection at the forefront. Not that the perfectionists can't get crowd connection, cuz that's a crock too, I'm just agreeing that sick dancefloor vibe doesn't always require perfect mixing.

Flame on.

-JH

----- Original Message ----
From: Chris Jackson <cjax@sbcglobal.net>
To: Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com>
Cc: Marco Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; SFR Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, November 9, 2007 9:37:57 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

>
>
>> His Global Underground "New York" CD is a perfect example of  
>> that...the mixing is frickin' terrible and there's even a wreck on  
>> the mix. A PROFESSIONAL FUCKING MIX. Pathetic.
>
> You're dissing one of my all-time favorite discs - but I guess we  
> have different criteria - music can only be about technique to a  
> certain point -
> the heart, the spirit of the thing has to take over at some point -  
> otherwise it gets stuck in the head, and this IS dance music we are  
> talking about -
> a DJ lost in his own ego is never gonna connect with a crowd - a DJ  
> who has no problem with fucking up and being real with the moment  
> will always
> win over a crowd - I know this pisses the perfectionists off - but  
> it is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with  
> his ears -
> he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is  
> happening and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you  
> can't rehearse that -
> you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG  
> chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .
>
>


Hey bud, you're talking about Paul Oakenfold here.  Are you fucking  
kidding me??  Can you even possibly be saying that Oakie is not  
caught up in his own ego??  Being "real"  Hahaha.  Uh-huh...yup.  He  
has his picture in Websters next to the word "ego".  The above  
statement is one of the most asinine things I have read in quite a  
while.  Thanks for the entertainment.

c h r i s

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

has anyone notice how much detail Marco seems to know about Oakenfold?

fanboy, for sure.

in other news...i've seen Oakenfold several times.  at the Fillmore in
2000, Cyberfest 2000 in Fresno, Once in a Blue Moon at the Cow Palace
in 2001 (?), and most recently...he opened for Underworld a few months
ago at the Warfield.

at the Fillmore, i liked the opener's set better.  i think it was Mark
Grant.  at Cyberfest....BT went on before Oakie and totally rocked.
Okie went on and i left the room to go see Carl Cox.

at the Cow Palace, Okie follwed Chemical Brothers...who rocked with
some sick visuals to boot.  Sasha and Digweed were playing in the side
room on their Delta Heavy tour.  i really, really enjoyed their set
that night.  3+ hours and awesome progression.  when he opened for
Underworld...it was absolutely terrible.  trance at 8pm to a crowd who
isn't having it.  he looked bored, uninterested, and some of his mixes
were just straight terrible.  he ended with a horribly cheesy remix of
Laid Back's "White Horse."

BUT

i will give his Tranceport CD a lot of credit for getting me into
electronic music in SF, clubbing and raving.  i listened to that mix
several times per week for several months back in 99.

PS.  i recently started listening to old trance and i realised that
there is still something about it that i really really enjoy.  i own
quite a bit and have been mixing it at home for fun.  it brought back
some very fond memories.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <645221.39286.qm@web32411.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

As an amateur that doesn't always get all my mixes right I take some solace in this notion.  

On the other hand, since I started mixing myself, I also notice many other people's mistakes that probably I would never have noticed previously.  Today, for me a lot of the measure of a DJ is not that they never muff a mix, but how they handle it when they do.  There are easy saves and more subtle saves.  Some saves are jarring and kill the groove if you are dancing, but I've heard others that seem to have the opposite effect actually pumping the dance floor.  I saw Francois K do this at a party in NYC actually.  I wonder if it was on purpose now that you mention it.

Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies.  Not to mention the case where you are actually playing a prerecorded studio mix and only pretending to play live while spilling expensive champagne on your records.

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

Marco secretly collects Oakenfolds pit hairs?

----- Original Message ----
From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, November 9, 2007 12:34:43 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

has anyone notice how much detail Marco seems to know about Oakenfold?

fanboy, for sure.

in other news...i've seen Oakenfold several times.  at the Fillmore in
2000, Cyberfest 2000 in Fresno, Once in a Blue Moon at the Cow Palace
in 2001 (?), and most recently...he opened for Underworld a few months
ago at the Warfield.

at the Fillmore, i liked the opener's set better.  i think it was Mark
Grant.  at Cyberfest....BT went on before Oakie and totally rocked.
Okie went on and i left the room to go see Carl Cox.

at the Cow Palace, Okie follwed Chemical Brothers...who rocked with
some sick visuals to boot.  Sasha and Digweed were playing in the side
room on their Delta Heavy tour.  i really, really enjoyed their set
that night.  3+ hours and awesome progression.  when he opened for
Underworld...it was absolutely terrible.  trance at 8pm to a crowd who
isn't having it.  he looked bored, uninterested, and some of his mixes
were just straight terrible.  he ended with a horribly cheesy remix of
Laid Back's "White Horse."

BUT

i will give his Tranceport CD a lot of credit for getting me into
electronic music in SF, clubbing and raving.  i listened to that mix
several times per week for several months back in 99.

PS.  i recently started listening to old trance and i realised that
there is still something about it that i really really enjoy.  i own
quite a bit and have been mixing it at home for fun.  it brought back
some very fond memories.

> > ago at the Warfield.
> >
> > at the Fillmore, i liked the opener's set better.  i think it was Mark
> > Grant.  at Cyberfest....BT went on before Oakie and totally rocked.
> > Okie went on and i left the room to go see Carl Cox.
> >
> > at the Cow Palace, Okie follwed Chemical Brothers...who rocked with
> > some sick visuals to boot.  Sasha and Digweed were playing in the side
> > room on their Delta Heavy tour.  i really, really enjoyed their set
> > that night.  3+ hours and awesome progression.  when he opened for
> > Underworld...it was absolutely terrible.  trance at 8pm to a crowd who
> > isn't having it.  he looked bored, uninterested, and some of his mixes
> > were just straight terrible.  he ended with a horribly cheesy remix of
> > Laid Back's "White Horse."
> >
> > BUT
> >
> > i will give his Tranceport CD a lot of credit for getting me into
> > electronic music in SF, clubbing and raving.  i listened to that mix
> > several times per week for several months back in 99.
> >
> > PS.  i recently started listening to old trance and i realised that
> > there is still something about it that i really really enjoy.  i own
> > quite a bit and have been mixing it at home for fun.  it brought back

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

--0-643161239-1194650256=:38503
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

"Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."

i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few i'm going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you either. some of the technology out there might include some rough assistance for matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the beatmatch indicators on a lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at all because 1) they are grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) that's boring ;)

i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working any less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3 programs simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the mechanics of mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting some new standard of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of playing standard 12" vinyl releases. 

and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that too :D

love,
mo

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: As an amateur that doesn't always get all my mixes right I take some solace in this notion.  

On the other hand, since I started mixing myself, I also notice many other people's mistakes that probably I would never have noticed previously.  Today, for me a lot of the measure of a DJ is not that they never muff a mix, but how they handle it when they do.  There are easy saves and more subtle saves.  Some saves are jarring and kill the groove if you are dancing, but I've heard others that seem to have the opposite effect actually pumping the dance floor.  I saw Francois K do this at a party in NYC actually.  I wonder if it was on purpose now that you mention it.

Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies.  Not to mention the case where you are actually playing a prerecorded studio mix and only pretending to play live while spilling expensive champagne on your records.

Peter

>I disagree. I loved the statement, so much I quoted it elsewhere. A bit out 
>of context though as I don't really agree that it pertains to DJs like Paul 
>Oakenfold, but I do somewhat agree. In my experiences, i've seen this kind 
>of 'non-mixing' on purpose.. Most I've seen at sick Wicked parties in the 
>day... Francois Kervorkian and DJ Harvey come to mind instantly. I was a 
>bit thrown off by the lack of mixing until I realized what it was doing to 
>the dancefloor and that it was VERY on purpose. Dancefloors like the 
>Paradise Garage never had Larry Levan spinning perfect mixes, but had sick 
>vibe.. Shit was off the cuff, experimentation and crowd connection at the 
>forefront. Not that the perfectionists can't get crowd connection, cuz 
>that's a crock too, I'm just agreeing that sick dancefloor vibe doesn't 
>always require perfect mixing.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

Well put Mo.

I play primarily CDJ's and Serato now - and I can promise you, it's just as 
much work as mixing wax. The only "easier" part of mixing on (most) cdj's, 
is the fact that they have more precise adjustments, meaning, it's easier to 
fix slips in beatmatching, etc. - but only once you get the hang of 
switching from wax to CDJ in the 1st place.

There's a learning curve like any other medium for the craft.

And re: all the trance Bam & Mo just mentioned. I have CRATES of that 
stuff - and will gladly be the douchebag that plays it at a party one night 
(or morning preferrably) if someone wants to book me to do so.

Yes it's a guilty secret, and no I don't care if you know it.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "mo corleone" <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, November 09, 2007 3:17 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man


> "Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really 
> no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."
>
> i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that 
> mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't 
> beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi 
> controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few i'm 
> going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you either. 
> some of the technology out there might include some rough assistance for 
> matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the beatmatch indicators on a 
> lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at all because 1) they are 
> grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) that's boring ;)
>
> i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working any 
> less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3 programs 
> simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the mechanics of 
> mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting some new standard 
> of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of playing standard 12" 
> vinyl releases.
>
> and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven 
> cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that too 
> :D
>
> love,
> mo
>
> dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: As an amateur that doesn't always get all my 
> mixes right I take some solace in this notion.
>
> On the other hand, since I started mixing myself, I also notice many other 
> people's mistakes that probably I would never have noticed previously. 
> Today, for me a lot of the measure of a DJ is not that they never muff a 
> mix, but how they handle it when they do.  There are easy saves and more 
> subtle saves.  Some saves are jarring and kill the groove if you are 
> dancing, but I've heard others that seem to have the opposite effect 
> actually pumping the dance floor.  I saw Francois K do this at a party in 
> NYC actually.  I wonder if it was on purpose now that you mention it.
>
> Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really 
> no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies.  Not to mention the 
> case where you are actually playing a prerecorded studio mix and only 
> pretending to play live while spilling expensive champagne on your 
> records.
>
> Peter

>>> it is true.  A DJ has to spin with his eyes as much as he does with
>>> his ears -
>>> he has to be able to look at his dancefloor and see what is
>>> happening and react in the moment - you can't pre-plan that - you
>>> can't rehearse that -
>>> you just have to connect - and sometimes that means taking BIG
>>> chances - they don't always work out, but when they do . . .
>>>
>>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

--0-742019677-1194653194=:58223
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I have to admit I'm no expert on the CD DJ front, and I recognize it doesn't mix for you, but I do think CD DJing makes certain things much easier.  I understand about the beat counters (I purposely didn't buy a mixer that had them for the reasons you stated) but CDJ set ups do make certain effects much easier to produce.  For example, on the Pioneer CDJ-1000s you can return to a cue point simply by pressing the jog wheel.  You can only store 3 cue points I think, but still pushing the wheel is a much easier skill to master than spinning back a record to just the right spot.  IMO anyhow.  You can also create 1-8 beat loops and trigger these with the press of a button.   Again, IMO relatively much easier than creating the same effect using standard vinyl and turntables.
 
With regards to MP3 mixing, I've never used Serato, but for the true laptop DJ there certainly are programs that do automatic beat matching.  These are not perfect of course, but in my experience they do a decent job, and you literally can play an entire set without having to beat match at all.  I agree its boring and I don't use any of this stuff myself when I play.  
 
However, I tried a Visiosonic PC DJ set up hands on at WMC 2001 and it definitely does beat match for you if you want it to.  The resulting mixes might not be innovative or unique, but it works well enough for the average bar DJ at least.  I was pretty drunk and fried at the time (WMC!), and I still could mix just fine. This has some appeal to me ;)  
 
Also, even if you don't use automatic beat matching, you can visually cue up tracks using the waveform display.  You can see right where a beat starts using this and set the cue point on that exact sample.  As an amateur I personally find this much easier than matching by ear and dropping the record right on the beat by hand, but maybe its because I am so used to computer interfaces and still a duffer when it comes to mixing.  
 
You really can't and shouldn't ever train wreck using this sort of laptop DJ tech.  It would actually be hard to do I think.  Maybe if you get really drunk, turn off the auto beat matching, and then spill your drink on the laptop...
 
See http://pcdj.com/products/dj-software/reflex
 
Hey, also, hope to meet you at the 8yr tomorrow.  My friend Mark and I will be there...
 
Peace,
 
Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
Sent: Friday, November 9, 2007 3:15:07 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

"Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter. There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."

i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few i'm going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you either. some of the technology out there might include some rough assistance for matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the beatmatch indicators on a lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at all because 1) they are grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) that's boring ;)

i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working any less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3 programs simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the mechanics of mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting some new standard of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of playing standard 12" vinyl releases. 

and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that too :D

love,
mo

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: 
As an amateur that doesn't always get all my mixes right I take some solace in this notion. 

On the other hand, since I started mixing myself, I also notice many other people's mistakes that probably I would never have noticed previously. Today, for me a lot of the measure of a DJ is not that they never muff a mix, but how they handle it when they do. There are easy saves and more subtle saves. Some saves are jarring and kill the groove if you are dancing, but I've heard others that seem to have the opposite effect actually pumping the dance floor. I saw Francois K do this at a party in NYC actually. I wonder if it was on purpose now that you mention it.

Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter. There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies. Not to mention the case where you are actually playing a prerecorded studio mix and only pretending to play live while spilling expensive champagne on your records.

Peter

Except for that nice added visual of the waveform from each channel 
moving along their right on your screen.  So if the waveforms line up 
perfectly, you're beatmatched.  If not, you're off.  Compared to having 
to have an ear to hear this, I'd say this takes away 85% of that effort.

And I believe that there ARE programs that have auto beatmatching and 
timestretching for you.

> programs simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the

> some new standard of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of

release only)

7. Junk Project - Composure - Universal Prime Breaks
8. Funkopath - Skwirm - 21-3 Records
9. Energy 52 - Cafe Del Mar (Hybrid mix) - Hooj
10. Gus-Gus - Believe - 4AD
11. Furry Phreaks - Soothe (Chicane & 16B mixes) - FSUK
12. Prana - Geomantik - Matsuri
13. Fluke - Reeferendum - Circa
14. Lost Tribe - Angel - Hooj
15. Spooky - Little Bullet (Pt.1) - Guerilla

And I am sure I could add way more, but those are the ones that come to =

> 3. Tekara - Breathe In You - 3Beat
> 4. Fade - No Resolve (NuTribe mix) - Phattraxx (ltd. edition promo  
> release only)
> 5. Greece 2000 - Three Drives on a Vinyl (Farmatronic mix) - Hooj
> 6. Cyclone Tracy - Balla Con II Ritmo - Go For It
> 7. Junk Project - Composure - Universal Prime Breaks
> 8. Funkopath - Skwirm - 21-3 Records
> 9. Energy 52 - Cafe Del Mar (Hybrid mix) - Hooj
> 10. Gus-Gus - Believe - 4AD
> 11. Furry Phreaks - Soothe (Chicane & 16B mixes) - FSUK
> 12. Prana - Geomantik - Matsuri
> 13. Fluke - Reeferendum - Circa
> 14. Lost Tribe - Angel - Hooj
> 15. Spooky - Little Bullet (Pt.1) - Guerilla
>
> And I am sure I could add way more, but those are the ones that  
> come to mind immediately....
