Ableton could POTENTIALLY mix for you, but most people use midi controllers 
to mix w/ it and it's quite like using Serato or something similar.

As far as the auto-cues w/ CDJ's - I have yet to enjoy cueing w/ a button - 
so I use "vinyl mode", which cues (dun dun dunnnn) JUST LIKE VINYL!!!


----- Original Message ----- 
From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, November 09, 2007 4:06 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man


>I have to admit I'm no expert on the CD DJ front, and I recognize it 
>doesn't mix for you, but I do think CD DJing makes certain things much 
>easier.  I understand about the beat counters (I purposely didn't buy a 
>mixer that had them for the reasons you stated) but CDJ set ups do make 
>certain effects much easier to produce.  For example, on the Pioneer 
>CDJ-1000s you can return to a cue point simply by pressing the jog wheel. 
>You can only store 3 cue points I think, but still pushing the wheel is a 
>much easier skill to master than spinning back a record to just the right 
>spot.  IMO anyhow.  You can also create 1-8 beat loops and trigger these 
>with the press of a button.   Again, IMO relatively much easier than 
>creating the same effect using standard vinyl and turntables.
>
> With regards to MP3 mixing, I've never used Serato, but for the true 
> laptop DJ there certainly are programs that do automatic beat matching. 
> These are not perfect of course, but in my experience they do a decent 
> job, and you literally can play an entire set without having to beat match 
> at all.  I agree its boring and I don't use any of this stuff myself when 
> I play.
>
> However, I tried a Visiosonic PC DJ set up hands on at WMC 2001 and it 
> definitely does beat match for you if you want it to.  The resulting mixes 
> might not be innovative or unique, but it works well enough for the 
> average bar DJ at least.  I was pretty drunk and fried at the time (WMC!), 
> and I still could mix just fine. This has some appeal to me ;)
>
> Also, even if you don't use automatic beat matching, you can visually cue 
> up tracks using the waveform display.  You can see right where a beat 
> starts using this and set the cue point on that exact sample.  As an 
> amateur I personally find this much easier than matching by ear and 
> dropping the record right on the beat by hand, but maybe its because I am 
> so used to computer interfaces and still a duffer when it comes to mixing.
>
> You really can't and shouldn't ever train wreck using this sort of laptop 
> DJ tech.  It would actually be hard to do I think.  Maybe if you get 
> really drunk, turn off the auto beat matching, and then spill your drink 
> on the laptop...
>
> See http://pcdj.com/products/dj-software/reflex
>
> Hey, also, hope to meet you at the 8yr tomorrow.  My friend Mark and I 
> will be there...
>
> Peace,
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>
> To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> Sent: Friday, November 9, 2007 3:15:07 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man
>
> "Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter. There's really 
> no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."
>
> i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that 
> mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't 
> beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi 
> controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few i'm 
> going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you either. 
> some of the technology out there might include some rough assistance for 
> matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the beatmatch indicators on a 
> lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at all because 1) they are 
> grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) that's boring ;)
>
> i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working any 
> less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3 programs 
> simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the mechanics of 
> mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting some new standard 
> of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of playing standard 12" 
> vinyl releases.
>
> and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven 
> cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that too 
> :D
>
> love,
> mo
>
> dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> As an amateur that doesn't always get all my mixes right I take some 
> solace in this notion.
>
> On the other hand, since I started mixing myself, I also notice many other 
> people's mistakes that probably I would never have noticed previously. 
> Today, for me a lot of the measure of a DJ is not that they never muff a 
> mix, but how they handle it when they do. There are easy saves and more 
> subtle saves. Some saves are jarring and kill the groove if you are 
> dancing, but I've heard others that seem to have the opposite effect 
> actually pumping the dance floor. I saw Francois K do this at a party in 
> NYC actually. I wonder if it was on purpose now that you mention it.
>
> Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter. There's really 
> no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies. Not to mention the 
> case where you are actually playing a prerecorded studio mix and only 
> pretending to play live while spilling expensive champagne on your 
> records.
>
> Peter
>

PS Regarding Halcyon by Orbital, I love that track!  

There is a place just south of Pismo Beach where there is a Halcyon Road which crosses Hwy 101.  http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&time=&date=&ttype=&q=N+Halcyon+Road+Arroyo+Grande,+CA,+USA&sll=35.121909,-120.584521&sspn=0.011794,0.022402&ie=UTF8&ll=35.12384,-120.586839&spn=0.011794,0.022402&z=15&iwloc=addr&om=1

I used to do a lot of driving between Santa Cruz and Santa Barbara and I would load up the brown album so that the track Halcyon would start right when I got to that road.  

Why?  I don't know...

Peace,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, November 9, 2007 4:13:11 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

On 9 November 2007, mo corleone wrote:

> "Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."
>
> i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that

[see below for my response about this "misconception"]

> mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't 
> beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi
> controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few 
> i'm going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you 
> either. some of the technology out there might include some rough 
> assistance for matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the 
> beatmatch indicators on a lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at 
> all because 1) they are grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) 
> that's boring ;)
>
> i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working 
> any less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3

Except for that nice added visual of the waveform from each channel 
moving along their right on your screen.  So if the waveforms line up 
perfectly, you're beatmatched.  If not, you're off.  Compared to having 
to have an ear to hear this, I'd say this takes away 85% of that effort.

And I believe that there ARE programs that have auto beatmatching and 
timestretching for you.

> programs simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the 
> mechanics of mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting 
> some new standard of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of 
> playing standard 12" vinyl releases.

It's already here.

>
> and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven 
> cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that 
> too :D

So do I.  Had intended to break some of the old stuff out and throw down 
an old nostalgic mix, but haven't made that happen yet.  Soon enough!

>
> love,
> mo
>

http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php

X-YMail-OSG: 2eInHYYVM1k.Pz6XZTindjCtEP3tfXKhXBmxnDZNky8nuB2qAkdWVqV9hb3AYgkmu7Hjl6W0rZWEsgwhRzFDmZYc0T7K_ankOen6kRniZg.E7mtoMg7al1ZE_1rL
Date: Fri, 9 Nov 2007 16:33:18 -0800 (PST)
From: mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com>

In-Reply-To: <20071109160849.G20251@kzsu.stanford.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <629288.52588.qm@web51509.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

--0-81307349-1194654798=:52588
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

yeah, i'm aware of the waveforms on most programs, and again i think they are about as helpful as the beatmatch lights or bpm counters on most mixers. and even if they worked well, they don't give you a magic hand that can make the proper adjustments. you still have to learn how to make the corrections yourself.

i guess it all comes down to how lazy you want to be. i suppose the technology is out there if you really want something to do all the work for you, but i don't think most people who play on CD-Js or serato/final scratch/etc. are going that route. maybe since i started out playing regular vinyl, i still spin like i'm playing regular vinyl - i.e. i'm paying attention to what i'm hearing in my headphones rather than staring at a display on a laptop. 

either way, it sounds like we need to put together a memory lane trance party :)

love,
mo

"J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote: On 9 November 2007, mo corleone wrote:

> "Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."
>
> i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that

[see below for my response about this "misconception"]

> mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't 
> beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi
> controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few 
> i'm going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you 
> either. some of the technology out there might include some rough 
> assistance for matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the 
> beatmatch indicators on a lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at 
> all because 1) they are grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) 
> that's boring ;)
>
> i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working 
> any less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3

Except for that nice added visual of the waveform from each channel 
moving along their right on your screen.  So if the waveforms line up 
perfectly, you're beatmatched.  If not, you're off.  Compared to having 
to have an ear to hear this, I'd say this takes away 85% of that effort.

And I believe that there ARE programs that have auto beatmatching and 
timestretching for you.

> programs simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the 
> mechanics of mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting 
> some new standard of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of 
> playing standard 12" vinyl releases.

It's already here.

>
> and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven 
> cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that 
> too :D

So do I.  Had intended to break some of the old stuff out and throw down 
an old nostalgic mix, but haven't made that happen yet.  Soon enough!

>
> love,
> mo
>

Subject: [sfraves] Trance Mix Battle

so as i mentioned before, i recently started playing my old (secret)
stash of trance at home. i joked with some friends online that i still
like trance...which is true because of the nostalgia.

i even went to far as to record myself and shared the cheesy mix with
a few friends.

i hereby challenge you, SFR DJs, to record an hour long trance mix for
Trance Battle 2007!  extra points for cheese, rare remixes, and "hands
in the air OMG tingles down the back of my neck someone give me a
blowpop" factor.

who is in?

i want to record another one for the hell of it.

Shameful.

As long as we're embarrassing ourselves, though, here's my favorite
trance tunes:

1) Energy 52 - Cafe Del Mar (DJ Kid Paul Mix)
2) Lost Tribe - Gamemaster, perhaps the gayest track ever made
3) Three Drives on a Vinyl - Greece 2000 (Original Mix, not the half
ass breaks version)
4) Clockx - Clocks
5) Tilt - Invisible
6) Paul Van Dyk - Words
7) Quake - In & Out of My Life
8) Erasure - Freedom
9) Underworld - Cowgirl
10) Salt Pervert - 5am Soho (all right, so it's progressive house,
close enough. . .)

Out gay that, Marco.

:-)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

Word, if you play with serato and you keep the screen turned away from
you, it's actually a bit harder than playing vinyl because there's no
grooves to read, all you have to go on is the sound. I love playing
shit that way, keeps you on your toes.

On Nov 9, 2007 3:17 PM, mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com> wrote:
> "Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies."
>
> i think this is a common misconception. i haven't yet seen a CD-J that mixes for you, and mp3 mixing programs like serato certainly don't beatmatch for you either. i have friends that play mp3s out with midi controllers and software setups, and since i've heard them wreck a few i'm going to venture a guess and say those programs don't mix for you either. some of the technology out there might include some rough assistance for matching beats, but it's about as helpful as the beatmatch indicators on a lot of mixers... which nobody i know uses at all because 1) they are grossly inaccurate most of the time, and 2) that's boring ;)
>
> i don't play CDs, but i don't think people who do it well are working any less hard than i am when i'm spinning vinyl. the most common mp3 programs simply allow you to assign mp3s to either CD or vinyl - the mechanics of mixing are otherwise the same. i wouldn't go expecting some new standard of perfection just because a DJ has opted out of playing standard 12" vinyl releases.
>
> and bam... if by old trance you mean stuff like greece 2000 or seven cities or anything with 'halcyon' in the title, then yeah, i like that too :D
>
> love,
> mo
>
> dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: As an amateur that doesn't always get all my mixes right I take some solace in this notion.
>
> On the other hand, since I started mixing myself, I also notice many other people's mistakes that probably I would never have noticed previously.  Today, for me a lot of the measure of a DJ is not that they never muff a mix, but how they handle it when they do.  There are easy saves and more subtle saves.  Some saves are jarring and kill the groove if you are dancing, but I've heard others that seem to have the opposite effect actually pumping the dance floor.  I saw Francois K do this at a party in NYC actually.  I wonder if it was on purpose now that you mention it.
>
> Of course with MP3 and CD DJing it is a different matter.  There's really no excuse for blowing a mix with those technologies.  Not to mention the case where you are actually playing a prerecorded studio mix and only pretending to play live while spilling expensive champagne on your records.
>
> Peter
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man

--0-250627661-1194684587=:4678
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Francois K doesn't beatmatch his mixes because he doesn't like the idea
of a dj's set keeping a constant tempo. He believes that variation in tempo from one track to another when done correctly can work a dance floor in a way that a beatmatched set with a constant tempo never could. He also believes that the very nature of beatmatching every track and keeping a constant tempo makes a set boring. You can ask
him about it over at his forum at http://www.wavemusic.com/community/forumdisplay.php?f=9  and he will tell you all about it. Thats a great forum for all kinds of info on people like Francois K, Larry Levan, Frankie Nuckles, Tony Humphries, as well as the clubs from that era such as The Paradise Garage, Zanzibar etc. Also lots of great info on the greatest club sound system designer of all times Richard Long of RLA, the man behind the sound systems in most of the great clubs of that era.

Another thing to keep in mind when talking about old school dj's like Larry Levan and the way they mixed (or didn't mix) at clubs like the Paradise Garage is the equipment they were using. The Garage as well as Zanzibar and even Studio 54 all had systems installed by Richard Long and Richard did not install Technics 1200 tables in the booths. Instead he installed what was industry standard BEFORE the tech 1200's... the belt drive Thorens TD 125's. These decks didn't have any pitch control. Unreleased or pre release stuff was played on reel to reel tape machines which obviously don't have pitch controls either. Its gonna be a little hard to perfectly beatmatch a set when you have no pitch controls on your sources.
 
Dowload my latest mixes here:
www.musicv2.com/artist/dj_kevin_james
New mix added 10/28/07 
Watch me spin live Sunday evenings here:
http://www.stickam.com/profile/djkevinjames
 
Baba Booey!!!

----- Original Message ----
From: John Fowler <djjustinhale@yahoo.com>
To: SFR Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, November 9, 2007 11:01:26 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Begoggled in the Mega-Vibe: Burning Man


I disagree. I loved the statement, so much I quoted it elsewhere. A bit
 out of context though as I don't really agree that it pertains to DJs
 like Paul Oakenfold, but I do somewhat agree. In my experiences, i've
 seen this kind of 'non-mixing' on purpose.. Most I've seen at sick
 Wicked parties in the day... Francois Kervorkian and DJ Harvey come to mind
 instantly. I was a bit thrown off by the lack of mixing until I
 realized what it was doing to the dancefloor and that it was VERY on purpose.
 Dancefloors like the Paradise Garage never had Larry Levan spinning
 perfect mixes, but had sick vibe.. Shit was off the cuff, experimentation
 and crowd connection at the forefront. Not that the perfectionists
 can't get crowd connection, cuz that's a crock too, I'm just agreeing that
 sick dancefloor vibe doesn't always require perfect mixing.

Flame on.

-JH

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: electrofunk138@hotmail.com, Nathan Seven <n7@nathanseven.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <414322.54113.qm@web32413.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Ambient Mafia Roll Call

I agree.  The venue was pristine.  Great location.  The "main" room under the loft was cool and intimate.  Early in the evening they had these fabric curtains lowered so that the room didn't feel too empty.  As more people showed up, they raised these opening the space up.  And the loft and fabric curtains kept the room from having that to harsh giant empty wherehouse sound.  Also a large fabric curtain along one wall helped keep the sound from echoing.  

The chill room was really small, and (of course) comfy bean bags.  I enjoyed the Alice in Wonderland posters...I parked nearby and the security made me feel my car was safe.  Maybe that was an illusion, but this plac efelt pretty secure.  This is a really nice venue, and I hope to return soon.

Just the right number of people and a pretty wide variety of people too.  A great promotion job by the Ambient Mafia brought in a full house of heads, groovers, and a few assorted weirdos.There were a lot of younger people, but I certainly was not the only geriatric nor the oldest person there.  Everyone I talked to was cool and interesting, and I didn't see a single instance of anyone showing disrespect for the space or each other.  Great vibe.  I also liked the BYOB bar service.

Great music.  Loved everything I heard and even heard a few rare items from my own collection.  Styles ranged from atmospheric DnB to house to, well, other stuff.  

The projecttions and lasers were nice too.

The floor was jumping around 1-2 AM...I was grooving!

One interesting thing happened...earlier in the evening my partner thought the DJ was playing Nine in Nails, but I didn't think so.  We got in this conversation and was saying that my favorite NIN track was probably Head Like a Hole and maybe five minutes later the DJ dropped Head Like a Hole!  Interesting synchronicity!  Surprising track!  

Saw PXD, who said he was doing great!  Agent Smith, Marco, Osby, Redstikman,...am i forgetting anyone? 

Some girl from Chicago hit on me.

Overall:  Great night!  Great venue!  Great party!

Peace,

Peter

Received: (qmail 71679 invoked from network); 12 Nov 2007 06:09:02 -0000
Date: Sun, 11 Nov 2007 22:09:02 -0800 (PST)
From: Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org>
X-X-Sender: terry@taz3
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20071111203914.Y10606@taz3>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Ambient Mafia Review

WTF, Ambient Mafia invented a time machine last night. I had no 
idea I was going 88 miles per hour with a flux capacitor in the 
building.

Party started off great, and then suddenly I'm surrounded by 
Brian Behlendorf, Bryce, and Wayne Correia? (OG SFRavers). Us 
four haven't been in the same place, same time in *years*.

Tons of reminiscing, including Brian reminding me that Garth 
played at the *first* SFR party at Bonny Doon in '92.

Time machine continued: Steph Stiavetti, Martin Randall, 
Assorted Cloudfactory peeps, many more, crap it was just weird.

That aside, the overall crowd was fantastic, a nice eclectic 
blend of well-mannered (and freaky!) people.

Kevin the laser guy was super-cool, he brought 4 hand-built 
lasers. He really knows his stuff and we got to geek out on his 
gear for a while.

I had a few of the newer Viberation crew in tow, who started a 
fun breakdance circle, then later told me they felt 
self-conscience about it. I'm like, "Dude, look around you, 
stilt walkers and freaks of all kinds, you're supposed to 
express yourself!". This party was a huge eye-opener for them.

The Ambient Mafia crew is the shit. Not only a tight group of 
awesome people, to have downtempo opened-up and displayed 
center-stage like that was refreshing. The party was produced 
so well I felt spoiled ;-)

They rocked it, congrats :-)

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Ambient Mafia Review

fucking amazing night.  congratulations AM!

On Nov 11, 2007 10:09 PM, Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> WTF, Ambient Mafia invented a time machine last night. I had no
> idea I was going 88 miles per hour with a flux capacitor in the
> building.
>
> Party started off great, and then suddenly I'm surrounded by
> Brian Behlendorf, Bryce, and Wayne Correia? (OG SFRavers). Us
> four haven't been in the same place, same time in *years*.
>
> Tons of reminiscing, including Brian reminding me that Garth
> played at the *first* SFR party at Bonny Doon in '92.
>
> Time machine continued: Steph Stiavetti, Martin Randall,
> Assorted Cloudfactory peeps, many more, crap it was just weird.
>
> That aside, the overall crowd was fantastic, a nice eclectic
> blend of well-mannered (and freaky!) people.
>
> Kevin the laser guy was super-cool, he brought 4 hand-built
> lasers. He really knows his stuff and we got to geek out on his
> gear for a while.
>
> I had a few of the newer Viberation crew in tow, who started a
> fun breakdance circle, then later told me they felt
> self-conscience about it. I'm like, "Dude, look around you,
> stilt walkers and freaks of all kinds, you're supposed to
> express yourself!". This party was a huge eye-opener for them.
>
> The Ambient Mafia crew is the shit. Not only a tight group of
> awesome people, to have downtempo opened-up and displayed
> center-stage like that was refreshing. The party was produced
> so well I felt spoiled ;-)
>
> They rocked it, congrats :-)
>
> -terry
>
> ------------------------------------------
> terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

--- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> I agree.  The venue was pristine.  Great location. 
> The "main" room under the loft was cool and
> intimate.  Early in the evening they had these
> fabric curtains lowered so that the room didn't feel
> too empty.  As more people showed up, they raised
> these opening the space up.  And the loft and fabric
> curtains kept the room from having that to harsh
> giant empty wherehouse sound.  Also a large fabric
> curtain along one wall helped keep the sound from
> echoing.  
> 
> The chill room was really small, and (of course)
> comfy bean bags.  I enjoyed the Alice in Wonderland
> posters...I parked nearby and the security made me
> feel my car was safe.  Maybe that was an illusion,
> but this plac efelt pretty secure.  This is a really
> nice venue, and I hope to return soon.
> 
> Just the right number of people and a pretty wide
> variety of people too.  A great promotion job by the
> Ambient Mafia brought in a full house of heads,
> groovers, and a few assorted weirdos.There were a
> lot of younger people, but I certainly was not the
> only geriatric nor the oldest person there. 
> Everyone I talked to was cool and interesting, and I
> didn't see a single instance of anyone showing
> disrespect for the space or each other.  Great vibe.
>  I also liked the BYOB bar service.
> 
> Great music.  Loved everything I heard and even
> heard a few rare items from my own collection. 
> Styles ranged from atmospheric DnB to house to,
> well, other stuff.  
> 
> The projecttions and lasers were nice too.
> 
> The floor was jumping around 1-2 AM...I was
> grooving!
> 
> One interesting thing happened...earlier in the
> evening my partner thought the DJ was playing Nine
> in Nails, but I didn't think so.  We got in this
> conversation and was saying that my favorite NIN
> track was probably Head Like a Hole and maybe five
> minutes later the DJ dropped Head Like a Hole! 
> Interesting synchronicity!  Surprising track!  
> 
> Saw PXD, who said he was doing great!  Agent Smith,
> Marco, Osby, Redstikman,...am i forgetting anyone? 
> 
> Some girl from Chicago hit on me.
> 
> Overall:  Great night!  Great venue!  Great party!
> 
> Peace,
> 
> Peter
>

Almost totally better. I have a golfball size hard
rock that is either going to slowly heal over like a
year, or leave a dent. It's just wait and see... But
otherwise all better.

The worst part is, I run around like a 5 yr old girl
when I see black widows now... even though it was a
brown recluse... We have ZILLIONS of widows here. I
have had the exterminators out 3 times to spray my
entire property, because I keep seeing more fucking
spiders.

I put some "around day 8" pics on my myspace page.
They are from after about 90% of the swelling went
away, but you can still see some of the grossness.
There's even an oozing picture... LOL

Thanks for asking....

E

PS... Chris, we shoulda had a raver baseball team
years ago. I can still throw in the mid 80's... I'm a
bit wild now, but that just scares batters...  ;)

Filter.SF :: David Last :: Goosehound/Unfoundsound :: Live PA
Friday, November 30, 2007 (10:00 PM)
Filter.SF featuring David Last :: Live PA

With BABD/Filter Residents:

Kontakt + Solekandi :: live/DJ
Saya :: DJ

Friday, Nov. 30
Anu-Bar
46 6th St
Free before 11
$5 after 11


>From the critically-acclaimed Pocket Pet project with Japan's Segeke for the
Goosehound Label - to remixes for Wolf + Lamb - to a slew of releases for
Found/Unfoundsound plus forthcoming material on Musique Risquee, expect to
be hearing a lot about this Brooklyn-based artist and producer in the coming
months.

As one of the emerging names in experimental dancefloor minimalism, David
Last has translated the format of live laptop techno into a high energy
stompfest using elements of dancehall, dub and hip-hop - severely rocking
crowds in Australia, Japan and the U.S.

Catch his live PA in a premier West Coast performance Friday, Nov. 30.

------=_Part_10284_31887947.1194901471189--

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: BSP: Looking for house dj's for  house music only internet radio page

--0-1004773648-1194902454=:76901
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Hey what's up peeps. I am starting a brand new internet radio page dedicated strictly to house music, and I'm looking for house dj's that would be interested in broadcasting live mix shows from the comfort  of their own home. This is just getting started so all time slots are open and available at this time. Slots will be filled on a first come first serve basis. In order to broadcast you will need your own home dj set up, a computer with internet connection and at least a mic or line in, and a webcam. 
 
 
If you are interested in filling a time slot please email me at househeadradio@yahoo.com. with the weekday and time slot you would like. Please have a demo mix available for review (preferably a downloadable mix to speed up the process) and a short bio.
 
Thanks,
 
Kevin James & Househead Radio

 
Dowload my latest mixes here:
www.musicv2.com/artist/dj_kevin_james
New mix added 10/28/07
 
Watch me spin live Sunday evenings here:
http://www.stickam.com/profile/djkevinjames
 
Baba Booey!!!

them from the inside of my mailbox. I didn't believe
it either, until Poison Control TOLD me what they
were... Little bastards... the spiders that is... 

They are positive it was not a MATURE black widow, and
fairly certain of the Brown Recluse diagnosis, because
it was a necrotic toxin and not a neuro-toxin....
could have been a baby or male widow... but according
to the hospital, docs, and poison control, it was a
classic recluse bite.

And... around dusk, or in a storage unit, or just a
walk around thhe neigborhood, we could find a black
widow chillin every 25 feet... SERIOUSLY. 

I like to WD-40 Torch em now. ALthough, in this day
and age, some asshole might have you arrested for
using an improvised explosive device if they see you
doin it. LOL... but seriously... Did you hear the
story about thhe Kragen employee who got Patriot-Acted
for blowing up a dry-ice 2 litre plastic bottle
"bomb"?

awesome review, thank you!

i too saw some smiling faces from my earliest days of partying - i definitely felt the family reunion vibe in a big way. huge thanks to everyone who made it out to this event! it was definitely one for the record books, and we're all very proud to call you our friends :)

love,
mo

Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> wrote: WTF, Ambient Mafia invented a time machine last night. I had no 
idea I was going 88 miles per hour with a flux capacitor in the 
building.

Party started off great, and then suddenly I'm surrounded by 
Brian Behlendorf, Bryce, and Wayne Correia? (OG SFRavers). Us 
four haven't been in the same place, same time in *years*.

Tons of reminiscing, including Brian reminding me that Garth 
played at the *first* SFR party at Bonny Doon in '92.

Time machine continued: Steph Stiavetti, Martin Randall, 
Assorted Cloudfactory peeps, many more, crap it was just weird.

That aside, the overall crowd was fantastic, a nice eclectic 
blend of well-mannered (and freaky!) people.

Kevin the laser guy was super-cool, he brought 4 hand-built 
lasers. He really knows his stuff and we got to geek out on his 
gear for a while.

I had a few of the newer Viberation crew in tow, who started a 
fun breakdance circle, then later told me they felt 
self-conscience about it. I'm like, "Dude, look around you, 
stilt walkers and freaks of all kinds, you're supposed to 
express yourself!". This party was a huge eye-opener for them.

The Ambient Mafia crew is the shit. Not only a tight group of 
awesome people, to have downtempo opened-up and displayed 
center-stage like that was refreshing. The party was produced 
so well I felt spoiled ;-)

They rocked it, congrats :-)

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] WR: The Mafia 8 Yr Ann Shindig & Thank U Mafia

So even to get to the location like... I mean... yeah... 4 hours
consisting of a car ride, a bus, 2 barts, a walk to the bus stop to like
4th & harrison 'cause i forgot i can catch the muni on 4th but it only
took me to Cal Train station & i had to walk to China Basin to get to rhw
light rail muni stop, then i was lost for a while on the street 'cause the
well.. the directions i had kinda told me to go the wrong way then i
finally got there.. lol.. Hello 2Day... I mean... I really wan feeling
kinda outta place @ the beginning of the party 'cause i still had raver
commute funk on my head like hardcore & I just wanted to melt into the
party...

Soon enough though it started happening.. like i mean.. fuckin' good
fucki'n shit man... like outta the old raver year book, Yes Jim, Bryce is
back for a week & he looked really good on Saturday like healthier or
something... YUM!  Randel also came out of hiding in Santa Cruz to come
party down!!! Yeah.. I mean.. things got really full & the warehouse got
really full & was @ peak for a few hours & kinda got scary.. kinda... but
i mean... yeah... it wa a mondo Family night w/ like oh my gosh...
serioulsy.. it hella felt like mondo time machine to back in the day when
everyone was just kickin' it like some kinda ASR,Epiphany, FnF, Cloud
Factory, SFR kinda old school party!!  Even Canada & Malaysia (Dina &
Professor Terri) made an appearance well.. yeah.. i'ld love to get more
into that next post!!!

But oh my gosh, yeah... OK.. I feel bad I missed Wayne.. ain't seen him in
forever! But yeah.... talk about a family reunion, HELLO 2DAY!!! 
Eeeeveryone came out, Steph Stiaveti oooh (grrr.. forgot her married last
name), Brian was out, Super Puff Nate, I mean... gosh... I can't even
remember names.. but yeah... totally man... overall, alot people showed
up, Groovy vibe, so much yummy energy!!!  Even Canada & Malaysia (Dina &
Professor Terri) made an appearance well.. yeah.. i'ld love to get more
into that next post!!!  It was Awesome just seeing everyone who showed
up.. so many people!!!  But the overall Family vibe was just so damn
YUmmy!!!  It was Cute.. alota raveres from the Bay Raves showed up & were
like in awe of the party.. but yeah.. alota random people, some punk
rockers, it was just i mean.. yeah... so Dope!!!

Then like the Music was just all chill @ the begining.. Samba Samba Groovy
into like oooh... the Yummy live chill down tempo a la cubik y origami
ok.. & the live singing.. Oh My Gosh.. the Fieldsoe & the Skank w/ his
Yummy Awesome Groovy Dolphin Jungle I mean.. the Shane.... OK.. like all
the sets were Dope!! I Loved hearing Herbie Hancock Rockit & ooh gosh...
everything just got yummy & stuff!!  I mean... i was on the floor alot
dancin' my ass off so many times through out the night... i mean.. even
the chill down tempo sets I was just full of moves!!!

DEcorations Yummy.. there was lazers, lazers, smoke, & yummy visuals a la
terry.. oh my gosh man... so much fun stuff to look @!!!  Then the alter
in the main room in front of the DJ booth oooh.. & all the yummy colorful
lighting!!!  Oh yeah.. there was a bubble in the back that you could sit
in.. i never got to chill in there.. but man.. so Dope!!!

OK.. seriously though... YAAAAY!!  Hello 2day.. so much fun!!  Like i was
hardcore down & out a lil bit before the party started & a lil during...
but as soon as like all the the Groovy energy started manifesting itself
through the night, i got touched & filled w/ this amazing feeling of like
something kinda undescribale but i can say it was so touching!  I mean.. i
was literally feeling like blah... maybe 'cause of the nap i took in the
chill room during el jaun's set ('cause i was kinda through from the 4-5
hour commute & just needed to rest) & I kinda woke up disoriented i
think.. but ya know.. this is just 1 of them raves that just renewed
something in me & fuck man.. i'm proud to be part of the scene here!! 
Yeah.. i know yada yada, i say that probably once, maybe twice a year, but
fuck man... Thank U Ambient Mafia for a yummy night/ moring of
everything!!  I Love U All so much!!!  Thanks for helping me get that
feeling back!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Phoenix UG venue shut down by fire marshall

The old warehouse on South Fourth Avenue was a rarity for Phoenix, and not just because it's a cavernous old building in a city that has so few of them. What really made it unusual: It was a place to rave in a town where raving is hard to do. 

The kids called it "Boo's Warehouse," after the building's manager, 61-year-old Michael "Boo" Booher. And for months on end, neighbors say, Boo hosted raves that packed 'em in by the hundreds. 

It was quite the scene, but like all scenes without the proper permits, it was destined to come to an end. Two weeks ago, the Phoenix fire marshal caught wind of a rave called "Bloodfest 3." When the party went off, even after the Fire Department's warnings, they shut it down. 

...

http://search.phoenixnewtimes.com/2007-10-25/news/the-party-s-over/

Yeah!

 of weeks.=0A=0AAnyway, I quickly headed back to my room for a bit of the u=
sual hotel pay per view action.  It was then that I discovered the true sen=
sual nature of the Vagisoft pocket lining of my jacket.  Wow!  I'll spare y=
ou all the gory details, but lets just say that this jacket really needs mo=
re than two pockets!=0A=0ANow I find myself curious as to whether you've ev=
er considered using this luxurious and sensual fabric for other garments.  =
I'm thinking of perhaps some jockey briefs or maybe just a simple banana ha=
mmock.  =0A=0AI think either product could be a huge seller for you and it =
could signal Cordarounds entrance into an entirely new target market and de=
mographic segment.  Alternatively, would you consider a one off custom job?=

--- dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:

> A bit of immature humor to lighten your afternoon...
> 
> Delete this if you aren't in the mood!
> 
> Best,
> 
> Peter
> 
> Reversible Jacket with Vagisoft Lining?
> From:John Smythe (mr_smythe@hotmail.com)
> Sent:Wed 11/14/07 2:10 PM
> To: chris@cordarounds.com
> Bcc: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> 
> 
> Dear Sir:
>  
> I wanted to start off by saying that I am the happy
> recipient of one of your reversible smoking jackets.
>  I received the jacket as a gift from a close friend
> and it has since become my constant travel
> companion.  I do a lot of business travel and I like
> to pack light.  The reversible smoking jacket gives
> me such terrific flexibility, I don't need to bring
> another jacket with me.  
>  
> On a recent trip to NYC, following a successful day
> of business meetings with the jacket in blazer mode
> (auto hankie out) I decided to head back to my hotel
> for some R&R.  Thanks in part to the distraction
> from my laser wrist logos, I had convinced a large
> client to make their largest ever purchase from me
> and I was in a very good mood.
>  
> After a quick shave and shower, I simply reversed
> the jacket into nehru mode and headed down stairs to
> the bar where an assortment of lovelies awaited me. 
> I was certain that I would get lucky in part because
> of the confidence my reversible jacket had given me.
>  
>  
> However, five hours later despite my best efforts,
> winning pick up lines, extensive generosity, and the
> jacket, I found myself staggering back to my room
> alone.  Needless to say I was frustrated and lonely,
> especially since I had already been traveling for a
> number of weeks.
>  
> Anyway, I quickly headed back to my room for a bit
> of the usual hotel pay per view action.  It was then
> that I discovered the true sensual nature of the
> Vagisoft pocket lining of my jacket.  Wow!  I'll
> spare you all the gory details, but lets just say
> that this jacket really needs more than two pockets!
>  
> Now I find myself curious as to whether you've ever
> considered using this luxurious and sensual fabric
> for other garments.  I'm thinking of perhaps some
> jockey briefs or maybe just a simple banana hammock.
>  
>  
> I think either product could be a huge seller for
> you and it could signal Cordarounds entrance into an
> entirely new target market and demographic segment. 
> Alternatively, would you consider a one off custom
> job?
>  
> Sincerely Yours, 
>  
> John Smythe
> 
>

>
> Dear Sir:
>
> I wanted to start off by saying that I am the happy recipient of one of your reversible smoking jackets. I received the jacket as a gift from a close friend and it has since become my constant travel companion. I do a lot of business travel and I like to pack light. The reversible smoking jacket gives me such terrific flexibility, I don't need to bring another jacket with me.
>
> On a recent trip to NYC, following a successful day of business meetings with the jacket in blazer mode (auto hankie out) I decided to head back to my hotel for some R&R. Thanks in part to the distraction from my laser wrist logos, I had convinced a large client to make their largest ever purchase from me and I was in a very good mood.
>
> After a quick shave and shower, I simply reversed the jacket into nehru mode and headed down stairs to the bar where an assortment of lovelies awaited me. I was certain that I would get lucky in part because of the confidence my reversible jacket had given me.
>
> However, five hours later despite my best efforts, winning pick up lines, extensive generosity, and the jacket, I found myself staggering back to my room alone. Needless to say I was frustrated and lonely, especially since I had already been traveling for a number of weeks.
>
> Anyway, I quickly headed back to my room for a bit of the usual hotel pay per view action. It was then that I discovered the true sensual nature of the Vagisoft pocket lining of my jacket. Wow! I'll spare you all the gory details, but lets just say that this jacket really needs more than two pockets!
>
> Now I find myself curious as to whether you've ever considered using this luxurious and sensual fabric for other garments. I'm thinking of perhaps some jockey briefs or maybe just a simple banana hammock.
>
> I think either product could be a huge seller for you and it could signal Cordarounds entrance into an entirely new target market and demographic segment. Alternatively, would you consider a one off custom job?
>
> Sincerely Yours,
>
> John Smythe
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - Radio Integrated on the air, this Friday 11/16, 8pm-12am PST

------=_Part_5067_30586312.1195080643163
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

So finally. . . after lots of years of talking about it, DEF has finally
launched a techno-oriented online radio station, Radio Integrated. (Lots of
thanks must go out to our awesome wonderful friend DJ STML, who has been a
major part of getting this thing off the ground!) We're not on the air 24/7
just yet, but will be starting out with weekly shows.

Broadcasting live from Bliss Factory Studios in Alameda, Integrated will
feature DJ sets, interviews, live performances, and new and classic techno,
tech-house, electro, minimal, acid, neotrance, and other techy sounds, from
the San Francisco Bay to the banks of the Spree.

Our first weekly programming block will be coming up this Friday, November
16th, from 8pm to midnight Pacific Standard Time. 8-10 will be hosted by me,
Chelsea Faith, and 10-12 will be a live techno mix on three turntables by
DJs Toro Toro and Disconnect.

Tune in at http://www.zer01.net:1200/
Contact : radiointegrated@gmail.com


Love Chelsea

------=_Part_5067_30586312.1195080643163--

Saturday, November 17th, 2007  

MUCHTHUMP brings you THUMPLAND... 

A sweet warehouse party dedicated to the underground
sounds that we love so much...  going above and beyond
with a plush space, and rich, beautiful sound. 
MUCHTHUMP has assembled a line-up of DJ's bringin' the
electroniclovebombs filled with Techhouse, Electro,
Techno, Electro House, and Minimal Techno sounds that
will get the joint muchthump'n!  

--------C U THERE---------

Forest Green (Cute Things With Fangs, Daly City
Records, FnF, CFC)

Vinyl only mixes should be a requirement for a contest like this, in my
opinion.  Anyway, here's a little trance bit I put together right before the
start of the quarter, actually it makes me feel unoriginal now because I was
doing the exact same thing (playing around with my stash of trance records
from years gone past).  Incidentally it's just about an hour long too, so I
think it makes a good candidate.  Cheese factor locked in, phasers set to
glo-stick.

http://progressivemojo.phang.net/progressiveMOJO%20-%2011%20Reasons%20For%20Liking%20Trance.mp3

bring it on!

> From: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Wednesday, November 14, 2007 2:16:17 PM
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: In which I enquire about that sensual Vagisoft<tm> lining...
>
> A bit of immature humor to lighten your afternoon...
>
> Delete this if you aren't in the mood!
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
> Reversible Jacket with Vagisoft Lining
> From:John Smythe (mr_smythe@hotmail.com)
> Sent:Wed 11/14/07 2:10 PM
> To: chris@cordarounds.com
> Bcc: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
>
>
> Dear Sir:
>
> I wanted to start off by saying that I am the happy recipient of one of your reversible smoking jackets.  I received the jacket as a gift from a close friend and it has since become my constant travel companion.   I do a lot of business travel and I like to pack light.  The reversible smoking jacket gives me such terrific flexibility, I don't need to bring another jacket with me.
>
> On a recent trip to NYC, following a successful day of business meetings with the jacket in blazer mode (auto hankie out) I decided to head back to my hotel for some R&R.  Thanks in part to the distraction from my laser wrist logos, I had convinced a large client to make their largest ever purchase from me and I was in a very good mood.
>
> After a quick shave and shower, I simply reversed the jacket into nehru mode and headed down stairs to the bar where an assortment of lovelies awaited me.  I was certain that I would get lucky in part because of the confidence my reversible jacket had given me.
>
> However, five hours later despite my best efforts, winning pick up lines, extensive generosity, and the jacket, I found myself staggering back to my room alone.  Needless to say I was frustrated and lonely, especially since I had already been traveling for a number of weeks.
>
> Anyway, I quickly headed back to my room for a bit of the usual hotel pay per view action.  It was then that I discovered the true sensual nature of the Vagisoft pocket lining of my jacket.  Wow!  I'll spare you all the gory details, but lets just say that this jacket really needs more than two pockets!
>
> Now I find myself curious as to whether you've ever considered using this luxurious and sensual fabric for other garments.  I'm thinking of perhaps some jockey briefs or maybe just a simple banana hammock.
>
> I think either product could be a huge seller for you and it could signal Cordarounds entrance into an entirely new target market and demographic segment.  Alternatively, would you consider a one off custom job?
>
> Sincerely Yours,
>
> John Smythe
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Who am I?
My name is Ish.
On my hand I have a dish.
I have this dish
to help me wish.
When I wish to make a wish
I wave my hand with a big swish swish.
Then I say, "I wish for fish!"
And I get fish right on my dish.
So...
if you wish to wish a wish,
you may swish for fish
with my Ish wish dish.


-- Dr. Seuss

Waking up to this was great :)  Thanks JC.  Also, Tiesticles.

oh yeah, tracklist from the set I submitted:
1. Bedrock - Beautiful Strange (Moonface Remix)
2. Orbital - Lush 3.1/3.2
3. Sunscreem - Love U More (Boy's Dub)
4. Slick Mick - A Classic Thing
5. X-Tracks - Plan 94 (Chapter 1)
6. Chakka Boom Bang - Tossing and Turning (Original Mix)
7. Resistance D - Feel High (Spacefrog & Time Lord Remix)
8. Deepsky - Prime Radiant
9. Gus Gus - Believe (LFO Remix)
10. Sasha & Maria - Heart of Imagination
11. Hybrid - Symphony (Original mix)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Happy Fun Ball

Happy Fun Ball
-only $14.95-

Warning: Pregnant women, the elderly and children under 10 should avoid 
prolonged exposure to Happy Fun Ball.

Caution: Happy Fun Ball may suddenly accelerate to dangerous speeds.

Happy Fun Ball Contains a liquid core, which, if exposed due to rupture, 
should not be touched, inhaled, or looked at.

Do not use Happy Fun Ball on concrete.

Discontinue use of Happy Fun Ball if any of the following occurs:

Itching
Vertigo
Dizziness
Tingling in extremities
Loss of balance or coordination
Slurred speech
Temporary Blindness
Profuse sweating
Heart Palpitations
If Happy Fun Ball begins to smoke, get away immediately. Seek shelter 
and cover head.

Happy Fun Ball may stick to certain types of skin.

When not in use, Happy Fun Ball should be returned to its special 
container and kept under refrigeration...

Failure to do so relieves the makers of Happy Fun Ball, Wacky Products 
Incorporated, and its parent company Global Chemical Unlimited, of any 
and all liability.

ingredients of Happy Fun Ball include an unknown glowing substance which 
fell to Earth, presumably from outer space.

Happy Fun Ball has been shipped to our troops in Saudi Arabia and is 
also being dropped by our warplanes on Iraq.

Do not taunt Happy Fun Ball.

Happy Fun Ball comes with a lifetime guarantee.

Happy Fun Ball ACCEPT NO SUBSTITUTES!


-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Rave on... acid house is back

Rave on... acid house is back
Richard Hector-Jones
16/11/2007

AS Saturday's Warehouse Project acknowledges the 20th anniversary of =
acid
house with a stellar line-up of young guns, City Life tracks down a few =
of
the city's originators to recall the vitality of a musical revolution.

It was a revolution that, in the UK, grew very much from a =
post-industrial
Manchester ravaged by decay and dereliction - way before the bomb, =
before
regeneration and before the trappings of modernity we take for granted
today.

Graham Massey, innovator, producer and musician, says: "As a musician =
back
in the Eighties, I'd always been interested in music that was =
transcendent
in some way. That might include psychedelic rock, some of the heavier =
jazz
like Coltrane and Miles Davis, or even the weird easy listening records =
you
could pick up cheap back then. So long as music transported you to =
another
headspace it was doing its job for me.

"A lot of mid-Eighties music wasn't doing much. The indie scene and =
electro
pop was too kitchen sink drama - The Smiths being a good example - but =
there
was the beginnings of a more interesting 'off the wall' kinds of =
electronic
music around. New Order post Blue Monday and the extremism of another
ex-Manc, Genesis P Orridge, and Throbbing Gristle.

"I got more into music technology when I enrolled on a course at The =
School
of Sound Recording on Tariff Street. All of a sudden I had access to
computer music and samplers which were brand new at the time. At the =
same
time, a local Sunday night radio show by Stu Allen was playing these
imported American house records coming into the legendary Spin Inn =
records.
Much of it I didn't care for but some was so alien and had that =
transcendent
quality you get in heavy African music - primal yet futuristic.

"Once I started hearing it in clubs and parties it all made perfect =
sense as
the soundtrack to a brand new scene - which is not to say that it didn't
divide people at first.

"We formed 808 State from a group of house music enthusiasts at Eastern =
Bloc
Records and it settled into a three piece of Gerald Simpson, Martin =
Price
and myself. We were immediately in demand for warehouse parties and club
nights. We found with enough drum machines and synthesizers we could
improvise long organic non-stop sets and we began to find our own style =
of
acid.

Civic pride

"One of the unique things about making acid house back then is that you =
knew
who and where you were making this music for. There was almost a civic =
pride
in the north west clubbing scene, especially when heading in convoy up =
the
motorways, talking about what made a good track.

"There were occasions when we would make a track, jump in a cab and get =
that
track played at the Hacienda that same evening. It was a DIY music =
industry
with an exciting immediacy that fed back into the music. There were so =
many
great records coming out every week that inspired you to want to make =
one
better.

"To me, a very special relationship between the industrially decayed
mid-west of America and the industrially decayed north of England =
developed
as we lobbed tunes at each other on a weekly basis.

"If there's one memory that sticks in my mind from that period it was
watching the Berlin Wall coming down on the news as they were all =
dancing to
one of our tunes. We tried to create a futuristic optimism musically, so =
to
me it was `right time right place!'."

Hacienda

Graeme Park, legendary Hacienda and radio DJ, says: "I vividly recall =
the
first house records appearing from Chicago, Detroit and New York as =
early as
1986. I was DJing at The Garage in Nottingham and people were quite =
hostile
to this new sound that was essentially electronic disco influenced by
European electronic bands such as Kraftwerk, Depeche Mode, Telex and =
others
and played on cheap drum machines and synthesisers.

"Quite why people didn't warm to it straight away was beyond me at the =
time,
but I persevered and little by little house took over my entire record =
box.
Mike Pickering was similarly pioneering house in Manchester at the same
time, which is how we became aware of each other. It was in 1988 that I
joined Mike on the decks at The Hacienda to provide a DJ dream ticket =
and a
platform for house music to spread like wildfire. Sure it's spawned a =
huge
amount of crap, but it's still the only form of music that continues to
evolve and surprise and, most importantly, survive trends which =
ultimately
come and go in a whim.

"And I still love it now!"

Justin Robertson, DJ and producer, says: "Acid house changed my life in =
a
real road to Damascus way! It took the energy of disco, the evolving =
groove
of kraut rock and the spaciousness of dub and married it with a happily
carefree attitude to using new technology that few knew how to work
properly! Thus, a whole new musical revolution was created by chance.

"It can't be exaggerated how alien this music sounded then and indeed =
still
sounds today. It changed the way people write songs, how they produce, =
and
socially what constitutes a good night out! Before 1988, standing on a =
stage
waving my arms about like a demented robot filled with experimental =
appetite
suppressants wasn't even on my list of things to do!

"Crucially, I believe that acid house also empowered people by =
demystifying
the music making process and making it available to everyone. This DIY =
ethic
was the true fruition of the project punk could never finish. It was =
also
big fun!"

The Warehouse Project takes place under Piccadilly train station on =
Saturday
night featuring Vitalic (Live), Digitalism, The Whip (Live), Ivan =
Smagghe,
Simian Mobile Disco DJ set, A-trak & DJ Medhi (Ed Banger), and Ting =
Tings
(Live). For more info visit thewarehouseproject.com.

http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/clubs/s/1024613_rave=
_on
_acid_house_is_back



apollo@speakeasy.org
MySpace:=A0=A0http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo=A0
Tribenet:=A0=A0=A0http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
Moksha Tribe:=A0=A0www.mokshatribe.org=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 =
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0
House Music =
101:=A0=A0http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is =
nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and =
look
and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you
upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!"=20
- W.B.YEATS=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Rave on... acid house is back

I really don't think that acid really ever left our consciousness. 
There seems to have even been an acid "resurgance" that took place 2 or 
3 years ago.  But even so, I think that the 303 sound will never die, in 
this scene at least.  It may be resurrected in new and differenet forms 
from time to time, but we all owe a debt of one form or another to it.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: FYI: Sites who have traded/sold my email address

So, I've been lucky enough to have been aware of methods to easily 
generate "portable" email addresses that are easily traceable over the 
past few years (which has simply been a sneakemail.com account) :). 
And in doing so, I've also been able to "track down those "not so 
scrupulous" sites" that have either sold or traded these email addreses.

(FYI, sneakemail.com will generate a non-dictionary-guessable email user 
ID address, which is how I can confidently say that these sites are not 
ones to place your trust in.)

So, based upon what I've learned, I think it's appropriate to provide an 
accounting of the untrusted sights who have sold/traded these email 
addresses over the past few years (which, surprisingly, is less than one 
might expect.)

Here goes:
laplink.com
greenzap.com
thedjlist.com
lowdot.com this is likely a DNS registration spam.)
hpic.com (yeah, a porn site, of which apparently spams their 
affiliates. And they truly have no mercy; i.e. MULTIPLE spams each day. 
As well as evidence that they've traded the address to ANYONE who will 
pay.)
ekaiser.com
thedjlist.com (exclusively for jameswilliams.us???  I'm assuming that 
he must have been one of the primcipals behind the thedjlist.com site. 
If so, he's obviously another DJ Seven.)
groovetickets.com
aptimus.com/travel.com ("same" site, same result -> spam.)
yahoo.fr (apparently spamming the DNS registation DB.)
milfhunter.com (again, a porn site that apparently spams their 
affiliates.)
eroticy.com (another site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
onlinebootycall.com (still another site that apparently spams their 
affiliates.)

To this day, I still remember chatting with AndyW one evening about 
whether we were involved with "porn" or "spam" to be able to survive the 
1st internet bubble, and it seems to be obvious that they both survived.

FWIW, let this be your guide (and your friend;s guide.)


-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: FYI: Sites who have traded/sold my email address

So, I've been lucky enough to have been aware of methods to easily generate 
"portable" email addresses that are easily traceable over the past few years 
(which has simply been a sneakemail.com account) :). And in doing so, I've also 
been able to "track down those "not so scrupulous" sites" that have either sold 
or traded these email addreses.  And it's not the "biggest" list, which seems 
to be a "good" thing.

(FYI, sneakemail.com will generate a non-dictionary-guessable email user ID 
address, which is how I can confidently say that these sites are not ones to 
place your trust in.  And they're entry level account is free.)

So, based upon what I've learned, I think it's appropriate to provide an 
accounting of the untrusted sights who have sold/traded these email addresses 
over the past few years (which, surprisingly, is less than one might expect.)

Here goes:
laplink.com
greenzap.com
thedjlist.com
lowdot.com this is likely a DNS registration spam.)
hpic.com (yeah, a porn site, of which apparently spams their affiliates. And 
they truly have no mercy; i.e. MULTIPLE spams each day. As well as evidence 
that they've traded the address to ANYONE who will pay.)
ekaiser.com
thedjlist.com (exclusively for jameswilliams.us???  I'm assuming that he must 
have been one of the primcipals behind the thedjlist.com site. If so, he's 
obviously another DJ Seven.)
groovetickets.com
aptimus.com/travel.com ("same" site, same result -> spam.)
yahoo.fr (apparently spamming the DNS registation DB.)
milfhunter.com (again, a porn site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
eroticy.com (another site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
onlinebootycall.com (still another site that apparently spams their 
affiliates.)
gujaratonair.com
democracybike.com (yeah, WTF is up with an org such as this chosing this 
path??)

Please feel free to add your own experiences to the list.



FYI, this list is based upon receiving emails outside of what one might 
consider a normal relationship with these individual sites.

To this day, I still remember chatting with AndyW one evening about whether we 
were involved with "porn" or "spam" to be able to survive the 1st internet 
bubble, and it seems to be obvious that they both survived.

FWIW, let this be your guide (and your friend's guide.)

----- Original Message ----
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, November 16, 2007 12:36:40 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Rave on... acid house is back

Rave on... acid house is back
Richard Hector-Jones
16/11/2007

AS Saturday's Warehouse Project acknowledges the 20th anniversary of acid
house with a stellar line-up of young guns, City Life tracks down a few of
the city's originators to recall the vitality of a musical revolution.

It was a revolution that, in the UK, grew very much from a post-industrial
Manchester ravaged by decay and dereliction - way before the bomb, before
regeneration and before the trappings of modernity we take for granted
today.

Graham Massey, innovator, producer and musician, says: "As a musician back
in the Eighties, I'd always been interested in music that was transcendent
in some way. That might include psychedelic rock, some of the heavier jazz
like Coltrane and Miles Davis, or even the weird easy listening records you
could pick up cheap back then. So long as music transported you to another
headspace it was doing its job for me.

"A lot of mid-Eighties music wasn't doing much. The indie scene and electro
pop was too kitchen sink drama - The Smiths being a good example - but there
was the beginnings of a more interesting 'off the wall' kinds of electronic
music around. New Order post Blue Monday and the extremism of another
ex-Manc, Genesis P Orridge, and Throbbing Gristle.

"I got more into music technology when I enrolled on a course at The School
of Sound Recording on Tariff Street. All of a sudden I had access to
computer music and samplers which were brand new at the time. At the same
time, a local Sunday night radio show by Stu Allen was playing these
imported American house records coming into the legendary Spin Inn records.
Much of it I didn't care for but some was so alien and had that transcendent
quality you get in heavy African music - primal yet futuristic.

"Once I started hearing it in clubs and parties it all made perfect sense as
the soundtrack to a brand new scene - which is not to say that it didn't
divide people at first.

"We formed 808 State from a group of house music enthusiasts at Eastern Bloc
Records and it settled into a three piece of Gerald Simpson, Martin Price
and myself. We were immediately in demand for warehouse parties and club
nights. We found with enough drum machines and synthesizers we could
improvise long organic non-stop sets and we began to find our own style of
acid.

Civic pride

"One of the unique things about making acid house back then is that you knew
who and where you were making this music for. There was almost a civic pride
in the north west clubbing scene, especially when heading in convoy up the
motorways, talking about what made a good track.

"There were occasions when we would make a track, jump in a cab and get that
track played at the Hacienda that same evening. It was a DIY music industry
with an exciting immediacy that fed back into the music. There were so many
great records coming out every week that inspired you to want to make one
better.

"To me, a very special relationship between the industrially decayed
mid-west of America and the industrially decayed north of England developed
as we lobbed tunes at each other on a weekly basis.

"If there's one memory that sticks in my mind from that period it was
watching the Berlin Wall coming down on the news as they were all dancing to
one of our tunes. We tried to create a futuristic optimism musically, so to
me it was `right time right place!'."

Hacienda

Graeme Park, legendary Hacienda and radio DJ, says: "I vividly recall the
first house records appearing from Chicago, Detroit and New York as early as
1986. I was DJing at The Garage in Nottingham and people were quite hostile
to this new sound that was essentially electronic disco influenced by
European electronic bands such as Kraftwerk, Depeche Mode, Telex and others
and played on cheap drum machines and synthesisers.

"Quite why people didn't warm to it straight away was beyond me at the time,
but I persevered and little by little house took over my entire record box.
Mike Pickering was similarly pioneering house in Manchester at the same
time, which is how we became aware of each other. It was in 1988 that I
joined Mike on the decks at The Hacienda to provide a DJ dream ticket and a
platform for house music to spread like wildfire. Sure it's spawned a huge
amount of crap, but it's still the only form of music that continues to
evolve and surprise and, most importantly, survive trends which ultimately
come and go in a whim.

"And I still love it now!"

Justin Robertson, DJ and producer, says: "Acid house changed my life in a
real road to Damascus way! It took the energy of disco, the evolving groove
of kraut rock and the spaciousness of dub and married it with a happily
carefree attitude to using new technology that few knew how to work
properly! Thus, a whole new musical revolution was created by chance.

"It can't be exaggerated how alien this music sounded then and indeed still
sounds today. It changed the way people write songs, how they produce, and
socially what constitutes a good night out! Before 1988, standing on a stage
waving my arms about like a demented robot filled with experimental appetite
suppressants wasn't even on my list of things to do!

"Crucially, I believe that acid house also empowered people by demystifying
the music making process and making it available to everyone. This DIY ethic
was the true fruition of the project punk could never finish. It was also
big fun!"

The Warehouse Project takes place under Piccadilly train station on Saturday
night featuring Vitalic (Live), Digitalism, The Whip (Live), Ivan Smagghe,
Simian Mobile Disco DJ set, A-trak & DJ Medhi (Ed Banger), and Ting Tings
(Live). For more info visit thewarehouseproject.com.

http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/clubs/s/1024613_rave_on
_acid_house_is_back



apollo@speakeasy.org
MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo 
Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org                 
House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and look
and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you
upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!" 
- W.B.YEATS

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: FYI: Sites who have traded/sold my email address

I work in IT, do part time web work etc... 

I use my domain to track my spam... Best way ;) 

When I sign up for a site, say groovetickets.com I use
groovetickets@kiddzero.com, this distro sfraves@kiddzero.com... Etc.  

Over the years I've had countless spam, but I do fight back!  I'll take the
compromised address, whois the domain admin of the offending site (or even
use a help/sales alias) and put a forward from the spammed acct to their
domain.  Problem solved :D  

I've had a domain registrar sell my e-mail addy.. That was the worst.  I
think it was namezero.com, who back in the day was giving away free
.com's... not so freely.  

-r4ph

-----Original Message-----
From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu] 
Sent: Friday, November 16, 2007 2:56 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: FYI: Sites who have traded/sold my email address

So, I've been lucky enough to have been aware of methods to easily generate
"portable" email addresses that are easily traceable over the past few years
(which has simply been a sneakemail.com account) :). And in doing so, I've
also been able to "track down those "not so scrupulous" sites" that have
either sold or traded these email addreses.  And it's not the "biggest"
list, which seems to be a "good" thing.

(FYI, sneakemail.com will generate a non-dictionary-guessable email user ID
address, which is how I can confidently say that these sites are not ones to
place your trust in.  And they're entry level account is free.)

So, based upon what I've learned, I think it's appropriate to provide an
accounting of the untrusted sights who have sold/traded these email
addresses over the past few years (which, surprisingly, is less than one
might expect.)

Here goes:
laplink.com
greenzap.com
thedjlist.com
lowdot.com this is likely a DNS registration spam.) hpic.com (yeah, a porn
site, of which apparently spams their affiliates. And they truly have no
mercy; i.e. MULTIPLE spams each day. As well as evidence that they've traded
the address to ANYONE who will pay.) ekaiser.com thedjlist.com (exclusively
for jameswilliams.us???  I'm assuming that he must have been one of the
primcipals behind the thedjlist.com site. If so, he's obviously another DJ
Seven.) groovetickets.com aptimus.com/travel.com ("same" site, same result
-> spam.) yahoo.fr (apparently spamming the DNS registation DB.)
milfhunter.com (again, a porn site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
eroticy.com (another site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
onlinebootycall.com (still another site that apparently spams their
affiliates.)
gujaratonair.com
democracybike.com (yeah, WTF is up with an org such as this chosing this
path??)

Please feel free to add your own experiences to the list.



FYI, this list is based upon receiving emails outside of what one might
consider a normal relationship with these individual sites.

To this day, I still remember chatting with AndyW one evening about whether
we were involved with "porn" or "spam" to be able to survive the 1st
internet bubble, and it seems to be obvious that they both survived.

FWIW, let this be your guide (and your friend's guide.)


--
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing money in
the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of KZSU
Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] Ambient Mafia 8-year:  thank you!!!

Hey you!  Yes, you!

Thank YOU for coming out, participating in and making the
Ambient Mafia 8-year Anniversary Celebration an event for the
record books.

You see, the event would not have been the same without you. 
For us it was a fulfillment of a lifelong dream:  a dream that
began eight years ago when a few headz got together and
thought, "what if..."

"What if," indeed.

If you were in attendance on Saturday night, you witnessed that
dream explode beyond our wildest expectations.  As you know,
this event was about love:  love for the community that has
supported us for all of these years.  The community that has
taught us about exceeding the basics of party-throwing.  The
community that showed us that interaction and inclusion of our
attendees makes a good event an *epic* event.

This was our thanks to YOU.  Thank you for supporting us for
eight long years, for guiding us and giving advice on what you
want and need in an event.

And our apologies  our stilt walkers were having trouble
maneuvering around as the floors were so slippery due to the
rain:  we thought it was safer to forego that aspect of the
party.
 
Thanks to your support we have raised $1000 to be donated to
Direct Relief (directrelief.org) and SF Bay Keeper
(sfbaykeeper.org) to aid with the Southern California fires and
cleaning up the Bay Area oil spill.  (The Red Cross is no
longer accepting donations for the SoCal relief effort.)

Again, thank you for making this event what it was.  Keep your
ear to the ground - we will see you soon.

Love,
The Ambient Mafia

On 16 November 2007, raphael wrote:

> I work in IT, do part time web work etc...
>
> I use my domain to track my spam... Best way ;)
>
> When I sign up for a site, say groovetickets.com I use
> groovetickets@kiddzero.com, this distro sfraves@kiddzero.com... Etc.
>
> Over the years I've had countless spam, but I do fight back!  I'll take the
> compromised address, whois the domain admin of the offending site (or even
> use a help/sales alias) and put a forward from the spammed acct to their
> domain.  Problem solved :D
>
> I've had a domain registrar sell my e-mail addy.. That was the worst.  I
> think it was namezero.com, who back in the day was giving away free
> .com's... not so freely.

The domain registry entry's email address is always spammed.  I think 
I'm on my 4th or 5th address for that in not as many years.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: FYI: Sites who have traded/sold my email address

i know groovetickets absolutely gives access to emails.  if you sell
tickets for an event on groovetickets, they send you a list of names
and emails of people who make purchases.

so any promoter/company for whose event you've bought tickets for,
they do get your name and email.

On Nov 16, 2007 2:32 AM, J.C. <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu> wrote:
> So, I've been lucky enough to have been aware of methods to easily
> generate "portable" email addresses that are easily traceable over the
> past few years (which has simply been a sneakemail.com account) :).
> And in doing so, I've also been able to "track down those "not so
> scrupulous" sites" that have either sold or traded these email addreses.
>
> (FYI, sneakemail.com will generate a non-dictionary-guessable email user
> ID address, which is how I can confidently say that these sites are not
> ones to place your trust in.)
>
> So, based upon what I've learned, I think it's appropriate to provide an
> accounting of the untrusted sights who have sold/traded these email
> addresses over the past few years (which, surprisingly, is less than one
> might expect.)
>
> Here goes:
> laplink.com
> greenzap.com
> thedjlist.com
> lowdot.com this is likely a DNS registration spam.)
> hpic.com (yeah, a porn site, of which apparently spams their
> affiliates. And they truly have no mercy; i.e. MULTIPLE spams each day.
> As well as evidence that they've traded the address to ANYONE who will
> pay.)
> ekaiser.com
> thedjlist.com (exclusively for jameswilliams.us???  I'm assuming that
> he must have been one of the primcipals behind the thedjlist.com site.
> If so, he's obviously another DJ Seven.)
> groovetickets.com
> aptimus.com/travel.com ("same" site, same result -> spam.)
> yahoo.fr (apparently spamming the DNS registation DB.)
> milfhunter.com (again, a porn site that apparently spams their
> affiliates.)
> eroticy.com (another site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
> onlinebootycall.com (still another site that apparently spams their
> affiliates.)
>
> To this day, I still remember chatting with AndyW one evening about
> whether we were involved with "porn" or "spam" to be able to survive the
> 1st internet bubble, and it seems to be obvious that they both survived.
>
> FWIW, let this be your guide (and your friend;s guide.)
>

far and wide.)
