i guess i do something similar but i just turn the offending email  
address off so i don't get the spam.  some of the viagra ones and the  
she wishes it was bigger emails are kind of hilarious but i don't  
miss them.

a big offender for me was sprint pcs and their mycheckfree.com  
service, i gave my email address to them and almost immediately i  
started getting tons of spam.  tons.


On Nov 16, 2007, at 1:14 PM, raphael wrote:

> I work in IT, do part time web work etc...
>
> I use my domain to track my spam... Best way ;)
>
> When I sign up for a site, say groovetickets.com I use
> groovetickets@kiddzero.com, this distro sfraves@kiddzero.com... Etc.
>
> Over the years I've had countless spam, but I do fight back!  I'll  
> take the
> compromised address, whois the domain admin of the offending site  
> (or even
> use a help/sales alias) and put a forward from the spammed acct to  
> their
> domain.  Problem solved :D
>
> I've had a domain registrar sell my e-mail addy.. That was the  
> worst.  I
> think it was namezero.com, who back in the day was giving away free
> .com's... not so freely.
>
> -r4ph
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
> Sent: Friday, November 16, 2007 2:56 AM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: FYI: Sites who have traded/sold my email  
> address
>
> So, I've been lucky enough to have been aware of methods to easily  
> generate
> "portable" email addresses that are easily traceable over the past  
> few years
> (which has simply been a sneakemail.com account) :). And in doing  
> so, I've
> also been able to "track down those "not so scrupulous" sites" that  
> have
> either sold or traded these email addreses.  And it's not the  
> "biggest"
> list, which seems to be a "good" thing.
>
> (FYI, sneakemail.com will generate a non-dictionary-guessable email  
> user ID
> address, which is how I can confidently say that these sites are  
> not ones to
> place your trust in.  And they're entry level account is free.)
>
> So, based upon what I've learned, I think it's appropriate to  
> provide an
> accounting of the untrusted sights who have sold/traded these email
> addresses over the past few years (which, surprisingly, is less  
> than one
> might expect.)
>
> Here goes:
> laplink.com
> greenzap.com
> thedjlist.com
> lowdot.com this is likely a DNS registration spam.) hpic.com (yeah,  
> a porn
> site, of which apparently spams their affiliates. And they truly  
> have no
> mercy; i.e. MULTIPLE spams each day. As well as evidence that  
> they've traded
> the address to ANYONE who will pay.) ekaiser.com thedjlist.com  
> (exclusively
> for jameswilliams.us???  I'm assuming that he must have been one of  
> the
> primcipals behind the thedjlist.com site. If so, he's obviously  
> another DJ
> Seven.) groovetickets.com aptimus.com/travel.com ("same" site, same  
> result
> -> spam.) yahoo.fr (apparently spamming the DNS registation DB.)
> milfhunter.com (again, a porn site that apparently spams their  
> affiliates.)
> eroticy.com (another site that apparently spams their affiliates.)
> onlinebootycall.com (still another site that apparently spams their
> affiliates.)
> gujaratonair.com
> democracybike.com (yeah, WTF is up with an org such as this chosing  
> this
> path??)
>
> Please feel free to add your own experiences to the list.
>
>
>
> FYI, this list is based upon receiving emails outside of what one  
> might
> consider a normal relationship with these individual sites.
>
> To this day, I still remember chatting with AndyW one evening about  
> whether
> we were involved with "porn" or "spam" to be able to survive the 1st
> internet bubble, and it seems to be obvious that they both survived.
>
> FWIW, let this be your guide (and your friend's guide.)
>
>

Reply-To: osby@viberation.com
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.10a
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] WR: My Friday Night Adventure

So while this is still fresh in my head, & 'cause of the Raver hours of
Night Owl Insomniac i am still experiencing (well... of the past like 16
years now but even more so the past 2 'cause of staying up to catch
Voltron on Cartoon network @ 6AM then to only discover it was series 1
they only showed & not 2 or even the 3rd series that never aired), I have
decided to write my WR while it's still kinda fresh in the head...

So midweek, i get an email from Mikalow telling me about a shindig soire @
his pad on Friday... i had a previous like appointment w/ this promoter
person dude thingie, & thought about like just goin' to Anu from there..
but unfortunately that didn't pan out 'cause Homeboy got like mondo tummy
sick.. so i ended up goin' to his shindig... now mind you... this was a
"yucca party", so when enough people showed up @ Mikalow's pad... all the
ingrediants (10 cut up limes & lemons, alota ice, that big ass kinda blue
& clear bottle of vodka, & 3 pounds of sugar) we're all put in the 1st 2
square jug container thingies w/ spouts & all we had to do was like 5
minute shake shakes passes for like 20-30 minutes... OK... I had like a
big cup an a 1/2, 2 cups of this stuff & got tooooasted.. but not too like
tosted.. but really fuckin' damn fluffy man... & it's on rare occasions i
drink like that... but it was a special occasion!!!

Oh yeah.. be all that though.. like this house/ apartment party was like
filled w/ around 20-30 people, the only ravers were me & Mikalow, everyone
else was pretty much a tech geek, designer, or green peace
envirormentalist from Cal Berkeley... & just to have fun.. like i mean...
ofcourse i couldn't talk to them about music or this DJ or that party...
so i decided that i would introduce myself to each person with a different
name!  So i was Oliver, Daniel, Phil, Adrienne, Albert, Bob, & just all
these random normal names that i could come up with with a 2 second time
from of being introduced to each person... so when i ran out ofnormal
names, i started using countries like Afganistan, Austrailia, Blegium,
Canada, oh yeah.. i was even Brazil to a person!  Oooh yeah.. i was also
Isreal, Izzy for short, to this 1 dude who returned the greet & said, "Hi,
I"m Jeruselum, Jerry for short".  Hello 2Day!!!

So i stumbled over to Anu from Mikalow's pad & ooooooh.. it was Ill!!! 
OK.. the BIG crew tagged for like 2 hours all this yummy Dub Step & Hip
Hop... then OK.. the big fuckin' event.. Mega got on the decks & ok..
YUUUUUUUUUUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM... i mean.. he got off the 1st
hour like spinning dub step, then ok... he dropped this 2 Step track..
this old tune that ooh man.. ok... then from that... ok.. HELLO 2DAY, he
dropped this fuckin' old skool hardcore "techno" song (almost sounded like
an old 2 Bad Mice song) & I mean... who fuckin' does that???  I mean...
Who fuckin' does that shit & get away with it???  Shit man... it was like
heeeeeeella fuckin' Ill & i started dancing so hard on that tiny ass dance
floor @ Anu :) :) :)  WOW!!!  OK.. so then he went back to Dub Step then
closed his set w/ this Jungle track!!  Fuckin' YUM!!!  Ooh my goodness, Oh
My gosh... so Mondo Yum!!!

OK.. yeah.. then the rest of the night... the BIG crew totally tagged
until the last record!!  But it was So Dope!!!  Ummm.. they played alot
more broken beats this 2nd time around!!!  So YUM!!!  But the crowd that
all gathered up in Anu was Sick.. everyone Loved it, hella people dancing,
ooh Hello 2day... things got Frisky with DeceptaJason there for a bit..
Hello 2day!!  but it was so Dope!!!  Loved it!!!

OK.. then i got dragged across the street to Aarow Bar 'cause Smooves GF
was havin' a BDAY shindig (Rock On Sista Scorpio) there & some of the
Breaks crew was there & alota burners & it was fun!!  I had a huuuuuuuge
peice of Chinese cake (i knew it had to be from an Asain Bakery 'cause
there was soo much fruit in it ;)  BUt yeah.. ooooooooh... spo Bandon
showed up to Anu & him & ate cake together @ Arrow bar oooh with Icon!!!
:)
Yeah.. & it weas fun!!  'cause there was a period where like i was going
back & forth!!!  Fun Fun!!! :)

So like i was lucky to get a ride home from Entittee & Blazer 'cause they
went back to Sac & even still when i got home.. i was still kinda
sloshed... those Yucca drinks man... that vodka lemonade.. goes a long
fuckin' way./.. but yeah...

Tonight... i did phase 9 of my room renovation!!!  YAAAY.. So Y'all had a
good weekend?

La Vie Bohem man... so Dope!!!



-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)





---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Nicotine Withdrawal

Quitting smoking is something I'm actually rather good at ... I just  
simply lose the desire to smoke.  I've done it several times over my  
life.  Sometimes I just enjoy it a little so I'll have one or two  
rolled Drum, but I've never been a real heavy smoker anyway, so  
quitting is not a big deal for me.


On Nov 18, 2007, at 1:24 AM, pinkko wrote:

> I quit smoking yesterday. Today I made a mix about it. Any of you
> fuckers that have had the experience of quitting smoking can probably
> sympathize with this mix.
>
> http://pestilence.short-b.us/mp3/01%20Nicotine%20Withdrawal%20% 
> 5b11-17-2007%5d.mp3
>
> Running Time: 1:02:24
> Tracklist:
> 01) Audiosex - Kocsma Mafia
> 02) Mi-5 - Red Line
> 03) Current Value - Brainwash (Hidden Memories)
> 04) Limewax - 1/2 Pounds
> 05) Chase & Status - Barbarians
> 06) Cause 4 Concern - Research
> 07) Catacomb - Buried Alive
> 08) Audiosex - Kola Phobia
> 09) Antichristus & Kryptoid - Unknown Pi Sequence
> 10) Bad Company & MC Verse - Antrim
> 11) Chaotech - Gun Talk
> 12) DOC - Tool
> 13) Gremlinz & Friske - Shattered
> 14) Danny Tha Wildchild - Tilt
> 15) Digital - Pickyhead
> 16) Cause 4 Concern - Slimeball

> 19) Skitty - Bare Witness
> 20) Company Truck - Pulverized
> 21) Future Cut - Horns 2000
> 22) John B - Adrenaline
> 23) Universal Project & DJ Friction - Street Life
> 24) Sketch & Code - Snakehead

> 26) Motion - Elements of Truth
> 27) DC Breaks - Laputa

Word. Not wanting to smoke is definitely helpful to quitting. If you
smoke a pack a day or more, though, when you first stop it makes your
brain hurt and you want to strangle people. At least it has for me
every time I've quit.

:-)

Subject: [sfraves] We won't have Paul Oakenfold to kick around anymore....

"I've felt that with DJing, I've achieved everything that you can achieve, from playing stadiums, supporting U2 and Madonna, headlining festivals," he says. "It's very difficult. I played with the Boston Pops about five months ago with a full orchestra, with three-and-a-half thousand people sitting down and just watching me. That was extremely nerve-racking. 

"I do enjoy being a DJ, but I don't enjoy the hassle of travel, and I see myself progressing into film. That's exactly where my head's at and where I want to go."

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] trance again, but seriously

------=_Part_2046_8877569.1195559805771
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I've had an interesting day by all accounts, let's just say that if someone
else (obviously not me) took a lot of shrooms in the early afternoon and
then dropped e once it got dark, they might have a similar experience to
mine.

anyway, I've been listening to one of my favorite mixes of all time, which
incidentally happens to be full out mid-90s rave trance.  Sasha @ Zen
Afterparty (all 6 hours of it) if anyone's interested send me a message
off-list and i'll try to get you a copy somehow.  The point though, I'm
getting to the end of it and it's really epic stuff, but the thing is, I
don't have to be on anything to utterly love this music.  It's so different
than most of today's trance, before they forgot that trance came from house,
when it still had a spirit.  Sasha would be great forever in my mind if this
were his only mix ever, and the music is iconic of both Sasha and the date,
which is what made me think of this.  BS reminiscing aside, it just made me
curious.  What mixes do you look back on and think they're the great mixes
(live sets i mean) of all time?  What are the other sets that specifically
THAT SET defines an artist or a moment in music history?

enough of my post-trip rambling, let's share some good music with each
other.

------=_Part_2046_8877569.1195559805771--

then dropped e once it got dark, they might have a similar experience to
mine.

anyway, I've been listening to one of my favorite mixes of all time, which
incidentally happens to be full out mid-90s rave trance.  Sasha @ Zen
Afterparty (all 6 hours of it) if anyone's interested send me a message
off-list and i'll try to get you a copy somehow.  The point though, I'm
getting to the end of it and it's really epic stuff, but the thing is, I
don't have to be on anything to utterly love this music.  It's so different
than most of today's trance, before they forgot that trance came from house,
when it still had a spirit.  Sasha would be great forever in my mind if this
were his only mix ever, and the music is iconic of both Sasha and the date,
which is what made me think of this.  BS reminiscing aside, it just made me
curious.  What mixes do you look back on and think they're the great mixes
(live sets i mean) of all time?  What are the other sets that specifically
THAT SET defines an artist or a moment in music history?

enough of my post-trip rambling, let's share some good music with each
other.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

YES! =3DD

Unless you make music nowadays, it seems as though getting gigs across the =
US is much harder then it used to be.
I for example, have been playing since 1993 and I found it much easier to g=
et gigs back in 1996 then now.

So i thought, "hey, why not book a DJ that throws a party in a different ci=
ty, and he would return the favor?"

Got trance in your pants, its gonna make you dance.

On 11/20/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> One of my all time favorite mixes is a mix by DJ Scottie Soul.  It was
> recorded at a Stompy party in the mid-nineties and for me captures the
> essence of the SF house sound.  I bought my copy at housewares on Haight
> Street if anyone remembers that place...
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Matthew Johnson <prayformojo524@gmail.com>
> To: sf raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Tuesday, November 20, 2007 3:56:45 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] trance again, but seriously
>
> I've had an interesting day by all accounts, let's just say that if
> someone
> else (obviously not me) took a lot of shrooms in the early afternoon and
> then dropped e once it got dark, they might have a similar experience to
> mine.
>
> anyway, I've been listening to one of my favorite mixes of all time, which
> incidentally happens to be full out mid-90s rave trance.  Sasha @ Zen
> Afterparty (all 6 hours of it) if anyone's interested send me a message
> off-list and i'll try to get you a copy somehow.  The point though, I'm
> getting to the end of it and it's really epic stuff, but the thing is, I
> don't have to be on anything to utterly love this music.  It's so
> different
> than most of today's trance, before they forgot that trance came from
> house,
> when it still had a spirit.  Sasha would be great forever in my mind if
> this
> were his only mix ever, and the music is iconic of both Sasha and the
> date,
> which is what made me think of this.  BS reminiscing aside, it just made
> me
> curious.  What mixes do you look back on and think they're the great mixes
> (live sets i mean) of all time?  What are the other sets that specifically
> THAT SET defines an artist or a moment in music history?
>
> enough of my post-trip rambling, let's share some good music with each
> other.
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me



YES! =D

Unless you make music nowadays, it seems as though getting gigs across the 
US is much harder then it used to be.
I for example, have been playing since 1993 and I found it much easier to 
get gigs back in 1996 then now.

So i thought, "hey, why not book a DJ that throws a party in a different 
city, and he would return the favor?"



Sinestro

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me

That is the MOST disgusting way to get a gig PERIOD.
If you cannot get gigs based on your merits, maybe you
should think about what your merits are.

Gig swapping makes you the laughing stock of the
party. Everyone knows, everyone talks shit about you
behind your back, and it always leads to long-term
shit-canning by whatever scene you are in.

BAD IDEA. Been done by bad Dj's who used their
promoter status to get gigs for years. People love to
hate those that do this.

Mark my words... Or fuck me.... Who cares... But what
you described has been done for years, and always,
wiith maybe a 5% degree of success, turn out as
described.

E

wow bro.

I understand your concern here, however, as Marco can attest, I am a compet=
ent DJ and have been playing
and buying records since 1994.

It is VERY hard to market yourself to promoters nowadays without literally =
begging for gigs, which of course, doesn't do anything for you in the long =
run except getting pegged as "the local DJ". The only alternative is making=
 music, which has never really been my forte. (though I do have a track out=
 on Frankie Bone's label along with another I put out in 96)

So what is a DJ such as myself supposed to do get Promoters in other cities=
 to book me?

By gig swapping, it is possible for me to be able to play in San Fran, or h=
ouston or wherever because a promoter would be willing to have me out witho=
ut risk (I would play for free, promoter would pay for flight), and also ga=
in something. Human nature unfortunatly dictates a "me first" mentality.
I have no idea how I could get a San Fransisco promoter to have me out base=
d on just a mix alone due to me never playing there so I do not have a foll=
owing.

Now you might say put out a national mix cd ala bad boy bill(good example o=
f a dj that rarely produces), but I am also poor. I cannot afford to put ou=
t a mix cd nationally.

Marco? am i wrong here? you know how it is in DC man. Is DC the only city t=
hat is brutal on "the local DJ" phenomenon?
Because I am absolutely open to suggestions on how to get a san fran promot=
er to fly my ass out there to play.

Sinestro

www.rehabrecords.net

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me

Eric you make a good point, but let's also be realistic.  My
experience is that DJs from different crews constantly play at the
parties of promoters whose DJs that they've booked.  It's not usually
an outright verbal/written agreement, but it definitely occurs on an
informal basis.  "Scratch my back and I'll scratch yours."

  I remember I played at a particular DJs party last year.  I later
saw him at one of our parties and he had the nerve to ask, "when are
you going to have me out at one of your parties?"  I This kind of shit
definitely irks me, and I was forced to come up with a white lie to
cover my ass!

On Nov 20, 2007, at 12:45 PM, dj sinestro wrote:

>
> wow bro.
>
> I understand your concern here, however, as Marco can attest, I am a =20=

> competent DJ and have been playing
> and buying records since 1994.
>
> It is VERY hard to market yourself to promoters nowadays without =20
> literally begging for gigs, which of course, doesn't do anything for =20=

> you in the long run except getting pegged as "the local DJ". The =20
> only alternative is making music, which has never really been my =20
> forte. (though I do have a track out on Frankie Bone's label along =20
> with another I put out in 96)
>
> So what is a DJ such as myself supposed to do get Promoters in other =20=

> cities to book me?
>
> By gig swapping, it is possible for me to be able to play in San =20
> Fran, or houston or wherever because a promoter would be willing to =20=

> have me out without risk (I would play for free, promoter would pay =20=

> for flight), and also gain something. Human nature unfortunatly =20
> dictates a "me first" mentality.
> I have no idea how I could get a San Fransisco promoter to have me =20
> out based on just a mix alone due to me never playing there so I do =20=

> not have a following.
>
> Now you might say put out a national mix cd ala bad boy bill(good =20
> example of a dj that rarely produces), but I am also poor. I cannot =20=

> afford to put out a mix cd nationally.
>
> Marco? am i wrong here? you know how it is in DC man. Is DC the only =20=

> city that is brutal on "the local DJ" phenomenon?
> Because I am absolutely open to suggestions on how to get a san fran =20=

> promoter to fly my ass out there to play.

Same thing happens here in DC Ben
It definitly is informal but kind of understood.

I just don't see a way for the "mid level" Dj's to get out besides making m=
usic.
Scott Henry is considered to be one of the forefathers of the techno scene =
here on the east coast. No one can argue that he has thrown out some dope a=
ss sets. but, if he were to start dj'ing nowadays, he would be opening for =
headliners at local parties and playing the after parties because he has ne=
ver made a track.

I guess I'm just at a loss as to how to market myself to promoters across t=
he US, since all I have to offer is the ability to rock a party.


Sinestro

>=20
> Eric you make a good point, but let's also be realistic.  My
> experience is that DJs from different crews constantly play at the
> parties of promoters whose DJs that they've booked.  It's not usually
> an outright verbal/written agreement, but it definitely occurs on an
> informal basis.  "Scratch my back and I'll scratch yours."
>=20
>   I remember I played at a particular DJs party last year.  I later
> saw him at one of our parties and he had the nerve to ask, "when are
> you going to have me out at one of your parties?"  I This kind of shit
> definitely irks me, and I was forced to come up with a white lie to
> cover my ass!
>=20
>=20
>=20

> > competent DJ and have been playing
> > and buying records since 1994.
> >
> > It is VERY hard to market yourself to promoters nowadays without =20
> > literally begging for gigs, which of course, doesn't do anything for =20
> > you in the long run except getting pegged as "the local DJ". The =20
> > only alternative is making music, which has never really been my =20
> > forte. (though I do have a track out on Frankie Bone's label along =20
> > with another I put out in 96)
> >
> > So what is a DJ such as myself supposed to do get Promoters in other =20
> > cities to book me?
> >
> > By gig swapping, it is possible for me to be able to play in San =20
> > Fran, or houston or wherever because a promoter would be willing to =20
> > have me out without risk (I would play for free, promoter would pay =20
> > for flight), and also gain something. Human nature unfortunatly =20
> > dictates a "me first" mentality.
> > I have no idea how I could get a San Fransisco promoter to have me =20
> > out based on just a mix alone due to me never playing there so I do =20
> > not have a following.
> >
> > Now you might say put out a national mix cd ala bad boy bill(good =20
> > example of a dj that rarely produces), but I am also poor. I cannot =20

> > have me out without risk (I would play for free, promoter would pay =20
> > for flight), and also gain something. Human nature unfortunatly =20
> > dictates a "me first" mentality.
> > I have no idea how I could get a San Fransisco promoter to have me =20
> > out based on just a mix alone due to me never playing there so I do =20
> > not have a following.
> >
> > Now you might say put out a national mix cd ala bad boy bill(good =20
> > example of a dj that rarely produces), but I am also poor. I cannot =20
> > afford to put out a mix cd nationally.

I wouldn't rain on his parade that much. I think gig swapping is a great 
idea...and Sinestro is well worth it. But it's in my experience that most 
people don't want folks invading their territory, let alone swapping gigs 
for the chance to play elsewhere when they can be big fish in their own 
small sea.

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 20 Nov 2007 22:12:01.0238 (UTC) FILETIME=[5FE25F60:01C82BC2]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me

Be patient and wait till I have the spare pocket change to do it. I am 
thinking in March...throwing myself a birthday gig and booking whoever the 
fuck I please.

If people come out and see you, most likely you'll get opportunities to play 
again.

Problem is, there are nine billion DJ's in SF, and everyone is scrambling 
for gigs here, so having a lesser known out of towner come in is a slim and 
none proposition. The only ways I see out of towners getting booked is:

1. If they are a headliner with a following.
2. They have enough local fans to warrant a booking.
3. A promoter has enough disposable money to take a chance on you and 
actually wants to.
4. They have some amazing "thing" (or event) to offer the person you are 
trying to appeal to. And even then, unless the gig is some massive 
networking opportunity or banging, super well known weekly/regular event - 
you are lucky to even get a reply.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "dj sinestro" <djsinestro@hotmail.com>
To: "Eric Spire" <ericspire@yahoo.com>; "Marco" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, November 20, 2007 12:45 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me



wow bro.

I understand your concern here, however, as Marco can attest, I am a 
competent DJ and have been playing
and buying records since 1994.

It is VERY hard to market yourself to promoters nowadays without literally 
begging for gigs, which of course, doesn't do anything for you in the long 
run except getting pegged as "the local DJ". The only alternative is making 
music, which has never really been my forte. (though I do have a track out 
on Frankie Bone's label along with another I put out in 96)

So what is a DJ such as myself supposed to do get Promoters in other cities 
to book me?

By gig swapping, it is possible for me to be able to play in San Fran, or 
houston or wherever because a promoter would be willing to have me out 
without risk (I would play for free, promoter would pay for flight), and 
also gain something. Human nature unfortunatly dictates a "me first" 
mentality.
I have no idea how I could get a San Fransisco promoter to have me out based 
on just a mix alone due to me never playing there so I do not have a 
following.

Now you might say put out a national mix cd ala bad boy bill(good example of 
a dj that rarely produces), but I am also poor. I cannot afford to put out a 
mix cd nationally.

Marco? am i wrong here? you know how it is in DC man. Is DC the only city 
that is brutal on "the local DJ" phenomenon?
Because I am absolutely open to suggestions on how to get a san fran 
promoter to fly my ass out there to play.

Sinestro

------------------------------------------------------------

I like large posteriors and I cannot prevaricate.
www.rehabrecords.net

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Ben Haus" <benhaus@gmail.com>
To: "Eric Spire" <ericspire@yahoo.com>
Cc: "Marco" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, November 20, 2007 12:46 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me


Eric you make a good point, but let's also be realistic.  My
experience is that DJs from different crews constantly play at the
parties of promoters whose DJs that they've booked.  It's not usually
an outright verbal/written agreement, but it definitely occurs on an
informal basis.  "Scratch my back and I'll scratch yours."

  I remember I played at a particular DJs party last year.  I later
saw him at one of our parties and he had the nerve to ask, "when are
you going to have me out at one of your parties?"  I This kind of shit
definitely irks me, and I was forced to come up with a white lie to
cover my ass!



On Nov 20, 2007 12:34 PM, Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com> wrote:
> That is the MOST disgusting way to get a gig PERIOD.

> should think about what your merits are.

> behind your back, and it always leads to long-term

Message-Id: <4751EF82-8CDD-4003-81F6-8A62F94AC84D@mac.com>
From: Henry E Kielarowski <djapollo2k@mac.com>
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary=Apple-Mail-3-396588858
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v912)
Date: Tue, 20 Nov 2007 15:00:37 -0800
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.912)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Jeno:  Savage Innocence - a special dedication - tonight in the VOID..

--Apple-Mail-3-396588858
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed;
	delsp=yes
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Savage Innocence - a special dedication - tonight in the VOID..
Date & Time: 2007-11-20 9:00 PM

Tonight's show is dedicated to my old friend Ghandi, who died on  
Friday. I'm not going to make it back to England for the funeral, but  
I figure spinning some music in his honor is the next best thing I can  
do...



I hadn't actually seen the guy for quite some time, our life's taking  
quite different paths before I came out to the States. But during my  
late teens and early twenties he was a close friend, a great  
inspiration, and a fellow traveller on the unconventional backroads of  
life. From the anarcho-punk scene, through animal rights actions, to  
exploring the free spirit of the 80's psychedelic festival circuit -  
he, I and our close knit group of friends did alot of very intense,  
fun and perhaps at times foolish things together. But that's what  
living is all about, isn't it. Of all of us he was the most sweet,  
innocent and likeable, yet had a wild and curious streak that took him  
down some murky paths. After 20 years of battling mental problems and  
drug addiction he finally decided he'd had enough and threw himself  
under a train at Kings Cross Station in London. May his once tortured  
soul now rest easy..

My memories of him are nearly all happy and joyful, so don't expect a  
morose show tonight - I'll simply be spinning some good music as a  
celebration of all the wonderful things that he brought into our lives  
during the crazy times we spent together..

And lastly I'm also gonna dedicate the show to Kevin, Saul and Pete, 3  
other close former friends of mine from that same era, who didn't make  
it this far either..



go to 90hz.org to listen and chat
Posted by: Jeno
--Apple-Mail-3-396588858--

------=_Part_23847_32138187.1195602435067
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=WINDOWS-1252
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Great topic. Sinestro, I completely hear where you are coming from and I
respect that you want to create working relationships with folks on the Wes=
t
Coast.

I think that could naturally happen through investing in relationships and
creating some positive synergies around new styles of music or an intention
to create a certain party concept from coast to coast.

My feeling about this whole thing is (and I'll try to be as general about
this as possible to avoid any finger pointing), that unless you have a grea=
t
natural working relationship and similar goals and visions of how parties
should look, feel and sound, or a lot of trust and comeraderie or other
things at stake that warrant this arrangement....don't swap DJ gigs, and
even then, don't swap...make it a natural cycle of working together.

Booking anybody who promises anything in return, or worst, bowing to any
pressure, bribing or politics whatsoever is unadvisable and just plain
stupid. It only feeds the Dj mafia mentality and stains the ecosystem with
crappy and unworthy Djs or producers who gang up on others and attempt to
dominate a scene through power-plays or false pretenses.

-Jennifer/Solekandi

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area shoot me in the FACE please

SO I will offer my advice since I offered my opinion
on the topic... 

I always hated self promotion. It made me feel dirty.
How can you not feel gross about basically telling
someone you are great?

So, here is how I dealt with it....

1) Someone else told people I was great... lol... the
seperation is both professional and an ease on the
soul. Most important though, the person needs to
believe it and be an advocte rather than a jabbering
mouthpiece.

2) Never play for free if you are looking to increase
your presence. Think of it like this... you put an old
sofa on the front porch that says free. It sits there
for a month and no one takes it. The next day, you put
a for sale sign on, and someone steals it. There is
some psychological thing that goes on where people
appreciate more the things they pay for, and bizarre
as it is, promoters will often promote YOU harder the
more they pay, as the price they are paying directly
relates to the value they place on you as a performer

3) Never carry your records around to clubs in hopes
that if someone does not show you can take their
place. May get you a turn at the decks, but less
respect from the promoter, and the expectation that
you are always a freebie.

4) Make a professional promo pack and MAIL it to
people. For locals and long distance gigs. EMAIL
carries less weight if any...This will help you to
meet and greet promoters, gather a database, and be
social. Being seen out and about is important for your
local presence. 

5) Promo pack should be simple. A LOGO on a single
page. A third person description of your style, some
gigs you have played, and ONE or TWO headliners you
have played WITH... not just at the same event, but on
the same stage. Do not load your list up with 1000
names from one massive you played, this just demotes
everything. Include a few attractive flyers where you
are prevalently listed. Oh yeah... and a
PROFESSIONALLY made CD of you mixing. It should be
perfect without exception.

6) DO NOT TALK SHIT ABOUT ANYONE! If you want to make
it, your opinion about other DJ's, promoters, sound
guys, and "important scenesters" needs never be
uttered. Not to your girl, to your bbest friend to
anyone... as soon  as there is a fight with them, all
of a sudden a newbie is on every message board outing
you and your opinions.

7) It takes as much effort to gety gigs, remain
humble, track your mailings, collect music, market
yourself, etc.... as a full time job... That time will
realize you the success you want, but don't think you
deserve anything, and don't expect anything other than
what you put out in effort.

8) If you are trying to get your first out of town
gigs, might I suggest that you offer to play for a
fee, that only covers your expenses. Do 10 minutes of
research in advance, find cheap flights, a motel 6,
add them up, and present an offer that covers food and
travel. With the caveate that you do not make a big
deal about giving travel for free... you'll just be
there and there is nothing to worry about.

9) locally and when travelling, send promo materials
to local newspapers, LIKE metro, not the big ones, try
to get your music reviewed in them, do college radio
shows etc... have local websites host your mixes 
before your gigs, etc... Hearing your name on the
radio, and more so IN PRINT, brings instant
recognition for no reason other than it makes the idea
of you as a HEADLINER more real, and that is what you
are going for.

Thats about it.... More work than you will get in gigs
for a couple of years, but will pay off in the future,
and most importantly, long-term.

NEVER BE AN ASSHOLE PRIMADONA ROCKSTAR!!!!

E



      ____________________________________________________________________________________

leaving out any subjective opinion on the topic, here is a link that addresses your original inquiry: http://djgigexchange.tribe.net

marco's right though, the challenge is that there are already a million DJs in san francisco - many of them skilled - so there's not much incentive to book a random out of town performer.

good luck!

love,
mo

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me

They will never take you as a client. And that isn't a
rip on you... they just won't.

Honestly, until you are bookable, all that getting an
agent will do is have them book someone above you on
the roster if anyone ever calls for you.

Make your own mini-team first. A girlfriend to return
phone calls. A couple of email addresses to respond
from, etc... Make your phone ring.... Respond
pleasantly to emails yourself, finishing that a call
from "person X" will follow shortly to discuss
details... You get names and numbers, remain the nice
guy, and appear professional.

E

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area please contact me

Thats hilarious... I left out all those names to
remain nuetral...

I booked all of them for the trance hysteria they were
involved in... but mostly to keep anyone else from
being able to throw a party against QUEST. Politics.

I never played for any of them... Except for Greg
Sandler once, he called the office booked me with no
swapping... Gave me great billing on the flyer, and
had me play at 8 pm in the downstairs bar at the
maritime hall to no-one. I think he was trying to put
me in my place because I would not gig-swap with
him... it was very wierd, but he paid me, and it was
my job to be professional, so went out to dinner and
was home by 1 am... 

But that is a comprehensive list of the biggest
gig-swappers. Notice that as their promoter presence
left the scene so did theiur gigging... That is not a
coincidence.... And without naming which ones, they
are all (or maybe it is some of them, or two... no
three... hmmm) hated in one form or another.

Slik-E-Loot = We are slik, we sell E, and we make
loot. And our names are in our name too. YEAH... Look
I have dreads. That means I'm a hippy full of love.
Oh, and my arpeggiator writes songs for me. He's my
best friend. I call him Arp-E... get it? 

"Me neither, Ho go home and wash out your beaver" or
your dreads...

E

Agreed to some of that kinda.... But... If you are
looking for more than a quick booking, how you are
viewed by others, which includes how you come about
bookings is HUGE in the future effect...

Its the difference between a one night stand and long
term relationship. 

Gig Swapping is a one night stand.

E
--- Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote:

> Eric you make a good point, but let's also be
> realistic.  My
> experience is that DJs from different crews
> constantly play at the
> parties of promoters whose DJs that they've booked. 
> It's not usually
> an outright verbal/written agreement, but it
> definitely occurs on an
> informal basis.  "Scratch my back and I'll scratch
> yours."
> 
>   I remember I played at a particular DJs party last
> year.  I later
> saw him at one of our parties and he had the nerve
> to ask, "when are
> you going to have me out at one of your parties?"  I
> This kind of shit
> definitely irks me, and I was forced to come up with
> a white lie to
> cover my ass!

  ----- Original Message -----=20
  From: filter.sf@gmail.com=20
  To: Marco=20
  Cc: dj sinestro ; Chris Jackson ; Eric Spire ; sfraves@hyperreal.org=20
  Sent: Tuesday, November 20, 2007 3:47 PM
  Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area shoot me in the FACE =
please


  Great topic. Sinestro, I completely hear where you are coming from and =
I respect that you want to create working relationships with folks on =
the West Coast.=20

  I think that could naturally happen through investing in relationships =
and creating some positive synergies around new styles of music or an =
intention to create a certain party concept from coast to coast.=20

  My feeling about this whole thing is (and I'll try to be as general =
about this as possible to avoid any finger pointing), that unless you =
have a great natural working relationship and similar goals and visions =
of how parties should look, feel and sound, or a lot of trust and =
comeraderie or other things at stake that warrant this =
arrangement....don't swap DJ gigs, and even then, don't swap...make it a =
natural cycle of working together.=20

  Booking anybody who promises anything in return, or worst, bowing to =
any pressure, bribing or politics whatsoever is unadvisable and just =
plain stupid. It only feeds the Dj mafia mentality and stains the =
ecosystem with crappy and unworthy Djs or producers who gang up on =
others and attempt to dominate a scene through power-plays or false =
pretenses. =20

  -Jennifer/Solekandi

    that has influenced a TON of other DC/Bmore locals, and deserving of =
some
    party rokcin' out here...

    If you can help w/. promoter contact, hook him up!!!=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area shoot me in the FACE please

I'd say that covers most events I have been to here....

The sad thing is, if y'all knew Sinestro like I know him, offering him this 
advice would seem ludicrous. He was one of the forerunners in the DC area 
for YEARS. Has been peer and played alongside folks like John Acquaviva, 
Frankie Bones, Peter Tall, etc.

This is a DJ's dj to be certain...and it's sad that the state of the EDM 
scene is such that a guy like him almost has to start from scratch in order 
to get the recognition he deserves.

Yes, I am biased....but if you all knew this kid like I do, you'd be 
agreeing 100%.

My how things have changed....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Promoters in the SF Area shoot me in the FACE please

Whatever happened to playing music simply for the love of playing music?

Trying to get famous by playing music just pollutes it. That's why you
feel dirty when you promote yourself.

But then, I guess that's why I'll never be a headliner, or get many
gigs, I don't have the stomach for the politics of it, and the
whoredom it requires.

That's aight, though, I can live with that, and the gigs I do play
I'll play for free (like it should be) and with as much heart as I can
muster.

On that note, Imma go play some dnb.

:-)

now he's the father of 14 kids.  Danny works 4 more jobs to support his
family!!!

But he wants everyone to know that he misses the Bay Area lots.. he'll try
to be here again some time w/in the next few months if all the vacations
from his jobs happen @ the same time or he can work out some kinda groovy
schedule.. ummmmm.. but yeah... mainly he misses everyone.. him the &
Misters & the Misseses & the kids are all fine!!  He Loves You guys too!!!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

11/22: THURSDAY
Phonic Part Deux: Dirty Dirty Techno
DJs: Alland Byallo, Chris Galvin, Shaun Reeves
The End Up: 401 Sixth Street, SF
Cover: TBA

11/23: FRIDAY
DEF's Radio Integrated
http://www.zer01.net:1200/
8pm-10pm: Namenschanz with Chel-C Faith
10pm-12am: DJ set by DJ STML

11/23: FRIDAY
Sick at Matador
Friday night techno with DJs: D. Spurlock, Jeffrey Allen, Johnathan Neil,
Kuze, Meekrob
Matador
10 6th St, SF
No Cover

11/24: SATURDAY
Ame + Dixon
with Tokyo Component, Hakobo
Pink :2925 16th St
Cover $15

11/24: SATURDAY
Simple Saturdays presents: Radio Slave
With DJs: Scott Carrelli, Kevin Knapp
Anu - 46 Sixth St, SF
Cover $10

:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
Coming up next week:

11/29 THURSDAY: Stap[e presents Sabbotage with Tres Manos from Barcelona and
DJs Fil Latorre and Javaight
Anu - 46 Sixth St.

11/30 FRIDAY: ::Filter:: presents Brooklyn's David Last
[Goosehound/Foundsound] Live plus Live PA by Kontakt + Solekandi.
Anu: 46 Sixth St
Cover: free before 11, $5 after

12/1 SATURDAY: [Kontrol] at the End Up with Alex Smoke, Samim and Lee
Curtiss with residents: Craig Kuna, Alland Byallo, Sammy D. and Nikola
Baytala
The End Up: 401 Sixth Street, SF
Cover: free before 11, $15 after

Welp!

I'm down here at my friend Buehler's house spending Thanksgiving.  He =20
lives down here in Wilmington, NC with his wife and Rrrowrreeeeguez.  =20
This is actually the second time I've come down here in a week and it =20
looks like I'm coming down at least twice more for various reasons =20
relating to travel and I'm installing one of those DVD navigation =20
systems in my Jetta.

Oh by the way, we both bought the Turbonator, which is like the =20
Tornado, on our cars, and he really notices the difference in his '03 =20
Passat.  I looked under the hood of that thing, it's got the 30V V6, =20
we're both amazed at how they're able to fit all that stuff in there.  =20
Oh yea, I also bought and installed this gas treatment from, none =20
other than, SFR Technologies, it's supposed to improve gas mileage, =20
but I didn't really notice anything there.  The Turbonator is supposed =20
to too, and improve power, I did notice less turbo lag and more meat =20
in the acceleration.  So we'll see about that.

By the way, the GTI is doing fine and my friend Proctor is driving it =20
around and is going to hopefully drive it up to New York.  It's =20
inevitable that car will get into a garage for a major overhaul.

So now that I got my talking about cars thing out of the way, Happy =20
Thanksgiving to all SFRavers and here's a quote from George Carlin to =20
soothe you during your holiday travels.

DF

--

Airport security is a stupid idea, it's a waste of money, and it's only
there for one reason:

To make WHITE people feel safe, to placate the middle class. Because the
authorities know they can't keep everything COMPLETELY safe; too many people
have access......You notice the drug smugglers have no problem getting their
little packages on board? No, and god bless them too!

- George Carlin

>and reached way in there to get something and it was apparently on top
>of a bag and my face brushed the bag.  Ouch, very random.


Ouch !!- I once had a yellowjacket jump onto a piece of sausage
on its way into my mouth - I never say the yellowjacket until
it stung me INSIDE my cheek - you have my total empathy -
and why aren't you at Walmart, too ?? (Fortunately for me -
Target doesn't open until 6)

This is a shout out to those who partied with me at
homebase, the crack house, and various underground
parties in the bay area.  Those who mingled and made
memories with people whom they can't remember the
names of for the life of them. 

Im a youngster when it comes to the scene, partied
from '98 thru 2005.  Travelled, got married, bought a
house, grew up too soon. 

I need a good house party to go to.  I need a drum and
bass party to go to (particularly techstep).  I
especially need folks who have been thru what I have
been thru.

Those who have graduated and taken that step forward
to another life, but still remember the eed out nights
and acid laced memories that made us who we are.

holler at me.

cuz Im a bay area junglist, house head, trance head
thats been through it all.

and fuck the haters.

Subject: [sfraves] [SRR] what I am thankful for

------=_Part_4226_18531523.1195899925043
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

In the beginning, there was Jack, and Jack had a groove.
And from this groove came the groove of all grooves.
And while one day viciously throwing down on his box, Jack boldy declared,

"Let there be house!" and house music was born.

I am, you see,
I am the creator, and this is my house!
And, in my house there is only house music. But, I am not so
selfish because once you enter my house it then becomes OUR house and
OUR house music!" And, you see, no one can own house because
*house music is a universal language, spoken and understood by all*.

You see, house is a feeling that no one can understand really unless
you're deep into the vibe of house. House is an uncontrollable
desire to jack your body. And, as I told you before, this is
our house and our house music. And in every house, you
understand, there is a keeper. And, in this house, the keeper
is Jack. Now some of you who might wonder.

Who is Jack, and what is it that Jack does?

Jack is the one who gives you the power to jack your body!
Jack is the one who gives you the power to do the snake.
Jack is the one who gives you the key to the wiggly worm.
Jack is the one who learns you how to walk your body.
Jack is the one that can bring nations and nations of all
Jackers together under one house.

You may be black, you may be white; you may be Jew or Gentile.
It don't make difference in our House.

And this is fresh!

------=_Part_4226_18531523.1195899925043--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I WANNA GET DIRTY!!!

Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY
Saturday, December 1st, 2007
Fat City (314 11th st. @ Folsom)
10pm-4am
21+

$10 presales: http://groovetickets.com/ordersystem/groove/eventviewqb.asp?A=
ffilID=3D93&EventsID=3D34375&PGname=3DEvil%20Breaks
$10 b4 11pm & $15 after


It's been a long time since we've had Uberzone play at one of our
shows (Dec. '05), and it's been even longer since Uberzone has
released a full-length album (2001). And during the past few years,
there have been quite a few of us waiting very impatiently for another
album. 6 years later, Ideology has been releaseed, and we are finally
getting some new music out of Q, and let me tell you, it was worth the
wait!!!

Evil Breaks does it right once again with Uberzone playing LIVE along
with Davey Dave at what is San Francisco's CD release party for the
long awaited new album from Uberzone. We'll also be giving away a few
of the new cd's as well as a bunch of other freebies. Check back here
later, or sign up our mailing list to get all the info on that as we
figure it out.

If that isn't enough, we also have an amazing producer coming out from
the East Coast to do a little live set for us (you are not ready for
this), along with the Ambient Mafia in the back room, Viberation doing
visuals, and the E.B. dj's owning the main room like they tend to do
at E.B. parties. I don't know about you, but it sounds like fun to
me.......


Uberzone LIVE with Davey Dave

Nitrus / City of Angels / Astralwerks / TCR / L.A.
SF Ideology Album release party

Uberzone is the brainchild of southern California native Q (named
after the "gizmo" -loving James Bond character). Like his namesake, Q
is a die-hard collector of all things electronic, and has been
collecting electronic-music gear since his early teens.

His early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on taste-maker
indie dance label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed club
tracks that established Q as one of the leading American producers of
breakbeat music. These singles were charted consistently by DJs like
Florida's DJ Icey and the UK's Adam Freeland, among others. His
remixes of Sarah McLachlan, The Crystal Method and BT also established
him as one of the biggest names in the American dance scene. Spin
Magazine named Uberzone as one of the six producers to create "the
biggest beats ever." Q does have Faith in the Future. "Sometime during
my life I turned from a pessimist into an optimist. Faith in the
Future ties into technology, electronic music and my lasting desire to
live in the Jetson Age." Perhaps that's why Uberzone's debut album,
"Faith in the Future" has a feeling to it unlike any other electronic
album. It recalls influences from quirky sci-fantasy film soundtracks
to "Planet Rock" to dream-pop to the energetic, future breaks that
Uberzone has created in ways no one else can approach.


J.Hazen
Sound of Habib / Virus B-23 / System Rec / NY

For quite a few years now this guy has been producing the wickedest
beats, but would never perform. After a bunch of badgering, some good
intentioned insults, and a few 3rd party threats, we're finally able
to bring out what I consider to be, one of the most talented producers
in the U.S. Although he's just recently had his 1st couple of official
releases, his tracks have been rockin parties around the world for
years. And to top it off, he's going to be performing a live set for
us!!

Check out a mix J.Hazen did for the "6th & Fairfax" radio show on
Bijoubreaks. This mix definitely shows his diversity & ability to
flawlessly mix a wide range of sounds and genres. He has promised to
bring the HEAT, for his first West Coast performance, so ya best be
ready for some slammin beats.......You've been warned.
http://www.bijoubeats.com/sets/J%20Hazen%20-%206th%20&%20Fairfax%20Mix%20-%=
20May%202007.mp3

Just got another mix from J.Hazen. Recorded Live on Halloween, this
set is being dubbed the "Zombie Prom" mix.
http://www.soundofhabib.net/audio/j_hazen-zombie_prom_set.mp3

To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Uberzone, J Hazen, and more! - Saturday night!

Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY
Saturday, December 1st, 2007
Fat City (314 11th st. @ Folsom)
10pm-4am
21+

$10 presales:
http://groovetickets.com/ordersystem/groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=34375&PGname=Evil%20Breaks
$10 b4 11pm & $15 after


It's been a long time since we've had Uberzone play at one of our shows
(Dec. '05), and it's been even longer since Uberzone has released a
full-length album (2001). And during the past few years, there have been
quite a few of us waiting very impatiently for another album. 6 years later,
Ideology has been released, and we are finally getting some new music out of
Q, and let me tell you, it was worth the wait!!!

Evil Breaks does it right once again with Uberzone playing LIVE along with
Davey Dave at what is San Francisco's CD release party for the long awaited
new album from Uberzone. We'll also be giving away a few of the new cd's as
well as a bunch of other freebies. Check back here later, or sign up for our
mailing list to get all the info on that.

If that isn't enough, we also have an amazing producer coming out from the
East Coast to do a little live set for us (you are not ready for this),
along with the Ambient Mafia in the back room, Viberation doing visuals, and
the E.B. dj's owning the main room like they tend to do. I don't know about
you, but it sounds like fun to me.......



Uberzone LIVE with Davey Dave
(Nitrus / City of Angels / Astralwerks / TCR / L.A.)
SF Ideology Album release party

His early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on taste-maker indie
dance label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed club tracks that
established Q as one of the leading American producers of breakbeat music.
These singles were charted consistently by DJs like Florida's DJ Icey and
the UK's Adam Freeland, among others. His remixes of Sarah McLachlan, The
Crystal Method and BT also established him as one of the biggest names in
the American dance scene. Spin Magazine named Uberzone as one of the six
producers to create "the biggest beats ever." Q does have Faith in the
Future. "Sometime during my life I turned from a pessimist into an optimist.
Faith in the Future ties into technology, electronic music and my lasting
desire to live in the Jetson Age." Perhaps that's why Uberzone's debut
album, "Faith in the Future" has a feeling to it unlike any other electronic
album. It recalls influences from quirky sci-fantasy film soundtracks to
"Planet Rock" to dream-pop to the energetic, future breaks that Uberzone has
created in ways no one else can approach.


J.Hazen
(Sound of Habib / Virus B-23 / System Rec / NY)

For quite a few years now this guy has been producing the wickedest beats,
but would never perform. After a bunch of badgering, some good intentioned
insults, and a few 3rd party threats, we're finally able to bring out what I
consider to be, one of the most talented producers in the U.S. Although he's
just recently had his 1st couple of official releases, his tracks have been
rockin parties around the world for years. And to top it off, he's going to
be performing a live set for us!!

Check out a mix from J.Hazen. Recorded Live on Halloween, this set is being
dubbed the "Zombie Prom" mix. This one's nice and bouncy.....YEEEAAAH!!!!
http://www.soundofhabib.net/audio/j_hazen-zombie_prom_set.mp3


In the Evil Breaks room:

Bam vs. Icon
Aaron Jae
M.O.D.
Athena


In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:

Calamity Jane
Seventh Swami
Speakeasy Ray
Hickory
Sixty4k

mixes, more info, more stuff:
www.EvilBreaks.com <http://www.evilbreaks.com/>

Curtiss [live] with residents: Craig Kuna, Alland Byallo, Sammy D. and
Nikola Baytala
The End Up: 401 Sixth Street, SF
Cover: free before 11, $15 after

TBA.

10-2
No Cover

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: I Wash My TV in Fear

http://www.zebbler.com/friends/iwashmytvinfear/iwashmytvinfear.html

"People's expectations have been so infantilized by television that the infantilation has itself disposed us to a genocide...My belief is that the constant exposure to news, the constant exposure of the viewer sensibilities to those planes flying into those buildings explains our involvement in Iraq. We wanted to be exposed to an absolutely different show (than the World Trade Center towers falling)...But we were promised a 12-episode miniseries. We'd go in, pull down a statue and it'd be over. Now we want to get out because we want the series to be over...It's the reason I believe the argument that the next time such a (terrorist) event takes place, we'll commit a genocide. We'll sanction the murder of men, women and children, the incarceration of Muslims the way we did the Japanese (during World War II.)"

-- David Milch

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Kontakt Live P.A. on An Epiphany Of Sound today

This morning Kontakt will be playing a preview of a LIVE PA set 
entitled: "The Soft Whip" :: on An Epiphany of Sound.

"The Soft Whip" is based on 22 original tracks produced as part of the 
duo Kontakt + Solekandi comprised of Yanni Ehm and his wife Jennifer.

The full version of "The Soft Whip" will be performed at Friday night's 
Filter event at Anu featuring Brooklyn's David Last, who records on 
minimalist-techno labels Foundsound, Wolf + Lamb Music and Goosehound.

Kontakt's debut track "Slith" is available for free download at 
Pertin-nce.com [P13] as a part of the "Changes" series.

Be sure to listen in!  We're on air at 90.1 FM in the bay area as well 
as streaming online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Namaste.

Message-ID: <6a557de00711291623q5dca2985r44941b6088082406@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Thu, 29 Nov 2007 16:23:05 -0800
From: Mark <vileru@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; 
	boundary="----=_Part_11821_16196117.1196382185898"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Suntrip Records: Anyone else?

------=_Part_11821_16196117.1196382185898
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It's not beer-trance, it's not coke-trance, nor is it meth-trance. IT'S GOA
TRANCE!!!

I'm not sure how many goaheads are on this list, but has anyone else been
following this label? Everything that these guys touch is gold. Not one bad
release! Goa trance was dead for a while, but these guys have proven that
604 can still rip apart a dancefloor. Call me a fanboy, but I just ordered
their new release by Goasia - From Other Spaces, and I've been checking my
mail daily in unbearable anticipation. I'm not some undercover promoter or
whatever, but if any of you out there loved those classic Hallucinogen,
Astral Projection, Dimension 5 (they actually released a remastered version
of D5's ultra-rare album Transdimensional; the kickdrums are nuts and the
sound is much crisper, while stile retaining those fat and juicy synths),
Koxbox, and Etnica/Pleiadians albums, then I strongly recommend that you
check out what Suntrip has to offer.

Anyways, here's a general idea of the styles of their album releases:

Filteria - sounds like Pleiadians for the 21st century; definite head
spinning material
Khetzal - extremely Eastern influenced, organic goa
Ka-Sol - forest goa (think Battle of the Future Buddhas)
Goasia - we'll see once the album arrives :)

For the interested: http://www.discogs.com/label/Suntrip+Records

P.S. If any of you guys love and remember the album To Sirius by Ra, then
you're in luck. He will be releasing a new album on Suntrip, BADASS!
P.P.S. If you disagree that goa trance can kill a dancefloor, then think
again. Usually wedding parties are tame, yes? Not with goa trance! Check it
out: http://youtube.com/watch?v=vVQmxzc03uA&feature=related

MIME-Version: 1.0

	boundary="----=_Part_12456_15232396.1196395336340"

Subject: [sfraves] Suntrip Records Fans: Anyone Else?

------=_Part_12456_15232396.1196395336340
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Hmm, my last message didn't seem to go through, so I'll try again. Sorry if
this went out twice...

It's not drunk-trance, it's not coke-trance, nor is it tweaked-trance. IT'S
GOA TRANCE!!!

I'm not sure how many goaheads are on this list, but has anyone else been
following this label? Everything that these guys touch is gold. Not one bad
release! Goa trance was dead for a while, but these guys have proven that
604 can still rip apart a dancefloor. Call me a fanboy, but I just ordered
their new release by Goasia - From Other Spaces, and I've been checking my
mail daily in unbearable anticipation. I'm not some undercover promoter or
whatever, but if any of you out there loved the classic Hallucinogen, Astral
Projection, Dimension 5 (they actually released a remastered version of D5's
ultra-rare album Transdimensional; the kickdrums are nuts and the sound is
much crisper, while stile retaining those fat and juicy synths), Koxbox, and
Etnica/Pleiadians albums, then I strongly recommend that you check out what
Suntrip has to offer.

Anyways, here's a general idea of the styles of their album releases:

Filteria - sounds like Pleiadians for the 21st century; definite head
spinning material
Khetzal - extremely Eastern influenced, organic goa
Ka-Sol - forest goa (think Battle of the Future Buddhas)
Goasia - we'll see once the album arrives :)

For the interested: http://www.discogs.com/label/Suntrip+Records

P.S. If any of you guys love and remember the album To Sirius by Ra, then
you're in luck. He will be releasing a new album on Suntrip, BADASS!
P.P.S. If you disagree that goa trance can kill a dancefloor, then think
again. Usually wedding parties are tame, yes? Not with goa trance! Check it
out: http://youtube.com/watch?v=vVQmxzc03uA&feature=related

------=_Part_12456_15232396.1196395336340--

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY - Timeslots for Saturday!

In the Evil Breaks room:

10-11 Athena
11-12 M.O.D.
12-1 J.Hazen
1-2 Uberzone LIVE w/Davey Dave
2-3 Aaron Jae
3-4 Bam vs. Icon


In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:

11-12 Hickory
12-1 Speakeasy Ray
1-2 Seventh Swami
2-3 Sixty4k (ambient)
3-4 Harken vs. Actual Rafiq (ambient)

--
Uberzone live in SF - Saturday

Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY
Saturday, December 1st, 2007
Fat City (314 11th st. @ Folsom)
10pm-4am
21+

$10 presales:
http://groovetickets.com/ordersystem/groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=34375&PGname=Evil%20Breaks
$10 b4 11pm & $15 after


It's been a long time since we've had Uberzone play at one of our
shows (Dec. '05), and it's been even longer since Uberzone has
released a full-length album (2001). And during the past few years,
there have been quite a few of us waiting very impatiently for another
album. 6 years later, Ideology has been released, and we are finally
getting some new music out of Q, and let me tell you, it was worth the
wait!!!

Evil Breaks does it right once again with Uberzone playing LIVE along
with Davey Dave at what is San Francisco's CD release party for the
long awaited new album from Uberzone. We'll also be giving away a few
of the new cd's as well as a bunch of other freebies. Check back here
later, or sign up for our mailing list to get all the info on that.

If that isn't enough, we also have an amazing producer coming out from
the East Coast to do a little live set for us (you are not ready for
this), along with the Ambient Mafia in the back room, Viberation doing
visuals, and the E.B. dj's owning the main room like they tend to do.
I don't know about you, but it sounds like fun to me.......



Uberzone LIVE with Davey Dave
(Nitrus / City of Angels / Astralwerks / TCR / L.A.)
SF Ideology Album release party

His early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on taste-maker
indie dance label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed club
tracks that established Q as one of the leading American producers of
breakbeat music. These singles were charted consistently by DJs like
Florida's DJ Icey and the UK's Adam Freeland, among others. His
remixes of Sarah McLachlan, The Crystal Method and BT also established
him as one of the biggest names in the American dance scene. Spin
Magazine named Uberzone as one of the six producers to create "the
biggest beats ever." Q does have Faith in the Future. "Sometime during
my life I turned from a pessimist into an optimist. Faith in the
Future ties into technology, electronic music and my lasting desire to
live in the Jetson Age." Perhaps that's why Uberzone's debut album,
"Faith in the Future" has a feeling to it unlike any other electronic
album. It recalls influences from quirky sci-fantasy film soundtracks
to "Planet Rock" to dream-pop to the energetic, future breaks that
Uberzone has created in ways no one else can approach.


J.Hazen
(Sound of Habib / Virus B-23 / System Rec / NY)

For quite a few years now this guy has been producing the wickedest
beats, but would never perform. After a bunch of badgering, some good
intentioned insults, and a few 3rd party threats, we're finally able
to bring out what I consider to be, one of the most talented producers
in the U.S. Although he's just recently had his 1st couple of official
releases, his tracks have been rockin parties around the world for
years. And to top it off, he's going to be performing a live set for
us!!

Check out a mix from J.Hazen. Recorded Live on Halloween, this set is
being dubbed the "Zombie Prom" mix. This one's nice and
bouncy.....YEEEAAAH!!!!
http://www.soundofhabib.net/audio/j_hazen-zombie_prom_set.mp3


In the Evil Breaks room:

Bam vs. Icon
Aaron Jae
M.O.D.
Athena


In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:

Harken vs. Actual Rafiq
Seventh Swami
Speakeasy Ray
Hickory
Sixty4k

mixes, more info, more stuff:
www.EvilBreaks.com <http://www.evilbreaks.com/>


-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

Message-ID: <347df33a0711300852v5bd8045dmd2cdd9d3b2dc31e3@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 30 Nov 2007 08:52:33 -0800
From: filter.sf@gmail.com
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

	boundary="----=_Part_1140_7791721.1196441558058"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Filter:: Techno Excusions w/ David Last, Kontakt + Solekandi [Live]:: Anu :: No cover before 11

------=_Part_1140_7791721.1196441558058
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Come check out some homegrown Oakland jams...22 tracks ranging from dub
techno to hip-hop (that's right!) inspired tech-house to atmospheric
minimalism with chunky dance beats. You'll hear it first!

Tonight's Filter at Anu also features NY-based Foundsound recording artist
David Last with a Live set that leans toward techno, but draws upon funk,
dancehall and early electro/hip-hop. Reports from all over the U.S. say this
one's a killer!

Get there before 11:00 to avoid cover. $5 after.

Filter.SF featuring David Last [Goosehound, Foundsound/Brooklyn]
Plus Kontakt + Solekandi [live/dj]
and Saya [dj]

Anu
46 Sixth St, SF
10-2
no cover before 11, $5 after

-- 

www.myspace.com/filtersf

------=_Part_1140_7791721.1196441558058--

> Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote: In the Evil Breaks room:
>

> 11-12 M.O.D.

> 1-2 Uberzone LIVE w/Davey Dave
> 2-3 Aaron Jae
> 3-4 Bam vs. Icon
> 
> 
> In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:
> 
> 11-12 Hickory
> 12-1 Speakeasy Ray
> 1-2 Seventh Swami
> 2-3 Sixty4k (ambient)
> 3-4 Harken vs. Actual Rafiq (ambient)
> 
> --
> Uberzone live in SF - Saturday
> 
> Evil Breaks presents:
> DIRTY
> Saturday, December 1st, 2007
> Fat City (314 11th st. @ Folsom)
> 10pm-4am
> 21+
> 
> $10 presales:
>
http://groovetickets.com/ordersystem/groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=34375&PGname=Evil%20Breaks
> $10 b4 11pm & $15 after
> 
> 
> It's been a long time since we've had Uberzone play at one of
> our
> shows (Dec. '05), and it's been even longer since Uberzone
> has
> released a full-length album (2001). And during the past few
> years,
> there have been quite a few of us waiting very impatiently
> for another
> album. 6 years later, Ideology has been released, and we are
> finally
> getting some new music out of Q, and let me tell you, it was
> worth the
> wait!!!
> 
> Evil Breaks does it right once again with Uberzone playing
> LIVE along
> with Davey Dave at what is San Francisco's CD release party
> for the
> long awaited new album from Uberzone. We'll also be giving
> away a few
> of the new cd's as well as a bunch of other freebies. Check
> back here
> later, or sign up for our mailing list to get all the info on
> that.
> 
> If that isn't enough, we also have an amazing producer coming
> out from
> the East Coast to do a little live set for us (you are not
> ready for
> this), along with the Ambient Mafia in the back room,
> Viberation doing
> visuals, and the E.B. dj's owning the main room like they
> tend to do.
> I don't know about you, but it sounds like fun to me.......
> 
> 
> 
> Uberzone LIVE with Davey Dave
> (Nitrus / City of Angels / Astralwerks / TCR / L.A.)
> SF Ideology Album release party
> 
> His early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on
> taste-maker
> indie dance label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed
> club
> tracks that established Q as one of the leading American
> producers of
> breakbeat music. These singles were charted consistently by
> DJs like
> Florida's DJ Icey and the UK's Adam Freeland, among others.
> His
> remixes of Sarah McLachlan, The Crystal Method and BT also
> established
> him as one of the biggest names in the American dance scene.
> Spin
> Magazine named Uberzone as one of the six producers to create
> "the
> biggest beats ever." Q does have Faith in the Future.
> "Sometime during
> my life I turned from a pessimist into an optimist. Faith in
> the
> Future ties into technology, electronic music and my lasting
> desire to
> live in the Jetson Age." Perhaps that's why Uberzone's debut
> album,
> "Faith in the Future" has a feeling to it unlike any other
> electronic
> album. It recalls influences from quirky sci-fantasy film
> soundtracks
> to "Planet Rock" to dream-pop to the energetic, future breaks
> that
> Uberzone has created in ways no one else can approach.
> 
> 
> J.Hazen
> (Sound of Habib / Virus B-23 / System Rec / NY)
> 
> For quite a few years now this guy has been producing the
> wickedest
> beats, but would never perform. After a bunch of badgering,
> some good
> intentioned insults, and a few 3rd party threats, we're
> finally able
> to bring out what I consider to be, one of the most talented
> producers
> in the U.S. Although he's just recently had his 1st couple of
> official
> releases, his tracks have been rockin parties around the
> world for
> years. And to top it off, he's going to be performing a live
> set for
> us!!
> 
> Check out a mix from J.Hazen. Recorded Live on Halloween,
> this set is
> being dubbed the "Zombie Prom" mix. This one's nice and
> bouncy.....YEEEAAAH!!!!
> http://www.soundofhabib.net/audio/j_hazen-zombie_prom_set.mp3
> 
> 
> In the Evil Breaks room:
> 
> Bam vs. Icon
> Aaron Jae
> M.O.D.
> Athena
> 
> 
> In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:
> 
> Harken vs. Actual Rafiq
> Seventh Swami
> Speakeasy Ray
> Hickory
> Sixty4k
> 
> mixes, more info, more stuff:
> www.EvilBreaks.com 
> 
>

We went to (the second) opening day @ Boreal last Friday. It was all fake snow, got pretty icy at night.

Upshot is that they were open till 9, and everyone pretty much wimped out after dark. Snow machines were on & blew us a nice fresh base. Main lift & pipe aren't open yet, but we had the park to ourselves! 

N.S. open as well. . . Can't go 110% until my knee is completely healed, but hell. . . I can still go!

peace

CKG

> > 
> > His early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on
> > taste-maker
> > indie dance label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed
> > club
> > tracks that established Q as one of the leading American
> > producers of
> > breakbeat music. These singles were charted consistently by
> > DJs like
> > Florida's DJ Icey and the UK's Adam Freeland, among others.
> > His
> > remixes of Sarah McLachlan, The Crystal Method and BT also
> > established
> > him as one of the biggest names in the American dance
> scene.
> > Spin
> > Magazine named Uberzone as one of the six producers to
> create
> > "the
> > biggest beats ever." Q does have Faith in the Future.
> > "Sometime during
> > my life I turned from a pessimist into an optimist. Faith
> in
> > the
> > Future ties into technology, electronic music and my
> lasting
> > desire to
> > live in the Jetson Age." Perhaps that's why Uberzone's
> debut
> > album,
> > "Faith in the Future" has a feeling to it unlike any other
> > electronic
> > album. It recalls influences from quirky sci-fantasy film
> > soundtracks
> > to "Planet Rock" to dream-pop to the energetic, future
> breaks
> > that
> > Uberzone has created in ways no one else can approach.
> > 
> > 
> > J.Hazen
> > (Sound of Habib / Virus B-23 / System Rec / NY)
> > 
> > For quite a few years now this guy has been producing the
> > wickedest
> > beats, but would never perform. After a bunch of badgering,
> > some good
> > intentioned insults, and a few 3rd party threats, we're
> > finally able
> > to bring out what I consider to be, one of the most
> talented
> > producers
> > in the U.S. Although he's just recently had his 1st couple
> of
> > official
> > releases, his tracks have been rockin parties around the
> > world for
> > years. And to top it off, he's going to be performing a
> live
> > set for
> > us!!
> > 
> > Check out a mix from J.Hazen. Recorded Live on Halloween,
> > this set is
> > being dubbed the "Zombie Prom" mix. This one's nice and
> > bouncy.....YEEEAAAH!!!!
> >
> http://www.soundofhabib.net/audio/j_hazen-zombie_prom_set.mp3
> > 
> > 
> > In the Evil Breaks room:
> > 
> > Bam vs. Icon
> > Aaron Jae
> > M.O.D.
> > Athena
> > 
> > 
> > In the Ambient Mafia Chill room:
> > 
> > Harken vs. Actual Rafiq
> > Seventh Swami
> > Speakeasy Ray
> > Hickory
> > Sixty4k
> > 
> > mixes, more info, more stuff:
> > www.EvilBreaks.com 
> > 
> > 
> > -- 
> > --------------------------
> > < Brandon / DJ Bam >
> > 
> > DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> > http://www.getbammed.com
> > http://www.evilbreaks.com
> >

Tonight DEF's Radio Integrated will be broadcasting live from Filter at Anu
in SF.  Of course we strongly recommend that you actually go to the party
itself.... But if you can't make it out, we're bringing the party to you at
home.  This month's Filter features the stellar minimalist dub and techno
producer David Last playing a live p.a. set, plus residents Kontakt +
Solekandi and Saya.

Tune in to Radio Integrated tonight, Friday the 30th, from approximately
10pm - 2am Pacific Standard Time.  You can find us at
http://www.zer01.net:1200/

For more information on Filter and tonight's event, check out their myspace
page at www.myspace.com/filtersf .


Love Chelsea for Radio Integrated

http://www.zer01.net:1200/  :  radiointegrated@gmail.com
